Still kind of a hack, but better than the hack that was in place before. In the future, maybe a cmake check is better.
Is the performance penalty that big to warrant an accuracy setting?
It depends on the cpu really, on cpus from the last ~5 years it may result in a slight performance *increase* actually.  On cpus which lack support for native FMA it can murder framerates.
I think we should avoid the extra setting then. All CPUs from Recommended Specs have FMA as far as I'm aware  If anything, we can make a CPU check to avoid older CPUs having the huge performance hog

At the very least, it should default to on. But I also agreed with Ani, I don't think a setting is warranted. Maybe make it an option in the other direction? That is, make it "PPU fast fma" and false by default. If someone really needs to they can enable inaccuracy.
I think it shouldn't check for m_use_fma. This would make setting work consistently.
The point is for the setting to be forced on fma enabled CPUs

let's hope and someday we can play the ps2 in this great emulator thanks for your efforts

> let's hope and someday we can play the ps2 in this great emulator thanks for your efforts    Why? The point of RPCS3 is to emulate the PS3, not to try and fully emulate the PS2 as well    All PS3s can play the PS2 Classics titles from the PS Store, so it makes some sense as to why the ability to play them on RPCS3 is implemented, but there's absolutely no point in emulating an entire second console when for one, there's already a very well-known PS2 emulator out there; and for two, only a relatively few real consoles can actually do it    If you want to play PS2 games then get PCSX2, because you'll be playing PS2 games much sooner than if you were to wait for RPCS3 to do it
Not to mention the PS2 emulators are kernels not programs, eg they are lv2

Shouldn't you remove very first sys_prx.todo? Because function is somehow implemented, even not fully, but you add new todos that specify the work. @elad335

The general use of the public "sys_prx_get_module_list" frunction from https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/master/rpcs3/Emu/Cell/Modules/sys_prx_.cpp#L199 is implemented here, but there more uses to the syscall which are not implemented here so the TODO is still needed.  Basically only bit 1 of "flags" arguments handling is implemented here, but the other bit is not.  @sampletext32
So, the "todo" should be more precise, not general. So if you cover one bit, todo should cover the other. It would help in future problems investigations. Correct me, if I am wrong.
Ok, done. @sampletext32

Travis still wins by speed (more correct cache inheritance), so there is no need to remove it.  About appveyor, I'm not so sure.

Well there's something fishy afoot. There must be something wrong with the way the Azure is configured on RPCS3's end. On mine, the linux caching is excellent and beats out travis. You can see it [here](https://github.com/JohnHolmesII/rpcs3/pull/2). Windows builds are at least faster than appveyor, so we can yeet that into the sun.

@Nekotekina The pr works sometimes. Any environment variables exported can sometimes be corrupted by a single quote. It is random. Look at the Artifact for the windows build, a single quote is in the filename. SOmetimes the single quote shows up in the "BRANCH" variable, which breaks compiliation, since it is expanded by macros in main_window.cpp. I think I'll either have to report and wait for a response from Azure, or do a workaround by making that code read in a file or something. I already put in a workaround for the GitHub release description, but there is work needed for others.

Alright, well I've worked around all but one of the side effects. I think the changes to main_window are even for the best: rpcs3 version checking should be unified imo.    @AniLeo The "all but one" just happens to be something related to the release artifacts. The title of the release will have an apostrophe at the end, as seen [here](https://github.com/JohnHolmesII/rpcs3/releases/tag/build-480f2e013ae65265fca884ecd279cc24c4f63293). The description part (that has the hash and filesize) is properly protected against the bug, so it should be easier to parse. I think it should be easy to scrape the title tho and simply discard the final apostrophe, but I don't know the details of that on the website's end.    Other than that, I think is should be squared away.
As the website is right now it will work fine since it uses the tag name in URL which is correct, but you may want to fix that release name either way

@Nekotekina It doesn't appear that the llvm libs have sha256 attatched for windows. Can you add that so I can make the Windows build automatically redownload based on checksum? Same thing with glslang.

Well, in the mean time I simply inlined the hash for now. The script can always be changed later I suppose.    In addition, I made changes to how caching dependencies is done. The previous setup was rather poor, but now it is quite robust.

Well, I think due to the issues with RPCS3's azure pipeline being temperamental, the other changes I had planned are best reserved for another time. In addition, there is a dearth of options available for build caching on Windows. I'm looking into something rather hacky, but even if it works, it's best reserved for another PR. Azure is at least as fast as appveyor was, and is usually faster, so I think the PR is mergeable as is at this point.
Nice work!  If you're removing Appveyor you also need to add the GitHub Releases setup to azure.
If you remove Appveyor I need to update the website as well so don't merge before that    Edit: No update was needed, I fixed what I was misremembering some time ago

@hcorion Wow, thanks for reminding me, I completely forgot. Deployment is set up and working.    @Nekotekina In order for deployments to work, Azure will need more permissions. In azure pipelines, select the rpcs3 pipeline and there should be a prompt that the pipeline needs "updated permissions" in order to run.
Need to add cacert.pem download to the windows artifact.
@JohnHolmesII Can you just use the same github connection as llvm-mirror?  It's called RPCS3-Token

Well, there seems to be a bug in the way Azure handles variables set from scripts. Even simple strings get corrupted with a mysterious roaming apostrophe, which is nondeterministic. I will likely need to manually scrub vars that are passed around. Do not merge until this issue is solved, or else we could corrupt various stages of deployment.

Async still has to be disabled for Sunset Heights heights to not be solid black (in 2D or 3D):    first/async on:  ![2020-03-08 10_53_56-FPS_ 30 09 _ Vulkan _ 0 0 9-11fc57f4-fixes _ Ridge Racer7 3D License Ver (Full G](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20983844/76168749-bbc79d80-612f-11ea-89fd-7a093dda3d80.png)    async off:  ![2020-03-08 10_59_13-Window](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20983844/76168735-9cc90b80-612f-11ea-8d63-a89d9860a7cd.png)    3D/async off (black on 1st run with async on):  ![2020-03-08 11_09_57-FPS_ 29 99 _ Vulkan _ 0 0 9-11fc57f4-fixes _ Ridge Racer7 3D License Ver (Full G](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20983844/76168757-c7b35f80-612f-11ea-949f-49718c8c7e57.png)
Obviously you need to first build a cache. Run rr7 twice with async on and sunset heights works just fine.
Ok, so it's expected behavior to have the background not render anything until you enter, play, exit and reenter with async on (or at least to to current expectations)?

For rr7 you only need to boot upto the namco logo, close the game and restart. The shader is used once until you restart so if using async it will have stored a black image the first time because the shader is missing. This is a limitation of how it works and will be improved with other techniques.

_"This is a limitation of how it works and will be improved with other techniques."_  Cool, just confirming it's only expected because of 'current' design. It's a trivial thing but I know other games like Backbreaker are the same way and it's not the most user-friendly thing. Thanks!

How are alternate 3D modes/shaders going to be tracked?    For anaglyph, I'm a big fan of Dubois Red-Cyan, as it drastically reduces eye strain for me: https://github.com/dolphin-emu/dolphin/blob/master/Data/Sys/Shaders/Anaglyph/dubois.glsl    And of course side-by-side support would make this work nicely in VR without having to decode Red-Cyan and dealing with the issues there.

If you are in the RPCS3 discord, go here and keep scrolling for a while to see my woes with trying to build this fucking thing. The guide got me past the part of building it now, but not actually getting the thing running at the time of writing: https://discordapp.com/channels/272035812277878785/272035812277878785/682730269266280498

Well, there are more things to consider, like ninja and ccache.  For ccache, you just need to install it from the repository.    My configure commands:  ```bash  cd build-release (some arbitrary location)  CXX=g++-9 CC=gcc-9 cmake ~/rpcs3-dev -G Ninja -DUSE_SYSTEM_LIBPNG=ON -DUSE_SYSTEM_FFMPEG=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DUSE_NATIVE_INSTRUCTIONS=ON -DUSE_COTIRE=OFF -DUSE_CCACHE=ON  ```  ```bash  cd build-reldeb (some arbitrary location)  CXX=g++-9 CC=gcc-9 cmake ~/rpcs3-dev -G Ninja -DUSE_SYSTEM_LIBPNG=ON -DUSE_SYSTEM_FFMPEG=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo -DUSE_NATIVE_INSTRUCTIONS=OFF -DUSE_COTIRE=OFF -DUSE_CCACHE=ON  ```    My build command:  ```bash  cd ~/rpcs3-dev  nice ninja -C /mnt/ccache/rpcs3-release  ```    Don't copy commands blindly.  I disabled native instructions for RelWithDebInfo build because valgrind doesn't support AVX-512.

Should probably file a bug report there so they can fix it before mesa 20 releases

It's not a bug though, it's intentional. And it has already been raised on their end, we'll see what happens. See [this bug report.](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/mesa/mesa/issues/2502)    It's an unfortunate problem with spec, there is seemingly no way to tell the driver "I don't want you touching my passes, render them in any order". I suppose they assumed vulkan would only be used for games where you have control over when a pass starts and stops, but on rpcs3 we have to constantly start/stop to handle vulkan events that cannot be done when a pass is active (another asinine restriction in the spec). It seems for proprietary drivers, setting no dependency at all frees up the driver to do what we want, but RADV is following spec strictly which means things are just fucked. As for why NVIDIA's driver freaks out when any dependency is declared with any options - I have no idea. I'd have to reach out to someone from their end for advice and I'm not sure its possible to do so efficiently.

This is really hype.    Is every kind of string included (e.g. log messages)? If so, you'll possibly need to rework the logging too, so that 13x's log parser and users can still parse it and search for issues language-agnostically (e.g. by prefixing each message with a specific error code or enum).    Also,  > Defaults to the english strings found in the code (same as before).    This is a bad idea. It let's untranslated lines slip through the cracks. English should be treated as any other language.    Neither of these are a blocker if this PR is for setting the groundwork for a fully localized RPCS3 though.

Log messages are not translated. That would be unfeasible to manage.    It's not a bad idea to fallback to english because:    1. it's easier to miss something that isn't there than to miss something that is wrong.  2. translators can mark and comment stuff in the Qt translation software and every entry is marked as "not edited" anyway to begin with  3. I'd rather read something in english than not at all

> Log messages are not translated.    I see, that's fair.    > it's easier to miss something that isn't there than to miss something that is wrong.    The problems with this are the following:  - first, I didn't say nothing should appear in their place. In videogames it's usually a placeholder text / enum, and I think that's the way to go about it too.  - second, the people that are going to translate RPCS3 will definitely speak English (they have to be able to). This means that English text will very easily slip through the cracks, simply because people won't notice it's not in their language. Happens with me quite often for example, and I dare to bet it happened to you as well at least once.    > the Qt translation software    This however changes the situation, didn't know this is a thing. I'll join back to the Discord server and check things out maybe. If that's how it works, that's great then.    > I'd rather read something in english than not at all    Placeholder enums are crafted in a way that delivers the same key message as the given piece of text, still in English. The point of them is their formatting that gives it away, even to a simple end-user, that they should not be seeing that and should report the missing translation asap. It's also more generic and clean to have every single translation separate, including English.    This is a non-issue if the aforementioned translation software cleanly reports these missing translations though.
Most of the logging is not really english, infact it's function names and variables names.  Translating those is a receipe for disaster, so it won't be added in the future.

How would you even translate function names and variable names cleanly? How did this even make sense to you and why would anyone want that? Nonsense. Should be obvious I was talking about that smaller amount of less symbolic, actually english messages.

In ideal world logging will only be shown to those who request it, and normal users will never see any of it. Logging should be intended for developers only and we can make the assumption that anyone developing for this project has to understand english to some degree.    I know we violate the above statement in various places by f.ex. not showing message dialogs to users, but the correct solution would be to add information to UI instead of making logs translateable.

I agree with that 100%, that's why my initial reaction was `I see, that's fair.`. My only counter would have been that despite this, we are still showing the log window to every end-user right now - but as you said, those few pieces of information regular users might need the log window for should be communicated through the UI instead.

The crowds are fine, the bug is that rpcs3 is behaving as if CPU blit is enabled. The crowds look like trash because you don't have WCB enabled. CPU blit is also why performance is so bad; I'm investigating why this is happening.

Ok, this game is just poorly written, rpcs3 is actually correct in this case. Game is sampling a partial texture with overdeclared height which means we need to load from CPU to get the missing bits. I'll try and make the code more lenient but this just opens us up to more bugs in other games which do not like this kind of hack.
Added a temporary workaround for broken games which hides this issue for now.

I have to say that I really don't understand the latest changes

7bd1843 and 9837e38 deal with the issue of DS4 reporting a battery level after around 12ms after connecting via Bluetooth. It was not apparent previously because the battery level polling was done late enough for the battery level to be available.

d475644 disables LED battery indication outside of `pad_led_settings_dialog` because it is not consistent. The feature works as intended in-game, but we're not polling battery level while in settings dialog. Consider this: the user enabled LED battery indication at 50%, the LED becomes yellow. Then the user closes the dialog, keeps RPCS3 open and expects the LED to correctly indicate the battery level, but it will stay yellow until the settings are opened again or the emulation is started.    To make it even more consistent, I'll make it so the LED is reset back to a static color when pad thread is terminated.
The explanation is missing as comment in the code.  Also, I don't like the timer. I think you can just add it to get_next_button_press.

If you're RSX limited (99% RSX load) I can guarantee using a large value will result in a noticable drop. The reason you may not be seeing any difference is that in most games, most setups will be choking on SPU performance anyway, so hobbling RSX throughput only increases the RSX load metric without much variance in ingame framerate. Its not possible that a real PS3 has several milliseconds of lag, which means the setting right now is largely hiding the Cell emulation lag and lower values will be more feasible in future as performance improves.

Sorry if this is a daft question, but is the effect of this setting influenced by your processor?    If it's not—i.e. the same setting has the same effect on the same game regardless of processor—then I think it would be nice if some testing could be done to find optimum settings for particular games, and potentially make 'patches' for them (I don't know how that could work in the scope of RPCS3, but it's just my two pence)    Then again, I suppose the above suggestions could be considered a rather hacky solution to a problem which could be naturally mitigated via future RSX code optimisations

Let me get this straight.. the race conditions lie in **games' code**. Because emulation code speed tends to be very inconsisent (unlike realhw where everything tends to be much more consistent) issues arising from games' race conditions may actually appear on **nearly all cpus, configs and gpu setups**.    To answer your specific question about "RSX optimizations", the answer is the opposite.  The faster RSX executes its' code, the more likely those races are likely to cause crashes.  Our SPU emulation is relatively slow compared to other parts (namely RSX, PPU) which helps causing more issues as well.

> I changed my us settings globally last build now they are all stuck 300us globally and I have to manually adjust them all. Please make the universal reset button work at least.    Change it from config.yml with a text editor, or delete the whole file to reset your settings. Idk, 2ms (2000us) is waaay too large. In fact a lot of values people are settling on are significantly massive. For example, 2000us is the difference between 53fps and 60fps, or a performance drop of 12%. With that in mind, I strongly suggest more granular testing with small incremental steps to avoid general users setting very large values and doing youtube howtos with unoptimized settings.

About this PR:  I don't see any change with loading shaders (tested with P5 with 4500 shaders) and didn't see any changes here, but compilation of all those shaders slowed down a lot. On master that lasts for a tenth of a second, on this PR lasts for about as long as loading them (about 40s). In game I see no difference.

@Dravonic @Xcedf Could you guys verify the speedup from the threading of the loading phase is still there? Its important to also mention the type of media used, I suspect HDD and SSD will behave very differently.  So, @vietnam13231, is your rpcs3 loading from SSD or HDD?

@kd-11 Speedup definitely still there. There are a couple things to take into consideration about @vietnam13231's comment:    - An SSD will definitely help since there is a lot of file reading taking place. I'm on and HDD and the first time I load the game the speedup isn't that great. Closing the game and loading it again after files are already cached in memory is where I get the most benefit.  - Driver shader cashes are finicky (at least for me on AMD) and will sometimes decide to compile the shaders again instead of using the cached shaders, which is probably why @vietnam13231 got the long compilation step. The compilation step is essentially unchanged by this PR.

I can also confirm there's a noticeable speedup in loading shaders. My testing was done on a hard drive.   It also seems to be working fine on OpenGL with RADV, although not as fast as Vulkan (as expected).

One thing you might need to keep in mind for default initialization over memset is that IIRC default initialization is only guaranteed to default initialize members and not padding bytes. So if any of these cases expect padding bytes to be zeroed, `memset` is preferable.

Which is also an advantage of default initializers here because we don't memcmp or memcpy from referenced objects where padding bytes state is important. Accessing padding bytes in other ways is UB anyways (unless referenced by char/uchar ptr).

there any different between pure Wayland and  X11 or XWayland build ?

So, Wayland is a protocol, X11 is a protocol. Xwayland is a build of the Xorg server allowing you to run any X11 program on a Wayland compositor.    This PR only makes it so a user using only Wayland can build rpcs3 without having to drag all of the X11 dependencies.  Both will work on Wayland and X11, but when no X11 headers are found the resulting binary will only work on Wayland.
You need X11 libraries/headers to build Mesa with OpenGL support. What we really need is optional OpenGL support.    https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/6740

No you don’t, since glvnd introduced the new libOpenGL ABI you can build Mesa with desktop OpenGL support without depending on libGLX or X11 libraries.    #6835 would be nice to fix though, I might give it a try after that.

Uh, do you know of a compiler which defines this constant? And would you expect other compilers to recognise your SSE2 implementation is actually a `memcpy()` and optimise it that way? I wouldn’t consider this a proper fix.
On Linux, gcc and clang define it. And I know that memcpy is better on this platform for some reason. We support limited number of platforms anyway.

You are probably confusing it with `__GNUC__`, which is actually defined. But it will also be defined on other platforms, such as Windows when using some mingw distribution. And you should profile it, but I highly doubt MSVC will use worse code in `memcpy()` than your SSE2 implementation.
__GNUG__ is C++ variant of __GNUC__.  I measured MSVC memcpy long time ago, on older PC, it was surprisingly slower than Linux version.
Honestly, dunno about mingw and MSYS2, depends on their memcpy implementation. If it uses MS CRT then it may be occasionally slow.
Thanks for the information, maybe it’d be useful to take it with Microsoft, providing them the implementation in glibc as an example? This could improve a lot of things for your Windows users.

I just added that flag, it can’t hurt but I wouldn’t expect any system to have a regression here, otherwise it is a bug which should be reported to the libc as it would affect every other part of the emulator.
I take back what I said, and with c++20 alignment hints can be made with std::assume_aligned instead.  also just use std::memcpy.
Oh, I didn’t know that we’re using C++20 now! I just pushed a new version replacing the asserts with `std::assume_aligned<16>()`.

well, it doesn't support c++20 fully yet but there is a workaround: derferencing pointer with aligned type then retaking addressof of it.  e.g. 16 byte alignment hint using v128: `reinterpret_cast<u8*>(&*static_cast<v128*>(vm::_ptr<void>(0)));`  also the alignment hint should only be applied for the paths where std::memcpy is called because it is only valid there. and add a todo for when std::assume_aligned would be supported.  Also add a hint for ASSUME((size % 16) == 0).
Sadly, it's only available on Linux. There is also __builtin_assume_aligned.
Or just give up and let memcpy check alignment internally.
Idk what to do with this PR, close it for now? Also, I doubt std::assume_aligned ever affects memcpy.

It could depends on the code the compiler decides to generate. Not in this case, but when the size is known the compiler will try to avoid calling `memcpy()` directly.    You can play with the `-march` flag, with the `N` constant, and with the selected compiler in this example: https://gcc.godbolt.org/z/Aw5r9N    In x86 instructions, u means unaligned and a means aligned, but AFAIK since the Skylake architecture there isn’t any difference in execution between the two any more. This doesn’t mean we shouldn’t aim to attempt to make the compiler generate an aligned access for older architectures, of course, but optimising for that doesn’t seem very useful to me.    When the compiler generates a libc call though, I don’t think it will change anything indeed.

This PR lowers the framerate a bit on my computer, from ~22 to ~21 fps, but this could also be due to the high variance, I’d need to measure the amount of frames in N seconds to give more precise results. But we [already established](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/6882#issuecomment-546855864) my current bottleneck is actually not starting to draw early enough anyway, so this may not be relevant.    On master, `rsx::convert_linear_swizzle_3d<unsigned int>()` takes 5.82% of the CPU, plus 1.50% for `__memmove_avx_unaligned_erms()`.    On this PR, `(anonymous namespace)::copy_unmodified_block::copy_mipmap_level<unsigned int, unsigned int>()` is taking only 4.09% plus 1.55% for `__memmove_avx_unaligned_erms()`.    On this PR plus #6948, `(anonymous namespace)::copy_unmodified_block::copy_mipmap_level<unsigned int, unsigned int>()` completely vanishes, and `__memmove_avx_unaligned_erms()` now takes 3.11% instead.    The time spent waiting for Vulkan events to complete stays about the same at ~33%, it seems to reach ~37% on the third case, but I’m not too sure about that, it could also just be that there is less to do on the CPU so it can spin loop more.    Note that all of that is on an i5-8350u CPU alongside its UHD 620 GPU, I expect the benefits to be much higher on weaker CPUs which have a stronger GPU.

This PR even in its incomplete form is much better for people with proper graphics cards. Ofc the graphics card has to be able to keep up in the first place. Compute operations are very heavy in terms of GPU interruption, and if you're on intel IGP, expect worse performance. Other GPUs however have a decent uplift, I've only been able to check RADV so far, but I gained around 7fps.

You need to enable the debug tab in your GuiConfig.ini file inside the GuiConfigs folder in your config folder. I think on linux its ~/.config/rpcs3/GuiConfigs. I feel like we're not communicating effectively. We don't need the gcc attributes check in this case. Only local users build with march=native, appimages build with march=sse2 always. In fact, appimages don't even build with gcc at all, we use clang for the official builds. With that being said, you find a curious difference between GCC and Clang; clang does not allow the method definitions to even exist if the march level is below it; i.e if march is SSE2 all SSE3 intrinsics will be undefined methods and throw errors, hence the inline asm workarounds.
I use [Agner's instruction tables](https://www.agner.org/optimize/instruction_tables.pdf) as a reference for that kind of stuff. It includes cycles, latency and more for lots of x86 CPUs.
Why did you squash anyway in the end?
I'm sorry, didn't realize the communication regarding it
No worries, I was just surprised. :)

It actually was a typo (I added a semicolon after the `__attribute__` in the previous revision…) that prevented both clang and gcc from using the AVX2 version.    With this attribute in place now, I believe we build both versions on all three OSes, and select the correct one at runtime.
There, I believe I fixed all of your comments.  I also split the commits so that they are easier to understand separately.

Well, the target attribute doesn't work the way you want it to, but it got clang to compile AVX and SSE4.1 code without much problem which is a win. Multiversioning usually works if there is a fallback overload with the same function name marked with a "default" target. Its not important for rpcs3 anyway and the proposed solution does generate the assembly output I wanted so it should be good. I'll have to check the u32 paths though since they're untested.
Do you have a stash of tests btw, so that I could verify I’m not regressing things in the future?

Yes, I have a stash of tests, but not for this particular situation. I do provide them and reference data if you happen to touch something that I have hardware tests for. I should probably put them somewhere easily accessible.

Windows intel driver was reported to work correctly, so maybe we can split INTEL into INTEL for proprietary and ANV.  As for the proposed solutions: The problem is that there is no true way for the windowing side to know what the driver side is using for surface dimensions. This is why we use suboptimal report if it is supported instead. i.e Just because the window changed and we know about it does not mean the driver is in agreement, there is indeed a ~1 frame latency, but this is fine as it is stable. Also gets around a user dragging the window frame to resize which causes a lot of problems and any sane implementation will reintroduce the same lag.  The way I see it, there are 2 possibilities:  1. Separate intel into 2 drivers and use manual mode for ANV, keeping the driver supported method for proprietary driver.  2. Optionally hide the window frame until the transition is finished if it is too distracting.

Hi, thanks for your quick answer!    I know the driver side is ultimately the one deciding on the buffer dimensions, but it should do so in accordance with what the window system tells it to do, not the other way.  And that’s already how it is in rpcs3 with the swapchain creation requesting the current `client_width`/`client_height` from the Qt window.    I don’t have any Windows license to test the proprietary driver, so what follows is pure guess on my end and I’d welcome someone else to validate them.    On Wayland at least (I know much less about the X11 ways), there is no such frame of latency because the size of the surface is directly derived from the size of the buffer the WSI attaches to it.    I just tested on both Wayland and X11, there is no regression on X11 (which already supported fullscreen resize) with this PR, nor is there any additional bug during resize compared to current master.  Note that on X11 we also use anv, it’s only anv on Wayland which doesn’t report `VK_SUBOPTIMAL_KHR`. Resizing the window doesn’t seem implemented on Wayland for now, but I wouldn’t expect it to cause any additional lag like it does on X11, it would just require changing the swapchain whenever the compositor requests a different window size, which I consider saner than introducing a frame of latency.    What do you mean by possibility 2 btw?  If we mark all drivers as not supporting `m_wm_reports_flag`, there should be exactly no frame of latency on any of the drivers, and it would also simplify the code quite a bit.
You don't need Windows license to test it. You can use Win 10 without activating a license , completely legal.

Relying on the GUI is not good, we have already changed the GUI platform once before and it was a pain. We only use if for OGL because setting up wgl is not pretty, but vulkan is very flexible and handling the contexts ourselves makes things like headless rendering possible (rendering without a window is actually supported and implemented).    So here comes another problem: there is no "hey I'm about to resize" signal that is cross-platform. I already went through all this about a year ago, you can see the history of the gs_frame.cpp file for the win32 message queue hooks I had to set up to see windowing information before it could reach the drivers. However, driver bugs led to horrible situations including windows dying, unclosable windows processes and BSOD, so I would very much like to never go back to that. The way normal games deal with this is that you do not resize the window manually, it is driven from menus so the game already has the knowledge. There is no random user dragging the window border around in that case, which greatly simplifies what needs to be handled.
A simple solution presents itself here: this problem is caused by wayland not supporting the surface expiry flags. As such, just make wm_reporting flag false when running under wayland.

Good morning, and thanks for the suggestion, I now force-pushed a better patch.    I’d welcome testing on radv to make sure it doesn’t regress any on Wayland, but it can’t be worse than no resizing of the buffer at all.    It seems to have also fixed resizing the windowed surface on Wayland, which behaves perfectly with no visible frame of latency and the buffer adopting the new swapchain size immediately!

@linkmauve You can remove them, but I found them to be much better for window border dragging resize instead of flooding the system with swapchain recreation. Due to some driver bugs, there was a much more complex system in place before this with Win32 hooks, but this has since been removed.

Ok, this system doesn’t seem to work on Linux at all, or at least not the way you describe it. Do I understand correctly that atm on Windows when you resize the window the buffer will continue to be at the previous size until you release the mouse button, at which point and only then the swapchain will get recreated at the size of the new buffer?  Because that’s totally not how I see it on either X11 or Wayland.    Maybe a better solution would be to keep the one frame delay on Windows, and to use the latency-less version on Linux?

Yes and no. On windows, resizing will invalidate the swapchain but its rate is not as bad as actually resizing every 'tick'. Ofc on windows only NVIDIA has this implemented that I can test, I do not have access to a suitable intel IGP to confirm how it behaves on that platform. AMD does not have any swapchain status reports at all on windows. Sounds like we're going out of our way to try and appease the nvidia driver as much as possible because we are; that driver has caused me endless frustration in the past when it comes to swapchains.

I use wayland on linux, and I've never noticed any kind of issue with resizing. In fact, resizing for me was better behaved than on windows. Does rpcs3 default to xwayland? Its possible I'm actually using X without realising it, I don't pay that much attention.
Try exporting `QT_QPA_PLATFORM=wayland` before starting `rpcs3` to make sure of that, or `QT_QPA_PLATFORM=xcb` if you want to make sure to use Xwayland.
I'll try when I get home from work :)
Yea, rpcs3 uses the native window handle from the Qt GUI window and decides which backend to use based on that.

My bug report about https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/mesa/mesa/issues/1979 was deemed invalid by an Intel developer.    Imo the best solution forward would be to make the Qt window layer propagate the size changes when it wants to change it (so that your Windows way continues to work, and on better windowing systems we can have the zero latency way), with e.g. an event sent to `GSRender` to recreate the swapchain.    What about the suggestion I gave in #6835 to use `QOpenGLWindow` and `QVulkanWindow` as the base class to avoid any kind of platform-specific context/WSI creation?  I have never used them but AIUI they are meant to handle this kind of thing on its own.

I've thought about writing a simple page-sized allocator into the space that's already there but since theres no deallocateCodeSection/deallocateDataSection functions that will ever be called anyway that would be a bit pointless, unless the allocator would just be there to allow usage of another memory region when the first one is exausted ?

I have written a new LLVM JIT memory allocator to take advantage of multiple segments so there really should be no way to get LLVM out of memory now (unless actual alloc call fails). Because LLVM can never deallocate JIT memory as it is now, I see no better way.

Well, this approach can work for now. Although I don't get the point of calling reserve/reset instead of allocating all possible segments at startup.

Everything accessible in the low <2GB area is already reserved at startup.  The reserveAllocationSpace override is there so that we don't switch allocation segments mid-module (otherwise trampoline stuff, whose code path was never actually used before, can break).
I meant emulator startup. Code under MAP_32BIT path doesn't seem to do it.
Ok, I've changed the MAP_32BIT path to greedy reserve as much as it can as well.

That would only address the immediate problem, and possibly only one broken case out of numerous ones. The more abstract issue here is that changing VFS paths leaves the host filesystem in the state which is different to the startup state fresh after booting the emulator. This PR breaks ability to resume playing Metal Gear Solid 4 after playing the MGS1 section:    This is what happens:  1. MGS4 creates file `/dev_hdd1/cache/s/dev_hdd1/cache/s/gclvar.bak` (after failing once, it mkdirs and tries again then succeeds)  2. MGS4 launches MGS1 self (mgs/stage/module/en.self) as new program  3. You play through MGS1 self (created gclvar.bak file is still there and accessible)  4. MGS1 launches MGS4.self back again (with some args telling it to use gclvar.bak)  5. ---- /dev_hdd1/cache/ FOLDER IS CLEARED ---- (why ? we never switched games, only exes)  6. MGS4 fails to open `/dev_hdd1/cache/s/dev_hdd1/cache/s/gclvar.bak` (fs_open returning CELL_ENOENT) because cache was cleared, and proceeds to play as if you launched it normally (unable to progress).    Log file from build that contains this PR:   [RPCS3_mgs_bad.log](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/3744452/RPCS3_mgs_bad.log)      Here's a save file that when loaded in MGS4 immediately goes into MGS1 (ASMJIT SPU required for MGS1 to work): https://files.sshnuke.net/BLUS30109G5DA88B89.zip just crawl into the vent or die and exit to finish that section    On master, everything proceeds correctly, here's log from build that doesnt contain this PR (cache cleared before running game):  [RPCS3_mgs_good.log](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/3744471/RPCS3_mgs_good.log)

You may want a clean start here.  1. Save current work with `git checkout -b newbranch`  2. Reset master to upstream `git reset --hard upstream/master`  3. Pick your 2 commits `git cherry-pick newbranch~1 && git cherry-pick newbranch`  4. Delete newbranch `git branch -D newbranch`

Seems that at idle the accuracy is approx 16us, but if switch to the performance governor the accuracy is 10us. Since the load of RPCS3 will cause any system to raise to maximum power state, it makes sense to test the accuracy of this at maximum power state as well.     So I suggest simply setting the min quantum to 10us rather than 16, this will also have the benefit of "fixing" the behavior when the accuracy is set to usleep for values of 30us, since   `thread_ctrl::wait_for(remaining - ((remaining % host_min_quantum) + host_min_quantum));`  would evaluate to 0 for values of 30us, causing us to simply spin, and not take advantage of timerfd.

This morning, I made some tests with all the railshooters I know on ps3.  Results:    *Deadstorm pirates (NPEB00409):  Combined with a pad configured, I'm able to enter the menus (for example, I press the Circle on my controller to avoid connecting to Playstation Network), do the calibration and enter the mode selection (pressing circle).  The mouse is recognized as "Calibrate Motion Controller n°7"  When in full screen, I can't see the mouse pointer, so I can't calibrate.  When the window is maximized, it's working well. Whell I'm in fullscreen, I must make big moves with the mouse to move the crosshair. I tried to increase "mouse acceleration" to 20 and deadzone to 0, but it didn't change anything. The crosshair moves slowly when in fullscreen. I'm on a 4k screen (don't know if that's relevant).  The game plays nicely (remember to active "write color buffers").    *Mad dog mccree: calibration ok, no slowdown in fullscreen. I'm able to reload the gun in fullscreen by firing outside the screen. Pb: Game freezes while in the main street.   *Maddog 2 & The last bounty hunter: same behaviour.  *Fast Draw showdown: can't calibrate (the crosshair stays on the left side). Strange as it seems the same engine as MadDog.    *Heavyfire: afghanistan: stuck on "select profile-player 2"  *Heavyfire: shattered spea: stuck on "select profile-player 2"    *Men In Black: alien crisis: can't navigate the menus with the pad. I'm able to launch a game, but it asks to press L1 which I can't.    *House of the Dead 3: very similar to Deadstorm pirates: calibration ok, but cursor very slow in fullscreen. Reload is automatic. With Vulkan: poor performance and exploding vertices. With Ogl: ok. Pb is you can't reload (you need to shake the gun for that).    *House of the dead overkill: for the calibration, I can fire with the Middle click (X button), not the left one. Can't use a pad to go back.  *resident evil umbrella chronicles: same

Just from reading the code you iterate over a set of dirs and only remove the shaders_cache dir. So what's the purpose of counting that single dir

> So what's the purpose of counting that single dir    The entire point of this PR is that there can be more than one `shaders_cache` directory. This can happen for games with multiple executables, or when you eg. first started the game unpatched and then patched it later. PPU and SPU cache clear handle such cases correctly, shader cache clear bails out after the first directory matched (which might be empty!) and doesn't clear the rest.
Ah. Sorry. I didn't see the QDirIterator::Subdirectories flag

Turns out DLL names changed from 1.0 to 1.1 branch.    libeay32.dll -> libcrypto-1_1-x64.dll  ssleay32.dll -> libssl-1_1-x64.dll    AppVeyor VS2019 image does have OpenSSL 1.1.1    https://github.com/appveyor/build-images/blob/master/vs2019.json#L106  https://github.com/appveyor/build-images/blob/master/scripts/Windows/install_openssl.ps1#L70    I installed the executable locally and checked the DLL names, so it should work now    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10283761/63660236-69cfb380-c7ad-11e9-9f21-dcfe980a8f16.png)

No change here,I still can't download the database unless I install OpenSSL or copy those two files from some other program folder into the rpcs3 folder  And btw libeay32 and ssleay32 are not inside the older versions of rpcs3 or in any environment paths but it worked before
It works for me, but could be because I already have OpenSSL 1.1.1 installed. Maybe it requires some other libraries.

It works if I paste those two files into the rpcs3.exe folder(libcrypto-1_1-x64.dll and libssl-1_1-x64.dll)  They are not part of the rpcs3 download archive so someone else will have the same problem.
OpenSSL DLLs have always been distributed separately due to licensing issues. This just updates them to newer versions. You can find these DLLs in our AppVeyor artifacts.
Why we didn't need them before(even with different name)
You did need them, you just had OpenSSL on your system and it used the available libraries.

little clarification on this guys if possible.    I have been using RPCS3 with several frontends and its one of the few to present issues as far as refinement goes due to being presented with the UI prior to the game actually loading.   (not a concern if playing at the pc, but when setting up a frontend to couch game its undesirable).    Now launchbox has several means to work around this, and in most cases (including rpcs3) they are adequate - when at the pc.    When streaming over steam, steam captures whatever is there. Hiding it is impossible.   Ive gone so far as moving the render window and GUI window to separate displays and steams capture method still loves to grab the GUI window first.    The one guaranteed way around this, which ive been watching and waiting for - is a CLI means of launching directly and circumventing the gui.   I had assumed this is what `--no-gui` was intended to do.    After a bit of testing, and now reading through the relevant issues on github, it seems it isnt intended to, or doesnt function that way?  Is that correct?    I'm basically using `rpcs3.exe --no-gui "FULL\PATH\TO\ROM\FILE"` which results in rpcs3 quickly opening and closing it looks like, or simply opening the GUI and no game (presumably running invis)    So if it does not function as I'm assuming, is it possible that we get a command line switch for the aforementioned, and perhaps if your feeling really generous, one for --fullscreen so fullscreen can be forced if playing remote without having to resort to toggling the gui option on/off beforehand.
If nothing change since I lasted, things are still as broken as I said in this thread in the comments above. The feature is thus not really usable atm.    The `--fullscreen` flag is not a bad idea.

The problem is that we haven't properly implemented the no-gui option yet. So if you run a game with llvm recompilers then it will open a window with a progress bar. As soon as that window is completed the game will close itself. You can work around this issue if you use interpreters and asmjit. This is a known issue. So it it basically working "as intended" for now.

How about this instead: just store a string and timestamp in the blist file and load it as a map. At loading, just grab the filename and do a map lookup for the file time, storing the correct ctime in the list. During sort it becomes a simple a < b operation. This is a much cleaner solution imo.

Why Faudio instead of Cubeb? Which is cross-platform and provides better latency than Xaudio.

@Illynir the main rationale was, that I could reuse the code of the existing XAudio2 backends and get identical behaviour. FAudio is also fully crossplatform and should work just as well on Windows.  I also looked at cubeb, but since cubeb only takes it's audio data via a callback i didn't see an immediately apparent way to make it fit rpcs3's current audio architecture.

FAudio depends on SDL2, and you need to find a way to include those. Probably just need to install the dev packages in the travis env and others. Don't forget to update the requirements on BUILDING.md once you do that.

I've made the necessary changes to CMake and the travis build, but sadly I have no real way to make it build with Visual Studio and appveyor, so the backend is Linux/CMake only for now.  It would be great if someone with Windows and Visual Studio could look into making it build there as well.

VKRendertargets.h line 266 a little typo ssize_t instead of size_t

Its not a typo actually, ssize_t exists on posix systems and they refuse size_t there as the argument. Looks like msvc is the odd one out here, both clang and gcc want the size argument to be a signed long int, while msvc wants unsigned. If you fix one you break the other one it seems.

@kd-11 doesn't `gsl::span` use `std::ptrdiff_t`? That makes the most sense. Why `ssize_t` in the first place?

I don't know if its defined in spec to always be ptrdiff_t, its some gsl::span::index_type type though. I'll look deeper into it before finalizing this.    EDIT: On posix, the span::index_type is actually signed but on msvc its not. Its why I had it set to ssize_t on linux for 1:1 match, but msvc did not like this.

@kd-11 Don't know how it can be unsigned on MSVC, seems to be ptrdiff everywhere: https://github.com/microsoft/GSL/blob/master/include/gsl/span#L361  Though yeah, the most robust solution would be to use cast to `::index_type`. Anyway, if it works - it works, unless it overflows.

Merging as hotfix, fixes #6323

page_mapped constant doesn't make any sense.  page_allocated bit should always be checked so it can be assumed and ORed with flags just inside check_addr.  Checking other bits should always be explicit.  Checking only page_writable is also fine since it implies page_readable (there is no "write-only" pages)
There is no such thing as page allocated with no-access on ps3, maybe the ability to do that should be removed from vm::page_protect.  For now im defaulting check_addr to readable + allocated.

Please review, Its touching a long lived flaw with current lib loading options.
This seems very crashy. Opening the trophy manager or resizing icons in any of the multithreaded views can cause the application to crash, and sometimes even the whole emulator fails to appear.

So it's likely the reason both this and code in current master can be creashy is because GUI update calls are invoked from outside the GUI thread - and it's possible that this PR makes it "worse" because it's invoking those concurrently and not from just one "trophy update thread", like it is now.    With `QT_FATAL_WARNINGS` it is easy to spot which calls throw errors, although you may have to reconvert some `ICON0.PNG` images to RGB colour profile to avoid a now-critical `iCCP: known incorrect sRGB profile` warnings.    I am currently experimenting with `QMetaObject::invokeMethod`, which hopefully will execute those Qt calls on a correct GUI thread. I am getting somewhere, but looks like there is a ton of places which have to be delegated to a separate thread and that may eventually break code relying on order of execution of Qt widget updates.
I really have no idea what crashes you are talking about
I can confirm running this PR with `QT_FATAL_WARNINGS` does not produce any errors now.

Btw what about VS2019 support? Both VS20[19-17] can be supported by specifying ` (DefaultPlatformToolset)` as Toolset and explicitly passing `/std:c++17`. That way VS2019 users would not need to install `v141` toolset, it would obscure real toolset value thou.
There's currently an unknown bug with 142. The emu builds but does not launch.

That is because std:c++17 is not specified, also `rpcs3_default.prop` adds `/std:latest`(which is partial c++20 in case of vs2019) as additional option. I successfully built rpcs3 with c++17 and 142 the toolset. Tested on P5, not extensively thou.    EDIT: I can push c++17 v14[1-2] changes here so they could be tested, but `hidapi` and `libusb` would require updating their respective submodules. Would have to build those 2 with 141 for the time being.     EDIT_1: Maybe it is better to place `hidapi` and `libusb` project files in this repo? It would be a lot easier to make MSbuild build system changes.

Here's a patch for the mac build. `<filesystem>` is too new for apple, so a newer xcode is needed.  ```diff  diff --git a/.travis.yml b/.travis.yml  index a7e7dda13..c2cd5028c 100644  --- a/.travis.yml  +++ b/.travis.yml  @@ -19,7 +19,7 @@ matrix:             install: "docker pull rpcs3/rpcs3-travis-trusty:1.1"             script: 'travis_wait docker run -v  (pwd):/rpcs3 -v " HOME/.ccache":/root/.ccache --env-file .travis/travis.env rpcs3/rpcs3-travis-trusty:1.1 /bin/bash -ex /rpcs3/.travis/build-linux.bash'           - os: osx  -          osx_image: xcode10.2  +          osx_image: xcode11             addons:               homebrew:                   packages:  diff --git a/rpcs3/cmake_modules/ConfigureCompiler.cmake b/rpcs3/cmake_modules/ConfigureCompiler.cmake  index 7fb92c779..ec104d109 100644  --- a/rpcs3/cmake_modules/ConfigureCompiler.cmake  +++ b/rpcs3/cmake_modules/ConfigureCompiler.cmake  @@ -66,6 +66,7 @@ else()   		endif()   	elseif(APPLE)   		add_compile_options(-stdlib=libc++)  +		set(CMAKE_OSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET "10.15")   		set(CMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS " {CMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS} -Wl,-image_base,0x10000 -Wl,-pagezero_size,0x10000")   		set(CMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS " {CMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS} -Wl,-no_pie")   	elseif(WIN32)  ```

I'm not sure if relevant, but one of PCSX2's developers created a Mesa patch to allow threaded(?) PBO a few years ago.    https://patchwork.freedesktop.org/project/mesa/list/?submitter=15643  https://github.com/PCSX2/pcsx2/issues/1403#issuecomment-364456965    It'd probably be worth making sure there's an open bug report for Mesa and letting the developers know there's still affected users; they're usually pretty great about investigating problems as long as they're made aware they exist.

Threaded PBO upload might be able to claw back some of the performance, but with our usage the data is never meant to leave the GPU in the first place. There is only so much that can be done before we run into pcie bandwidth limitations.     I'll open an issue for Mesa tomorrow and update the commit messages and comments with links to it.

LLVM 9 unlikely to be finalised and widely available before September.    Historically speaking, no code for the amdgpu target has ever been backported for a maintenance release (i.e. the recent llvm 8.0.1), and there also hasn't been any continued fixes/updates once the release has been forked for the Release Candidate stage.  So unless distros manually backport the fix, very few people will get it before 9.0.    I don't think it's too reasonable to expect people to run experimental drivers.  As LLVM 9 won't be released for at least another 2 full months, it would be a good idea to at least print a warning about this being a known issue with LLVM 8.0, and to direct them to the OpenGL renderer in the meantime if they're experiencing issues.

I don't think we need to be too concerned if some users on linux aren't able to upgrade their vulkan drivers. I just did some quick testing with OpenGL and it seems that radeonsi performance is genuinely excellent; it's able to surpass vulkan performance in some games even.      Hell, people are sleeping on OpenGL on this very thread even, here's a quick comparison with mesa_glthread=true on radeonsi.    <details>    <summary> Yakuza 3 demo 4 way comparison </summary>    ### OpenGL Master  ![Y3openglmaster](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26352541/60066547-7f552e00-96d5-11e9-963b-7b3934868dd0.png)    ### OpenGL PR  ![Y3opengl](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26352541/60066548-811ef180-96d5-11e9-8105-bfd7c57cc941.png)    ### Vulkan Master  ![Y3vulkanMaster](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26352541/60066550-83814b80-96d5-11e9-8359-7ffda08d0e0c.png)    ### Vulkan PR  ![Y3vulkan](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26352541/60066556-854b0f00-96d5-11e9-8075-6f466c1c2385.png)    </details>    Yes, some games are seeing way better performance than vulkan when mesa_glthread=true is set. Not all games are running faster with OpenGL, but it's not the end of the world if a user that doesn't have the technical know how to upgrade to LLVM 9.0 downloads this update.     So long as there's a log message that tells users that a black screen is expected behavior for LLVM 8.0.

Did you test many games?    Last time I played around with usleep (including seeing what happens when you skip the last quantum) a *ton* of games broke. In particular, some games (I believe Journey was one) do small usleeps instead of yielding, so skipping the last quantum just completely broke the game (it wouldn't get past the logos).

@ruipin I tested all the games I have. I tested Nier a bit, and that game spams 1us sleeps as well, and it still works.     Besides though, this won't change behavior for games requesting sleeps that small anyways, since we still don't sleep for values that small.     I know that some games can be tolerant of terrible usleep timing (I messed around with it a lot when I was trying to find the speed difference between windows and linux in that game, and you can do literally anything (including intentionally breaking it) and the game will still play fine)

Journey requests small sleeps that vary in size, and can go above the minimum quantum value on linux.    The problem is some games are extremely sensitive, and so are some CPUs. 4 thread CPUs especially are very sensitive to this kind of thing. I wouldn't merge such a change without a *lot* of testing.    Try setting affinity of RPCS3 to 4 threads, and see if anything changes.

I'm not sure that this is as unstable as you think it is, we aren't "skipping" the last quantum with this commit, we're making sure that we handle it accurately.     The windows code is inaccurate for values above 500 us, and the linux code on master is inaccurate for values above 100 us.     You can see in the results I posted above, while 100us works fine on master, just 200us suddenly causes linux to sleep for 281us. Even such small values can be wildly inaccurate on master.    That being said, while I don't expect any negative effects other than ~2% higher cpu usage seen in the overlay, I haven't found any games that respond positively to the added accuracy. So there's certainly no rush to get this merged.    I'll test this on my computer with hypthreading disabled later and see how bad it is 4T cpus, but testing from people with other usleep sensitive games would be nice.     If this method is really determined too expensive for 4T cpus (I doubt it), then I have another commit that I can push that I was playing around with earlier that should make usleep about 50% more accurate on linux (without spending any extra time yielding).

You need to specifically test 2C4T CPUs. I remember the windows hack (where we don't spinlock for the last quantum for accuracy, instead just sleep the whole duration) was put into place *specifically* for those. They got severely impacted whenever we increased spinlocking on usleep even slightly.

Disabled 2 cores of my 4C8T cpu (7700K) as per ruipin's suggestion and retested all my games.    Even in situations with 100% cpu load there didn't seem to be any difference in framerate between master and this pr. I put extra testing into P5 since rui mentioned that many users on windows with 2C4T cpus complained about loss of performance in that game when usleep was first made more accurate.     That being said, no games see any measurable improvement with 4C8T enabled either, so it'd be great if more people could test this PR.

I've pushed a new commit that scraps the old idea entirely, but this new one is now much improved over master with no drawbacks at all.    The default minimum quantum on linux appears to be 50 microseconds on linux. Now with this commit we don't have to spin as much as before for values between 50-100 microseconds. Wouldn't shifting the load to OS yield() cause problems for low-end CPUs? A 7700K isn't a good enough test for this imo, we had issues with this code in the past when tested on intel's 4 thread CPUs (older gen i3s and i5s) so I think we need more user testing here.  As for the code itself, its good.

The latest commit doesn't end up yielding any more than master does, the accuracy improvements for larger values were achieved just by sleeping better.     Two games from my testing see less time spent yielding, Persona 5 has about 1-2% less PPU usage with this commit, and Journey has 8% less PPU usage.

This in turn sounds like a weak argument against the macro if you only use it in 5 occasions. (Ironically the small usage makes that a weak argument for the macro as well)

The main intent of this PR is to avoid mixing two different ways (strings and macros) to identify the extension names. Since we started to use the macros (I can easily find them by looking at "VK_.*_EXTENSION_NAME" btw) before the strings , I though it was the recommended way. I don't really mind if we use strings (although I personally prefer macros :slightly_smiling_face:) but I think we should stay consistent by doing so.

I would have preferred the macros as well if they resembled the strings they map to. This would have been straightforward if khronos didn't feel the need to add the _EXTENSION_NAME suffix; makes the definitions not map directly to what is in spec. The other macros used were only for surface extensions which are different depending on the target platform, I plan on changing that as well to only have one and pre-select the proper string from vulkanapi.h. Thisisfine I guess; it bugs me but if enough people want it I can still just merge it.
redefine the macro without the _EXTENSION_NAME XD

You kid but I was considering that as well. To redefine them to match the spec entries the first two parts are all caps and the rest are always no caps. Or to wrap extension strings in some struct or something that would allow to pass something resembling the extension I'm trying to load.

Demon's Souls is a weird case, since the game has a specific race condition (game code, not RPCS3 fault) which causes the flicker. The more inconsistent the frame pacing, the more easily it triggers. I suspect frame pacing with the TSX fallback path is more inconsistent than before.

Isn't the flickering you're thinking of the full screen effect which appears with write colour buffers enabled? This seems different from that, since I used a patch which disables the dynamic exposure (removes the need for write colour buffers). Is there a tooltip or information elsewhere about what this option does?

> Is there a tooltip or information elsewhere about what this option does?    I *think* that is either the same or a similar idea of what manual thread pausing does, limits the amount of SPU Threads running

Yes, this is basically an automated version of the thread pausing hack that is often used for Persona 5.    I'm not an expert on this topic, but from what I've understood Spurs is a multithreading library that developers use to assign tasks for SPUs to execute without having to write the threading code themselves. This option limits the amount of threads for these     The upside is that there's less chances for resource contention, less context switching on thread-limited CPUs and hopefully less time wasted on synchronizing the threads, The downside is that games were never intended to be ran with limited thread count and thus all kinds of issues could arise.

Putting this to CPU tab would mean that this'd be one of the main settings that people would try for improving performance, and I'm not sure if this project's leaders would approve it. Besides, it'd require some other modifications to CPU tab to make room for a dropdown menu there and I'm not sure what megamouse would think of it. Either way, if you guys want to seriously suggest it then I'd recommend starting a new issue for it.    @Zangetsu38 Yes, but only values between 1-5 activate the limiter code, 6 causes it to be skipped. So technically the game code could spawn more threads, not that it would make any sense. Besides, I think it looks better this way.    https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/ea554ae8285e18d4ab4dcbded9ef1b94c78f9021/rpcs3/Emu/Cell/lv2/sys_spu.cpp#L260
@Psycho-A When it works, it works great, but some games would not boot unless set to Unlimited (RDR, Scott Pilgrim)

If anyone with knowledge about some of the remaining rpcs3 warnings (@elad335 @Nekotekina maybe?) and think of a way to resolve them, I can put those changes here too. The problem is that those instructions are wrapped in macros that disable them for missing instruction sets. However the macros are just left blank, generating a warning. For example, after the preprocessor is run, we get code like the following  `const auto sa = (A, index);`    which is just weird

I've gone ahead and implemented the changes to silence 3rd party code. I put in some PoC workarounds for the macro issues; these changes may or may not be okay.    Currently, the clang travis build produces no warnings of any kind. The log has gone from 8665 lines to 1220.    I still have more plans. Neko recently turned on extra warnings (-Wall) for gcc that was not turned on for clang. I plan to unify the flags between the 2 compilers, since they are mostly compatible. I will try to get as close to exact -Wall compliance as I can in future commits. Perhaps even -Wextra if enough gets done. Hopefully we can maintain this into the future.

I've pushed an update with quite a bit of changes to what's going on. When adding -Wall to the compilers, many more warnings were exposed. It was both too many for me to handle, and also well outside my knowledge to fix. So while refactoring the cmake setup to be (hopefully) more clear than it was before, I decided to simply enumerate all the warnings as silenced, rather than not use -Wall.    This may seem odd (and that list is disturbingly long), but it provides a number of advantages. For one, the sight of it may encourage devs to begin working on them. For another, the log output is much cleaner, meaning that *new* PRs will have new warnings immediately highlighted for all to see, **preventing issues from creeping in**.    It also provides a neat little way for contributors to help the issue, as this is larger than one dev can handle. Simply pop a warning off the silenced list, repair the necessary code until it is fixed, then open a PR. Recently several PRs were introduced that had small warning-fix scope, and hopefully we can get more of those.    I still have plans here.  1) GCC has an old issue rearing its head, #1818. It seems to have come back either in recent GCCs, or because I'm an idiot, or both. Before there was a warning silence in place (-Wno-invalid-pch), but readding this doesn't seem to help, likely because it is simply in the wrong place. It might be easier to fix than it looks, so I will look into that first.  2) MSVC has not been worked on at all, and I will have to do that. I have a wild fantasy that we might switch the windows build to clang and I won't have to do any work, but I cannot rely on that, given the "inertia" of the project.  3) Find a way to slap on -Werror. This will be useful as new PRs will *clearly* have warnings marked by CI, and it can't slip past reviewers who might be focused elsewhere.    And of course, I will be addressing the other review comments.
Also, my changes obviate #4989, so when this is done that can be closed.
Please rebase and resolve current reviews, other warnings can be cleaned up in a follow-up PR  This needs to be merged before hcorion's 16.04 PR

Updated my post above with a quick pass through some titles, noting some that are broken now on this PR. I'll continue to update it with new commit pushes.
The correct fix is to increase the texture size when decoding to be aligned to power of 2.

NOTE: If testing and you get a vulkan "verification failed' error in vkTexture.cpp, lower your resolution scale to below 284%. This means you ran out of rpcs3's VRAM budget due to the high resolution scale.  This situation will be patched with a hotfix before this PR is merged with a proper vulkan resource management PR to come later on.

Have you looked into [this](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/SysInfo/getting-the-system-version)? It seems like using a manifest, even tho it would work, is still deprecated. Getting the string from the kernel seems like plenty sufficient for what we need in rpcs3.    "To obtain the full version number for the operating system, call the GetFileVersionInfo function on one of the system DLLs, such as Kernel32.dll, then call VerQueryValue to obtain the \\StringFileInfo\\\\ProductVersion subblock of the file version information."

The GetVersionEx function is deprecated because developers used it to check whether the operating system would support certain feature ("it's Win10 or newer, it must support X"), and Microsoft hated that as it wants to reserve right to introduce or remove OS features with any update. You can ignore the warning and use that function regardless as long as you know the limitations it has, it's not going to be removed afaik.    And thanks for that tip, I'll check it out once I got some time.
@MSuih Does rpcs3 manifest exes? If not, `GetVersionEx` would return wrong version.

```  typedef unsigned __int64 QWORD;  ...  const QWORD AppCompatFlags     = *reinterpret_cast<const QWORD*>(PPEB + 0x02C8); //	0x02C8  const QWORD AppCompatFlagsUser = *reinterpret_cast<const QWORD*>(PPEB + 0x02D0); //	0x02D0  ```  Either can be used to determine if in compat mode. If any flags are set then compat mode is enabled.    I tested for all modes available for this executable (Vista, Vista SP1, Vista SP2, 7, 8). `AppCompatFlagsUser`: 19 and 28 bits are always set for any tested mode. `AppCompatFlags`: 22 bit is always set for any tested mode. Both are 0 when compat mode is disabled.    P.S. Anyone knows where is `QWORD` define? It is apparently not defined when including `<windows.h>` wich is a bit strange since there is [official doc](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/openspecs/windows_protocols/ms-dtyp/ac050bbf-a821-4fab-bccf-d95d892f428f) for it.    **EDIT:** It does not matter which member to use for compat but `AppCompatFlagsUser` is for user mode and the other is for kernel mode so it would be more logical to use user mode one.

@MSuih for MSVC you need to add additional manifest file trough properties.  Here is redacted [rpcs3_vcxproj.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/3109107/rpcs3_vcxproj.zip) vcxproj file.

I think I found a more lightweight solution and it does not require manifest.  ```  const DWORD peb_offset = 0x60; // PEB64 offset in GS register  const INT_PTR PPEB     = __readgsqword(peb_offset);    const DWORD OSMajorVersion  = *reinterpret_cast<const DWORD*>(PPEB + 0x118); //	0x118  const DWORD OSMinorVersion  = *reinterpret_cast<const DWORD*>(PPEB + 0x11c); //	0x11c  const WORD OSBuildNumber    = *reinterpret_cast<const WORD*>(PPEB + 0x120);  //	0x120  const WORD OSCSDVersion     = *reinterpret_cast<const WORD*>(PPEB + 0x122);  //	0x120    fmt::append(output, "Operating system: Windows, Major: %d, Minor: %d, Build: %d, SpVersion: %d", OSMajorVersion, OSMinorVersion, OSBuildNumber, OSCSDVersion);  ```  [struct PEB64](http://bytepointer.com/resources/tebpeb64.htm)  [PEB table](http://terminus.rewolf.pl/terminus/structures/ntdll/_PEB_combined.html)    Used PEB members are supported since first WinXP version so unless someone manages to run rpcs3 on something older this will always get the correct version.    Also as a bonus, this will return correct version of windows even when run in compatibility mode while GetVersionEx will return target of compatibility version.    [RPCS3_from_PEB.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/3109640/RPCS3_from_PEB.log.gz)    **EDIT:** I am not sure how to interpret service pack version member `OSCSDVersion` since `GetVersionEx` returns Major and Minor version for SP. Considering SP version numbers are usually low, first BYTE can be Major and second Minor. Needs to be tested on Windows version with SP.

The differences between OpenGL and Vulkan in some cases is because OpenGL supports float16 'natively'. In reality most vulkan drivers also do support float16 but they do not advertise this feature properly. The differences appear when the native float16 implementation is more accurate than the one we emulate with the shader. A config option "disable native float16 support" exists in config.yml to force use of the shader emulation path and should also 'break' OpenGL when enabled.

Glowy things in bad company are a programmer's error. Every test I have run on real hw says they should be black spots there (because the programmer forgot to add a saturate modifier somewhere, literally one misssing bit). Obviously the real PS3 somehow does not generate the condition that would require this, so I'm not sure if its a real regression. Its easy to add the saturate for them but this would be a hack. Ironically this would also hide other issues that appear due to broken clamping.

Added a workaround for the problematic instruction. It no longer behaves like real hardware but we cannot match exactly the PS3's TMU so I think going out of spec there is fine. Basically the texture filtering does not seem to match the PS3 exactly pixel-for-pixel which is expected. Since texturing is completely fixed function (non-programmable) a workaround is the only way to get around this. I can make the hotspots dance around the screen by altering the filtering even very slightly causes the hotspots to migrate. More research on this topic will be carried out at a later date, but likely only for academic curiosity rather than improving any games (NaNs are rather useless as they are often substituted with 0 anyway).

Has someone benchmarked this PR on a Nvidia Turing (GTX 16 or RTX 20 series) or AMD Vega (Radeon Vega 56/64 or VII) yet? Those GPUs offer double the FP16 performance, would be interesting to see the gains.

The version of glslang we use to emit SPIR-V may not have the optimizations built in to properly support fp16 as it is a relatively recent thing in the vulkan core spec, although the older AMD extension VK_AMD_gpu_shader_half_float seems to work correctly (there should be no difference to the emitter in theory, but you never know). A Vulkan tools update is coming soon to bring us to newer SDK versions, but it could be a few weeks before that is done.

What is the justification for disabling AVX completely?    Yes, a lot of CPUs apply a negative AVX offset, but a lot of people will set this offset to 0, and it's a waste to remove AVX when there is no offset. In addition, AVX is used in various critical regions (e.g. TSX code), and even with throttling it should still be faster than not having AVX at all. Or are there benchmarks showing otherwise?    You mention "context switch cost" - what context switch cost are you specifically referring to? Do you mean the need to stack/unstack the AVX registers? Won't they end up being stacked anyway even if unused?    If this gets merged, I would definitely be against a permanent disable - it needs to be exposed as a yaml config option *at least*.

It's not a "disabling AVX completely". It's allowing to avoid it where it's mostly unused (SPU ASMJIT doesn't emit code which makes real use of 256 bit wide instructions).  Anyway I want to test it first.

Doesn't LLVM use the same TSX path as ASMJIT? I believe your changes will affect LLVM as well.    Also, what do you mean by "SPU ASMJIT doesn't emit code which makes real use of 256 bit wide instructions"? As far as I understand, the TSX path emits AVX2 code on both ASMJIT and LLVM (since the logic is shared). Why does it matter if SPU ASMJIT doesn't otherwise?    Or are you proposing splitting the TSX path for ASMJIT and LLVM, and making ASMJIT only not use AVX? Then I can somewhat understand the logic, but I very much doubt most high-end Intel cores will even care - most of them will have an AVX offset of 0. And since TSX is present only on high-end cores, if feels like you're optimizing the TSX path for CPUs that don't have TSX? :thinking:    I concede that "disabling AVX completely" is incorrect, I should have said "disabling AVX in the TSX path".    Anyway, will wait for benchmarks. But I'd be very surprised if this improved performance, especially on high-end CPUs. I'm expecting the opposite, in fact, since this effectively doubles the number of instructions in the TSX critical region.

I would double-check why this is not an issue when not using CMake, before adding what is effectively a hack. I doubt MSVC is using a different version of time.h.

_TIMESPEC_DEFINED is set in msvc/config.h, and this file is included when building libusb using vcxproj file. These are the relevant lines:  https://github.com/RPCS3/libusb/blob/2e41930f74bbd8d741709283a106837d74065361/msvc/config.h#L8-L11  https://github.com/RPCS3/libusb/blob/2e41930f74bbd8d741709283a106837d74065361/msvc/libusb_static_2017.vcxproj#L81    Nothing inside msvc folder is used when compiling with cmake and thus this flag is never set when building with cmake.    If I understood https://github.com/libusb/libusb/commit/a34ba28b40d901afeeca084e6b7043fcf95cd935 correctly this issue used to affect the vcxproj too, but it was fixed by adding a definition similar to this.

`cellSysutilAvcExt` was introduced with firmware 1.50 and I believe only `cellSysutilAvc[...]` functions from the `cellSysutil` module were used before. The Logitech G27 is the only confirmed working racing wheel so far.     I've tested the Thrustmaster T500 (PID 0xb65e, Firmware 47) and it does not work.   (log: [RPCS3_t500rs_usbdtrace_gt5.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/3140777/RPCS3_t500rs_usbdtrace_gt5.log.gz))  The wheel does not calibrate like it should during bootup and instead goes into DualShock 3 emulation mode with 270 degree rotation (official details here: http://ts.thrustmaster.com/download/accessories/Manuals/T500RS/T500_RS_PS3_Games_Compatibility_Mode.pdf).    **EDIT:** T500RS is recognized by the game after pressing MODE + Left or Right on the D-pad, but no force feedback.    PS3-compatible Fanatec wheels like the Porsche GT2/3v2, CSR/Elite, and CSWv1 have a "PS3 Mode" which emulates a G25 or G27 depending on the firmware version, so they will probably work.    The following wheels still need testing with this PR:    Logitech (VID 0x046d):  - Momo Racing Force (0xca03)  - Driving Force (0xc294)  - Momo Force (0xc295)  - Driving Force Pro (0xc298)  - Driving Force GT (0xc29a)  - G25 (0xc299)    Thrustmaster (VID 0x044f):  - T150 (0xb65d ?)  - T300 (0xb66e)

It does get detected, the emulator detects inputs from the guitar now (again, without changing drivers), games that used to work like Rock Band 1 still work with your latest commit, but Rock Band 3 for example still has the same problem as master, where it thinks you're still using a joystick even when selecting "Guitar" on pad settings

You shouldn't use the guitar as a pad in rock band 3.  Rock band 1 & 2 use guitar through cellPad:  Your guitar => mmjoystick pad handler => cellPad hle => the game  Rockband 3 and a few other rock bands:  Your guitar => usb => sys_usbd => the game    When you're configuring pads you're configuring cellPad hle. Try to use a normal pad as player 1 and don't put your guitar in any pad configuration and try again.    Also if that doesn't work I'd appreciate a log with the last line of config.yml set to:  `Log: {sys_usbd: Trace}`

I did more reverse engineering for this syscall, turns out this syscall uses unique unlocking flags as opposed to `sys_lwmutex_unlock`.  The unlocking flags are being ORed in both syscall 117 and `sys_lwmutex_unlock`.  Any of those flags is enough for sys_lwmutex_lock to acquire the lock, and clears the flags.  When only the flag of syscall 117 is used, the return value of `sys_lwmutex_lock` is EBUSY.  `sys_lwmutex_trylock` on the other hand, accepts only the flag from `sys_lwmutex_unlock`, but clears both on success.    Testcase for all of this: https://github.com/elad335/myps3tests/tree/master/ppu_tests/sys_lwmutex_117%20syscall

After looking at some pseudo-regressions like genji, it has become obvious that they cannot be fixed in this PR as they require features that are yet to be implemented (e.g blit engine rotations). The old way worked because it was so broken that the wrong data was getting to the GPU. Rolling back the commits and enforcing strict memory management rules shows the same issues on master. Most of the noted regressions simply disappear when using WCB+CPU blit for this reason.  As such, this PR will be merged as-is for now and a follow-up PR will be done to address the missing features.
