Why not just support unicode properly?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47083527/52177835-27219c00-27c7-11e9-98fb-beb438d53159.png)  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47083527/52178007-1e31ca00-27c9-11e9-84cd-d41fa25cc7a2.png)  Half of the special letters now are displayed properly :)
> Why not just support unicode properly?    @danilaml https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/pull/5611#issuecomment-459393592
@raveskirza Ok. Feels like changing `render_text_ex` to operate on codepoints would be easier than trying to hack around utf8/16/32 to ascii conversions and replacements though.

Save text no longer clips through the border between items  <details>   <summary>Screenshots</summary>    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19759300/52180431-87780400-27ee-11e9-8f49-5bfe09570a6d.png)  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19759300/52180433-8a72f480-27ee-11e9-969f-7b2b969c8d1a.png)  </details>

@danilaml   > @raveskirza Ok. Feels like changing `render_text_ex` to operate on codepoints would be easier than trying to hack around utf8/16/32 to ascii conversions and replacements though.    Obviously the goal here is to support at least utf16.  The reason for the workaround has nothing to do with ascii conversions though, but rather with rendering and VRAM issues that have to be properly handled first.

@Megamouse well `render_text_ex` just iterates over plain `chars` which obviously breaks when dealing with unicode (past ascii): https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/a36d3af3b4fdbca94b84e590ec7df46f6caf0753/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/Overlays/overlay_controls.h#L271    Wouldn't need `s_ascii_lowering_map` / lowering, if `render_text_ex` iterated over `char32_t` codepoints and `get_char` did proper lookup for unicode charactes (since it should be supported by stb), though it wouldn't handle emojis and would probably require different font handling. Didn't know about VRAM issues.
Handling 100k codepoints is a lot more complicated than just resolving glyphs!
Makes more sense to eventually move to vector rendering for glyphs, but this introduces other issues in places. It will be done eventually just requires some more time and effort.

RPCS3 v0.0.5-30c6f275 Alpha   rsx_volatile  GPU: 'GeForce GTX 970' running on driver 417.71.0.0    Tested Catherine, Persona 5 and the triangle sample.  NV panel settings left at default. Using Vulkan with fullscreen mode,  vsync off -> All 3 games crashed within 10 minutes  vsync on -> Couldn't get the games to crash even after 20 minutes    So, the new vsync addresses the issues for me.

This version seems to fix the issue I've been having where Qt downscales fullscreen window to 720p no matter what the rendering resolution is. Even seems to automatically switch resolutions when going fullscreen during shader loading. Tested with both the appveyor build and my own compiled version.    Nothing else to really report as RX 480 user. Entering and exiting fullscreen seem to take slightly longer than they used to but the difference is very minimal. Tested a bunch of games and didn't have any issues with them.
I'm also curious if there is any perceptible performance loss.

Did comparisons with cube & triangle samples as well as handful of games, didn't see any difference in performance. I don't normally play with vsync enabled but gave it a quick test and performance with it seemed identical as well when compared to master.

Would it be possible to have backspace bound to some button? It's cubersome to move the cursor to that button every time one wants to erase something. Space as a button woudn't be too bad of an idea either. In addition I think the PS3 OSK also allows you to move the caret around, you could consider implementing that with shoulder buttons as well.    Also I don't like having shift and accept/cancel as face buttons. A more natural spot for shift would be a shoulder button imo and start would be more fitting as an accept button. I'm not sure what to do with cancel though, maybe it could be placed on the keyboard with no button assigned to it.

I don't have access to all buttons in native dialog right now without restructuring how pad input works. Caret itself doesn't exist yet as well and many other features. Right now its more important to just check that games do not crash.
@kd-11 When I wanna erase space in default name of world, game crashes...
And there is an isssue with special letters, but probably game crash is not caused by that.

@mavethee What is the default world name?  As for special characters, I did mention only ascii input is supported. Same as all native dialog elements. Needs a lot of font work before non-standard text is supported.

I think the issue he's having is that the default text contains non-ascii characters and your implementation assumes that only ascii characters have been entered. Maybe the backspace function uses a fixed chararter size or something? If you need a bandaid solution then wiping all non-ascii characters from default text could work.

Backspace just does text.substr(), not sure how that would cause the crashing, but the out of range definately hints at something of the sort where the special character is larger than ascii limit of 128. I'll run some tests with some non-ascii characters and see if I can reproduce.
Makes sense, we're unable to decode some of the characters. Will push a fix asap.

Had to just strip all extended codes and replace with the character '#'. Fixes crashing on polish characters. If the '#' replacement is too jarring, I'm open to alternative placeholder characters. Note that the replaced character is 'real' in that it exists in the string if you choose to confirm it. Its not just a visual effect/trick.
There are too many different variations for that to be feasible. For example there's over 30 different variations of letter A alone.
Added more buttons and remapped them to more closely match ps3. I think only the edit_text control remains, which will be important to support multiline and caret positioning.
Ouch. So only replacement with "#" left.  But thanks for fixing that error with erasing space between words :)

Too many variations unfortunately. Its really easy to write a replacement table manually but thats a tedious task given how many variations there are. I plan to eventually replace all text in the native UI with proper unicode support which will remove this limitation (all text variables encoded in utf-32). This is not going to happen any time soon though.
@kd-11 Nice. I will be waiting and learn some more stuff, because I wanna help you guys. Going to IT school in Sempteber, but learning on my own it's probably better :P
I'll hackishly map downward the characters instead of truly converting utf-16 to utf-8. Should help preserve characters in the high ascii range.

Upgraded the text rendering system to use extended ascii with all text converted to this representation. This allows a lot more glyphs to render correctly, and (e.g) makes french text readable. Not all characters can be represented yet, but its at least a step to support more languages.

Also added support for disabled keys e.g disabled enter key when multiline is disabled or spacebar when input with no spaces is requested. If the game sets a default text to OSK input, the caret stll starts at position 0. So if you'd want to replace it with your own text, you first have to keep tapping R1 untill you're at the other end before you can use backspace to erase it.    Edit: Also, if there are multiple text boxes in row with default text then the carat spawns in the position it was when last text box was closed. Meaning that if you entered a 3-letter word in first one then caret will start at 3rd letter in next text dialog.
@MSuih Fixed now. The crashes are possibly because the osk dialog never truly closes, just resets the interface. I must have failed to reset some variable.

Identified a bug in the overlay renderer where resizing the window from 1280x720 breaks clip regions. This must have silently affected save dialog as well (I suspect some entries were cut off but it was not reported). Will push a fix asap.
@AniLeo ping

I've made access violations pause the emulation.  It makes them always appear the last on the log, instead of letting other threads keep logging messages and hiding it.  This also avoids situations where other threads are starting to crash one after another after the first access violation.
Pushed an experimental commit. It should work, but please test for regressions or performance degradation just in case.

The removal functions are very dumb, they just recursevily iterate the directory and remove files ending with ".obj" or ".dat", or a folder named "shaders_cache". One question...what does the existing "Create PPU Cache" do so now we will have "Batch Create PPU Cache    This is what I tried:  1.Rename the data folder and run rpcs3  2.Set the logging method to trace  3.Right click on a game and choose "Create PPU Cache"(I thought it will create the PPU modules without running the game after that)  4.RPCS3 starts for few seconds and the only thing that happens is that rpcs3 is scanning the game disk for something and then stops,nothing is created after that and starting the game after that,rpcs3 starts to create the ppu modules like normal

As far as I know it can only compile the modules that aren't loaded at runtime.  For example Skate 3 loads another 25 modules only after you start a new game.  I don't think it is possible to compile any of those without reaching that point ingame.   The same would go for all the modules that are loaded right after boot, which is usually most of the modules.
You should probably mention this on the comment itself, otherwise no one guarantees some years from now no one will accidentally do that mistake again

Explanation why the extra granularity is required, I'll use Mahjong Dream C Club[BLJS10149] as an example:  3 values are used in the cb:  trophy[0x68] set to 2 before calling sceNpTrophyRegisterContext and 5 on reaching stage SCE_NP_TROPHY_STATUS_PROCESSING_COMPLETE  trophy[0x270] is set to contain the current trophy stage  trophy[0x274] contains a float reflecting the progress(completed/total), it is not important here    > seg001:002F34DC trophy_callback:                        # What CPU? I only see it happen immediately after a loading screen once or twice, usually the first loading screen (or when shader/SPU compilation causes stutter). In all those cases it's just the game's fault, causing the audio mixer SPU jobs to starve due to the large amount of SPU jobs right after the loading screen ends.    Again, try increasing the buffer duration (to e.g. 125000 or 150000) or turn on time stretching. Might help. Setting SPU threads to 2 or 1 also helps a lot with that game (frees up CPU time for audio).

Since this isn't the first time people have blamed this PR for games being broken, and until I get the chance to downgrade it to a warning, I will explain here what the following error means:    > Audio backend stopped unexpectedly, likely due to a buffer underrun    **This error means that the emulator ran out of audio to play, and thus stutter is unavoidable.** This could happen because the game is not driving audio fast enough for some reason (slow CPU, bugs, etc), or because the game crashed and therefore stopped driving audio.    Seeing this message last does **not** mean that audio is responsible for the crash. In fact, you will see this message every single time a game that was previously driving audio crashes.    To properly understand what caused a game to crash, look for what comes *before* this message (usually a Fatal message "F" in purple instead of Error "E" in red).

Hey @ruipin , I'm thinking of adding audio buffering and stretching to the PulseAudio backend as well. Do you think it would be a good thing to add at this point or it is not so useful anymore and effort should be more on something like cubeb?    Thank you!

I don't personally use PulseAudio, but I know multiple people do (it's the default RPCS3 audio backend for linux IIRC), so I don't think implementing buffering support would be wasted time. It probably wouldn't be too much effort either - I just didn't do it because I had never used PA before and so was not familiar with the API. Stretching is less useful (other than for very rare corner cases), and I believe PA doesn't have built-in support for it so you probably shouldn't worry too much about that part.    Take a look at the abstract AudioBackend class, which has comments describing what the API expects:  https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/master/rpcs3/Emu/Audio/AudioBackend.h    And then you can use OpenAL as reference:  https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/tree/master/rpcs3/Emu/Audio/AL    You'll want to implement the same methods with similar behaviour, and then report the capabilities accordingly, e.g.:  `static const u32 capabilities = PLAY_PAUSE_FLUSH   IS_PLAYING   GET_NUM_ENQUEUED_SAMPLES;`    I'm no longer active on the project, but let me know if you have any more questions.

Yes, the capabilities just represent sets of functionality that can optionally be implemented in the Backend.    By default (empty capability set reported), a backend simply gets fed audio data, and it plays audio until there's no more audio left. This is done by calling `AddData()`, as such every backend is *required* to implement `AddData()`. In this case, cellAudio does nothing special - as we get audio from the game, we feed it straight to the backend, and let it do its thing. This is essentially the current implementation of the PulseAudio backend.    More advanced backends might report the `PLAY_PAUSE_FLUSH` capability, meaning that they implement `Play()`, `Pause()` and `Flush()`. These methods allow more fine-grained control of audio playback, and if present cellAudio will be able to buffer data. For example, we request the backend be paused (using `Pause()`), we then feed in some data slowly, and then when the buffer is large enough we just call `Play()`. Strictly speaking, this is the only *necessary* capability for audio buffering, but there is no easy way of knowing whether a backend is currently playing or paused. As such, there is also the `IS_PLAYING` capability, which means the backend implements the `IsPlaying()` method. With these two capabilities, cellAudio will be able to provide audio buffering.     The reason why `PLAY_PAUSE_FLUSH` is separate from `IS_PLAYING` is because cellAudio can be slightly smarter about driving audio if only one of them is present - but you need both for audio buffering to work correctly.    However, without the `GET_NUM_ENQUEUED_SAMPLES` capability, controlling for a constant buffer size is more difficult. This capability means that the backend supports the `GetNumEnqueuedSamples()` call, which returns how many audio samples are left in the current buffer (i.e. how much audio there is left to play, assuming we stopped feeding in any new audio). Without this capability present, audio buffering is more prone to accidental buffer underflows / crackling, as it has to guess the current size of the buffer by keeping track of how many samples have been sent to the backend, and how much clock time has passed, which obviously isn't as accurate as being directly given this information by the backend. Turns out some audio APIs make it difficult to know how much audio is left in the buffer, so this capability is optional (but recommended).    Finally, there is the `SET_FREQUENCY_RATIO` capability, which describes that `SetFrequencyRatio()` is implemented. This is required to use the current time stretching functionality, hower time stretching is useful only in very rare corner case scenarios, so it's probably not worthwhile to implement it for backends where this isn't simply directly exposed from the API. OpenAL and XAudio both expose this, but AFAIK PulseAudio does not and would require manual software processing.

Thanks guys, that should be enough. I don't want to waste people's time debugging WinAPI any further.

I removed the print statements so you will not see any notification about whether it has detected hyperthreading or not. It will work as long as the CPU model reported by emulator contains the string "Intel". If you really want to test it then you can download the older version [here](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/rpcs3/rpcs3/builds/21190722/artifacts).    Oh, and there is only an implementation for 2c/4t CPUs, so anything further than that will not see any difference in performance.
ok thanks for the reply my cpy has 6c/12t so it will not get any performance improvement :(
I think Intel doesn't need this feature at all, this was just implemented to workaround Windows' broken Thread Scheduler on Ryzen CPUs

If this isn't needed then you can close the PR, I don't take offense from that. I just remembered that kd wanted to implement this but didn't feel like putting time into researching how to do it, so I thought I could do that for him.

I think it wasn't given much attention because it had barely any positive effects or even negative effects when used on Intel CPUs  This could still be useful if there is some way for the scheduler to actually benefit Intel CPUs, but if this does the opposite it can't be merged as is, specifically because Thread Scheduler is enabled by default and this would introduce a performance hit for no reason as is
The detection is important, so I would keep the ht detection and remove the thread assignment for now. It leaves the code open for optimization in other ways in future.
That seems logical. I commented out the related code, hopefully that's okay.
Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700HQ CPU @ 2.60GHz   8 Threads   15.88 GiB RAM   AVX+   TSX  F {PPU[0x1000000] Thread (main_thread)} Hyperthreading found!

Alright, should be ready to be merged now. The option won't probably have too much of an impact to performance (and it's limited to 2-cores with HT), but at least the option does something and there is a framework in case kd-11 or someone else improves the scheduler.    The lack of Linux implementation is not really an issue as it has better native scheduling than Windows.

Nope, it's not ready to be merged.    Nvidia GeForce 840M  Intel Core i5-4210U CPU @ 1.70GHz    Some games with enabled thread scheduler are REALLY slow.  The example - InFamous. With disabled thread scheduler - 3-5 fps.  With enabled - 0.5-1 fps, but i think it's slower.  Here is some logs.  [RPCS3_Thread_Off.log](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/2705197/RPCS3_Thread_Off.log)  [RPCS3_Thread_On.log](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/2705198/RPCS3_Thread_On.log)

Any performance differences are caused by thread scheduler doing what it promises; restricting certain tasks to certain cores instead of allowing them to use as many resources as the operating system allows them to. This doesn't mean that your concern is invalid, it just means that it's something I can't fix on my own.    I'll let the higher-ups figure out what to do with that. Thread scheduler just might not be a setting that Intel users should always keep enabled.    Edit: What I mean is that it's not a bug and actually expected behavior to some degree. Thread scheduler is not intended to always provide best performance, it's there as an option for those who are looking for ways to get extra performance out of their games and willing to experiment with things.
For Linux, one way of checking the availability of HT is to parse `/proc/cpuinfo`.

Yes, but It's such a hassle for me to do on windows and I'm worried that there'll be some distro incompatibility or whatever that'll trip me up. My plan is to provide a half-assed solution and hope that some linux guy gets offended by that and finishes the job for me.    And as I said before the impact of this thread scheduler is very likely going to be even less significant on linux side due to better scheduling on kernel side.

I added some code for using a Rocksmith USB cable with this PR. That cable acts as a mono microphone. The code is enough to get the game to recognize an attached guitar and to process input from it. Not sure if it entirely correct though since the game has a lot of audio output stutter (disabling framelimit and using Null renderer helps a bit).    There is one big hack in cellMicOpenEx, which Rocksmith 2014 calls with rawChannel=4. This value is ignored and hard set to 1 for mono input. Not sure what to make of this, maybe it is more like maxChannels in cellMicOpenRaw?    Changes are here: https://github.com/jjsat/rpcs3/commit/70119abc4689270ecc86d6a85aa5da3c0f52fa1b

Did a bit of spring cleaning, tested on linux, added rocksmith support as suggested by @jjsat .  Biggest surprise is that it seems to now work perfectly with Karaoke Revolution which I couldn't figure the issues with. Apparently the issues were not with my cellMic implementation so I'm removing the [WIP].

What do you mean by fixing a race condition?  In fact, you are introducing a one, because external write still can be forgotten in a process, but I doubt it's even necessary.

I mean, LR event is most commonly used to manage "sleep schedule" for spus.  kind of like a conditional variable when getllar + read even stat is used as cond_wait, and a write to the lock line is used as cond_signal. So in my view, fixing the event signaling is fixing a race condition.
I have fixed this issue, atleast for getllar. (by moving reservation lost check after reservation acquire)

just occasionally I played with highlighted fixes [some another amazing and kind guy built binaries with them and shared for those like me, who still learning how to contribute\build\apply_changes]    and I want to say thanks and share my results - their was already mentioned Tekken 6, and as for BLUS30359 - it's running amazingly, stable and faster then nightly builds [fullsspeed everywhere except very rare moments of bad_opponent_customization + camera moved to a place where in background too much moving objects]. With all of the GPU Scaling, LLVM, 6 SPU threads, Mega size, SPU cache, fullscreen, 165Hz refresh rate [CRT], none framelimiter and "realtime" rpcs3 process priority [win7]    as of Tekken Tag Tournament 2 - with these fixes it's absolute stable fullspeed [on nightly builds there were slowdowns in rare cases of opponent customizations+selected stage].    Soulcalibur V went from 17-20fps with no_color_buffers to 29-34 with color-buffers. [on nightly build it was also a matter of luck to get into training mode. And with these fixes I master in practice mode and went through Arcade mode around ~10 times with no crash or freeze at all]  Soulcalibur IV is working too, and it's slightly smoother then Soulcalibur V with stage from Star Wars in Arcade mode showing almost 60 fps on any character.    Outrun 2006 is much smoother in heavy places too [with fire rings in forest for example]. Now it finally produces results smoother then pcsx2 [on the same hardware]    Dead or Alive 5 LR at first launched with freeze on character thumbnails [same as nighlty builds], and with second and next launches it was stable and just faster then nightly builds. With settings set to fight only on Dojo stage - speed is even higher then 100% [and I think it can be limited to desired speed through drivers limiter. Will try this only after some time\days]    Virtua Figher 5 FS is working good and probably consuming less energy by this fix [on nightly builds it worked already flawlessly]

@Aurez it's because of "desktop composition" in "system properties". It's a some kind of desktop windows acceleration [as far as I know]. [cemu performance is hardly depends on it too for an example]
@Jhonny-2005 you can disable it in the config.yml Search for tsx.

@Jhonny-2005 Theres a critical point in loading in Twisted Metal where you see fps freeze for some time due to heavy use of transactions, even in master.  The PR added a conditional lock optimization bearing in mind that games would not use this lock regularly.  The extensive use of the lock in this game made the heavy transactions use even slower which is why you are seeing the semaphore timeouts.  I've succeeded to reproduce this "crash" in master with TSX enabled + Accurate GETLLAR + PUTLLUC settings to make transactions slow enough.  Its not a regression in usual terms.

First commit has some very different changes mixed in.  "Fix SPU LR event race conditions"  I'd suggest to stop using the term "race condition" at all, it's misleading without detailed explanation of the actual race which I haven't seen.
I forgot to say that I think that the test itself lacks a counterexample, i.e. where the 0x400 flag is set on PS3, not on the emulator.

It IS a race condition fix, not becuase there was a race condition in the event setting, but rather a race condition in applications from the nature of the usage of this event.  LR event is also used in applications to wake up SPUs from sleep (stalling on read event stat), so if the event was set redundently, SPUs will wake up instantly instead of correctly waiting for a signal to be received, leading to race conditions to take over.  example of such race condition this fixes : https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/5449#issuecomment-449786310
I know how polling on LR event is used. And it was working correctly.
If it bothers you I can just change it to "Fix SPU LR event setting in atomic commands".

>   >   > It IS a race condition fix, not becuase there was a race condition in the event setting, but rather a race condition in applications from the nature of the usage of this event.  > LR event is also used in applications to wake up SPUs from sleep (stalling on read event stat), so if the event was set redundently, SPUs will wake up instantly instead of correctly waiting for a signal to be received, leading to race conditions to take over.  > example of such race condition this fixes : [#5449 (comment)](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/5449#issuecomment-449786310)    Like I said in that issue, this PR completely fixes the problem. And now, retesting again your PR with the latest commits, the problem with the dualshock is fixed. So, the race condition is entirely fixed and the game runs as it should. Sorry for no pointing it before. Updating.

@Nekotekina ok I have update the testcase to also include your request. To achieve this I've looped getllar on the same addr until the value of the data changed from the original, then checked the status of the events. even though the event was triggered on both the emulator and realhw, the cause is different: after detecting a data change im using getllar with a different address to lose previous reservation. so on realhw, the event is triggered by an external write, on the pr its triggered by "last even check" and on master its triggered by the execution of getllar with a different address from the current reservation.

Did more tests with Pure and https://github.com/kd-11/rpcs3/commit/243236309ca7ca70b1c0c058418d9c5894c713cb, found out to minimize revert is needed to replace RSXThread.cpp line 1047  depth_buffer_unused = !depth_test_enabled && !depth_write_enabled && !stencil_test_enabled;  with:  depth_buffer_unused = !depth_test_enabled && !stencil_test_enabled &&  				!(context & rsx::framebuffer_creation_context::context_clear_depth) &&  				layout.target != rsx::surface_target::none;

Pretty sure the naughty dog engine needs WCB. Any results that are fixed with WCB are technically correct; the random nature with WCB off is because of random data in uninitialized memory. On master, we intentionally corrupt the unprotected region with a pattern which likely hid the issue before. Unfortunately not all games appreciate this intentional corruption as it often results in what is nonsensical data to the application logic.

Crashing at high scaling is caused by exhaustion of special image memory pool, I assumed we wouldn't need allocation of intermediary buffers larger than 4k x 4k but looks like we need more. Hope you have the VRAM for it :p
I have removed the VRAM restrictions and also added in some fixes I had lying around on my DeS branch that were directly related to this PR.

Vulkan API call failed with unrecoverable error: Device lost (Driver crashed with unspecified error or stopped responding and recovered) (VK_ERROR_DEVICE_LOST)  (in file c:\projects\rpcs3\rpcs3\emu\rsx\vk\vkhelpers.h:1269)  ```  RRC if it help simulation crash for u[NHL 16.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/2705264/NHL.16.zip)   e: tho it has some high VRAM requirement in rrc 6GB VRAM isnt enough to open  ____  OGL okish on master and pr    +new probably harmless error in PR in part of the menu  ```  E {RSX [0x02ac528]} RSX: Framebuffer setup error: Color target failed pitch check, Pitch=[2560, 64, 64, 64] + 2560, target=1, context=0  E {RSX [0x02ac6ac]} RSX: Framebuffer setup error: Color target failed pitch check, Pitch=[2560, 64, 64, 64] + 2560, target=1, context=3  ```

Can't use the RRC as it dies with either DEVICE_LOST or vram exhaustion, but both crashes are caused by memory exhaustion. I'm not sure its worth considering as a blocker if 200% scaling is working fine. Can you check the memory usage with OGL? (both dedicated and shared if possible)

Further inspection shows most of the resources are in the discard queue, which means the game is constantly changing out the textures in one frame and in terms of frame scope the requirement ends up being huge. The kind of work required for on-demand and safe garbage collection is not yet implemented so 200% will have to suffice for now.

This partition is always wiped clean when you boot a new game on a ps3. Better to just clean everything inside it on boot or something.

Hmm, that'd simplify the code a lot. Is anyone against clearing the cache on every boot? I was worried that it'd cause some games to write stuff there on every boot and thus drain write cycle unneccessarily.

Yes, very much so. Some games (like DeS) can take minutes to boot without a cache, but less than 5 seconds with one available. Maybe users with the games on an SSD aren't affected as much but it can be very measurable. If the cache size is done per-game, you can lower the storage significantly - even 256M is enough imo.
Yes, I think ill head for something like that instead (and there's functionality for checking basic information about file or folder). I'll think more about it when I have time later this week.

* Moved logic to System.cpp.  * Switched all instances of disc to disk.  * New deletion logic removes oldest folders based on their modification date (last time files were created/deleted/renamed/moved) and removes files until only 80% of the limiter is remaining (to avoid running the deletion on every startup if a game adds couple of bytes to folder whilst still keeping some files intact).  * Changed the default size to 3GB, which is still more than what PS3 provides.  * Did the requested UI changes.    Edit: If someone wants to clear the cache on every boot then that's possible by setting the size to 0.
you can still add bigger single step and page step values to the slider if you want.  This is doable in the Qt Designer.
I set page step to 512 units. Single step can stay at 1 so that people who want to be punctual can pick an exact value.

My current plan is to iterate through the `dev_hdd1/cache` folder, mapping out the last modification date and size of each top level folder (or file). Once that's complete I sort them by modification date and start deleting oldest folders untill the cache shrinks down to 80% of the cap.    How's that sound? The APis don't provide sizes and modification information on folders, so I'd have to recursively iterate through them to find everything, but hopefully that isn't dreadfully slow. I'll probably change the default size to 3 GB as well, it should mean that there's less to delete each time it's triggered.

Pushed experimental commit.

Quick question: When implementing `popcnt16`, why not optimize it with the `POPCNT` instruction for x86? E.g. `u8 better_popcnt16(u16 arg) { return (u8) __builtin_popcount( (u32) arg); }` compiles to just     ```asm  better_popcnt16(unsigned short):          popcnt  ax, di          movzx   eax, ax          ret  ```  with GCC + `-O3 -march=skylake`.

> Quick question: When implementing `popcnt16`, why not optimize it with the `POPCNT` instruction for x86? E.g. `u8 better_popcnt16(u16 arg) { return (u8) __builtin_popcount( (u32) arg); }` compiles to just  >   > ```assembly  > better_popcnt16(unsigned short):  >         popcnt  ax, di  >         movzx   eax, ax  >         ret  > ```  >   > with GCC + `-O3 -march=skylake`.    We support machines which don't have this instruction

`std::bitset::count` (https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/bitset/count) generates a `popcnt` instruction if the cpu supports it. Unfortunately, if it is not the case, GCC does a call to `__popcountdi2` whereas Clang seems to do a good job.

Right, in fact there is one more issue. I wanted to address it in the beginning, but unfortunately failed to implement. I believe MoltenVK, despite not working as of now, is no less mature than gfx portability at the very least, and wanted to support them both.    My original idea is to weak link (`-weak_library`) to either but not include the file. Later on I dynamically loaded (`dlopen`) one of the libraries to solve the symbols. This works just fine in flat namespace mode (all symbols belong to global namespace), but at present Apple uses two-level namespace (each symbol belongs to some library namespace), which obviosly fails. I tried doing the binding myself, yet it did not work properly (I could start rpcs3 but it would crash later on null pointer exec). I believe this solution may be fixed to work, yet it remains very hacky and not reliable.    For this reason, the way to select the Vulkan implementation is fairly open. We could always patch/symlink the vulkan library within rpcs3.app itself, but it will break codesigning if it is considered.

Can I get a review on this? seems like a forgotten pr @Nekotekina   tl;dr the game was overwriting its list elements in a GET list command in the first element, on a real ps3 it works since mfc has already fetched a good amount of list elements in one round before tranfers begun.  And it wont reduce perf since we already copy list elements to temp buffer from LS.
Copying potentially huge list will always cause the overhead with memcpy. It's also unrealistic that PS3 is able to fetch the huge list. I'd expect something rather small, like aligned 16-byte reads.

I've written a testcase specifically for that - https://github.com/elad335/myps3tests/tree/master/spu_tests/Max%20list%20elements%20prefetch%20count  I've executed a GET list where the first element transfers 128 bytes from a "bad" elements list pointing to nulptrs from vm to the list elements itself, other elements in the OG list were filled with empty transfers.  The highest list cmd size this testcase would go is 0x30 bytes (6 elements) without crashing.
That seems more realistic. This amount should fit into registers instead of memcpying it.
> This amount should fit into registers instead of memcpying it.    What do you mean?

Its pending for review.

If you are able to reproduce consistently the verification error, attach full log file. The 'log spam' is both important and harmless, indicates caution due to faulting unexpectedly, a situation for which there is no easy solution. It can be downgraded to trace to avoid annoying end users but may make it harder to debug any regressions.

UPLOAD_URL is supposed to be secret.

Travis CI will mask the UPLOAD_URL if it finds it in the log, so UPLOAD_URL will remain secret. This is just so if I'm uploading to, for example, 0x0.st, it will print the location I can download the file from.

Yeah you're right, for some reason the application crashes if focus switches from trophy window even for one second. I'll take a look at this tomorrow and see if I can figure out what's causing it, but I fear I might've taken too big of a task here. I've done some multithreading work in the past but Qt seems more confusing in that regard than other frontend frameworks.    I've already spotted some other potential trouble spots, I'll return in a day or two to report how far my research got me. Maybe I'll try subclassing QThread and using signals & slots more, see if that makes Qt happier.

Had to spend some time figuring out various quirks but I think I managed to get a working implementation together. All UI-related functionality (aside from thread state) is now handled with signals and slots, which should fix the crashes. I coudn't trigger any on my system at least.

Diablo 3 Reaper of Souls Ultimate Evil Edition . Sound has gone!
I don't understand the idea of this.  Most games comes with their own audio volume settings, that stored in save settings.

@isshininu I've seen some users request this option as they want to reduce game sounds without having to fiddle with the cubersome volume mixer in Windows. Having to set the volume level game-by-game is a tedious process. And there could be a rare title out there with no support for volume adjustments as well, not to mention games that don't let you fiddle with settings before an introduction movie or something similar.
The volume should be applied on cellAudio.cpp side, this way it doesn't rely on audio API.  Also the max limit can be bigger than 100, it's useful in some cases where the audio is too quiet.

With Pulseaudio you should be able to manipulate RPCS3's 'Application Specific Volume' - then you'd just leave the mixing to the PulseAudio Daemon.    The volume setting I'm talking about is exposed in KDE like this:  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/881518/47250739-80a0cd80-d459-11e8-813f-bb78cb072a38.png)    Just be mindful with manipulating it haphazardly if pusleaudio's `flat-volumes` setting is on.

@Nekotekina My idea with this was to just modify the audio output and leave the whole emulation side untouched. But I'll look into your proposal. Setting volume beyond 100% can cause distortion or reduction in quality, but I guess that's up for user to decide.    @Hirato Yes, the actual volume changes woudn't be too hard to implement. The problem is that RPCS3 uses a simplified version of the PulseAudio API that has just enough functionality to play audio and pretty much nothing else. Getting any additional features to work would require rewriting the whole PulseAudio support as there doesn't seem to be any "bridges" between simple and compicated APIs.

Alirght, I switched to manipulating the port levels directly. I still prefer my eariler idea, but if neko wishes this implementation then I'll comply. Now it does not require any support from the audio backends at least. I tried modifying the three `cellAudioAddData` functions but games seem to be able to bypass these.
I'd prefer to add my own PR for hacktoberfest

Tests are messy TBH, and don't seem to utilize sys_ppu_thread_get_stack_information to get more readable information.

The syscall provides initial stack *address* of the allocation, im looking for the current *offset* from the allcation end, which can only be pulled directly from the register itself. (even though the stack gap fix could still be figured out using the syscall only)
Offset you talk about is (stack addr + stack size - stack value), it's computed from 3 variables only 1 of them you print.

@kd-11 i'm experiencing slowdowns, even to a complete crawl (2fps) with some of the games i tested.  for example, risen 3 and rdr, when using opengl. i have nvidia btw, maybe it has to do with your workaround?
Yea, the degraded performance is due to another issue where glCheckFramebuffer is returning success even when the attachments are removed via glDeleteTextures. A proper fix is incoming.

The performance regression should be fixed now. Turns out the driver is reusing texture handles and CheckFramebuffer is not actually checking to see if the handle is the same one used when attaching. Switched to manually tracking usage and attachment refs and the problem is now gone.

Thank you @MSuih, I have also confirmed your findings. That helped figure out why there were performance gains; it was because zcull testing was illegally disabled.  @scribam   WRT the changes in check_zcull_status.  Picture the following:  1. The game changes the current depth buffer to some memory that is linked to the ZCULL unit. Zcull statistics are not enabled so no testing is expected. Your optimization aborts early and no ZCULL usage takes place.  2. The game enables Zcull testing. There is no framebuffer swapped however, so the set_active call now fails since zcull_surface_active was never updated and remains forever false.    EDIT: It is common for a game to enable and disable occlusion reports several times while rendering to the same framebuffer, even when it is bound to ZCULL ram. In fact, the framebuffer_swap path is very rarely taken in the context of a frame; usually about a dozen times at most for the highest end AAA games. Some rare cases can go above that but not by much since changing ROP target is quite expensive on GPU hardware (it messes with their memory controller caches)

I have fixed three(!) more causes of the VirtualProtect errors. Two of these were actually bugs in master that could cause softlocks/hangs/crashes but one of my changes made them fail immediately (one particular game that showed a lot of these issues was GoW3). Note that the current fix is somewhat experimental, so I would appreciate if people could test it a bit on GoW3 (and other games).  (especially @elhaya since you saw all the juicy `VirtualProtect` failures so far).    One of these fixes (a stupid typo in a very important function) seems to have fixed the THPS HD deadlock reported above as well. Please retest.    I did not manage to reproduce the `Assertion failed: !region.is_locked() && region.is_dirty()` assertion in TLOU. It is likely fixing that typo has also fixed this, but please retest and let me know. Otherwise I'll try again tomorrow.    -----------------------------    For a quick and dirty explanation of what was causing the GoW3 VirtualProtect failures, and likely some of the deadlocks experienced in that game on master, I'm going to quote my explanation on Discord:      > basically, there was a flushable section that spanned multiple cell pages (i.e. 0x3500'0000 to 0x37f00'0000)  > the game then decides to unmap one single cell block in the middle of that range (e.g. 0x3550'0000 through 0x355F'FFFF)  > the section is now invalid, obviously  > let's imagine the section was recently being used  > and nothing triggered a read/write to its address space between the last use and the unmap  > it is a flushable, so is locked no-access  > once someone faults, the violation handler unlocks and flushes  > (note: the only unusual thing the game does is the large section and the unmap in the middle)  > when the game unmaps, it triggers the notify_memory_unmapped callback on the RSX thread  > once the notify_memory_unmapped callback triggers  > the RSX saw the section as being in the unmapped range  > and discarded it  > it basically threw it away, thinking there's no sense in keeping it around so it is in unmapped memory  > HOWEVER large parts of it were locked no-access in memory that did NOT get unmapped  > meaning we just left the whole address space from e.g. 0x3500'0000 through 0x354F'FFFF locked NA without any valid section information structure to keep track of that  > anytime a game tries to access that address space, it will enter the RSX violation handler  > then sees that there's no section in this address space, but it has been cached in the past  > replies "This was a region of memory that we used to handle, but it's empty now (even though we didn't do anything since nothing matched)"  > the violation handler returns to the game  > the game retries the same access  > violation handler fires again  > ...  > = softlock
I can confirm that the issue with THPS HD has been resolved.

That would be very helpful.    @kd-11   > What happens when the application requests a format to draw into that is not supported? You will end up with a null render pass handle.    Yes, if a render pass is not possible on the Vulkan driver, then RPCS3 will need to crash gracefully on an attempt to use such a pass. This is better than crashing at initialization without knowing if the pass is going to be ever needed in the first place.    > Which are these formats missing from metal/gfxrs?    Unfortunately, Metal on MacOS (specifically, there is no such restriction on iOS/tvOS) [doesn't support](https://developer.apple.com/metal/Metal-Feature-Set-Tables.pdf) packed 16bit color formats, such as R5G6B5 or A1R5G5B5.    > At least throw when use of unsupported formats is attempted and mention that its because of driver incompatibility. @scribam they do seem to have a rebase option button, but the project disallows merging PRs that aren't up to date. I would highly recommend switching this requirement off:  ![screenshot from 2018-09-07 14-35-04](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/107301/45236947-5fba5980-b2ab-11e8-91f2-f9bc38d0d2ea.png)    That would streamline review/landing process quite a bit. Thus, reviewer just says "bors r+" and they do all the testing on CI, rebasing and landing tasks automatically. Hooking it up is really easy, just requires admin permissions on the project.

@kd-11 thanks for the review! comments are addressed now.  Also renamed the variable to just `bgra8_linear` since the other ones also check for blit support and the don't reflect that with `_blit` suffix.
Its ok now. Its quite strange to have a GPU with the BGRA8 format not usable as a blit source, I wonder how many other formats cannot be easily copied to the backbuffer via blitting.

@kd-11   *Copying* is fine, it's the blitting that's not so easy. Blitting is different in that it [requires a graphics queue](https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.1-extensions/man/html/vkCmdBlitImage.html), and can be implemented under the hood as a graphics operation.    Also, it's not BGRA8 that is problematic but the fact of placing it in HOST_VISIBLE memory (with linear tiling). Vulkan baseline requirements for HOST_VISIBLE images are super low, e.g. only 2D with a few formats, and they aren't required to support any graphics operations. Basically, they are glorified staging buffers, and that's how Metal portability backend implements them. Hence, they can only be used in transfers.

> Also, it's not BGRA8 that is problematic but the fact of placing it in HOST_VISIBLE memory.    Makes sense, otherwise it would have been strange as drivers often just implement blitting with a full-quad pass which would have made the user-side implementation of the same redundant. Thanks for that clearing up.

You can replace  ```  const GLenum index_type = std::get<0>(upload_info.index_info.value());  ```  by  ```  const GLenum index_type = std::get<0>(*upload_info.index_info);  ```  It should do the trick on MacOS. Source: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44217316/how-do-i-use-stdoptional-in-c

Splitting VS projects didn't do any significant service. Rather the opposite. In particular, it disallowed effective use of the precompiled header - we either had to have several precompiled headers for each project, or had to disable them. Currently only emucore.vcxproj uses a single one, as a compromise.    However, I think that removing current solution files and switching to CMake completely may be a good compromise too. In this case, enumerating all files for compilation seems much more attractive because there is only one place of change.    But creating a lot of targets creates more complexity in the same field, because now a programmer has to think a lot about said dependencies. It should be really much easier if there are only two non-3rdparty targets: emucore and rpcs3qt.

Several precompiled headers would be entirely reasonable especially if different components would be encapsulated well. Eg. it would be nice if graphics API headers wouldn't be included in any of the public headers of the RSX that are included to other components. That kind of encapsulation would also reduce compile times and need for precompiled headers.    I am also hoping that we can move to use one build system for all platforms. This pull request is first step towards that. Hopefully we get good usage experiences from this and can improve Windows + CMake development experience to same levels as with visual studio project files.    I actually added precompiled header as a separate target but now that I think of it it probably doesn't currently work correctly. Probably would need some cotire function calls to enable usage of that precompiled header in all targets.    IMHO programmer _should_ think about dependencies. Not having automatically everything available forces programmer to think about the dependencies and takes steps to avoid adding additional dependencies. Hidden dependencies make it easy to code messy code that does too many things and in wrong places.    Emucore might require some refactoring and better encapsulation of different components before splitting it to different components provides much benefit. So keeping it as a single library also has its benefits and is a good option.

Precompiled headers are big, and in practice, they almost repeated themselves. So not wanting it very much.    Many things that would be good... I just say that if adding another cpp file requires more complicated work and deep understanding of CMake targets (away from C++), it only encourages to make it even more messy by growing existing headers or translation units with new functionality which may or may not fit in there. That's the reality we have to deal with.    I currently see no benefits of multiple targets. Just some kind of logic association, which is fragile. The idea of emucore separation from rpcs3qt comes from the possibility to run it separately, without GUI.    Cleaning up the includes should be good for compilation time, but requires a lot of hard work. If C++ modules are available, they should help a lot, due to the elimination of the transitive inclusion problem.    Can you just drop VS solutions in the same PR?

Ideally adding new file to project shouldn't require anything else than writing its name to CMakeLists.txt in the same folder (if GLOB is not used). Doing anything more than that, is only required if the new source file requires additional dependencies that were not previously used in that library. In that case adding the target name of the library to target_link_libraries should be enough (difference between PUBLIC and PRIVATE link libraries probably should be explained in some "How to use CMake" doc).    I think I'll agree with you and combine emucore back to a single library. Splitting it to separate libraries can be done in another pull request later when some refactoring work has been done and it provides more benefits.    Based on discussion in Discord when I started working on this pull request, I don't think dropping VS solutions can be done yet. Many had strong opinions that they don't want their workflow to be affected especially before trying out Windows + CMake development setup. People need a transfer period for setting up their environments for CMake. So we have to keep double build system setup at least for a while for developers to test this.    Best option is probably to make another pull request which removes VS project and does some reorganization of source files. I didn't move any source files in this pull request just because I didn't want to do anything that affects vs project build. In the new pull request it would be possible to eg. move Utilities to rpcs3 folder and asmjit, Vulkan and llvm to 3rdparty folder.
- Combined separate subtargets under Emu to a single rpcs3_emu library target  - Squashed more fixup commits
I didn't mean only Emu by emucore. I meant literally all source code except rpcs3qt, including Utilities.

If emucore and rpcs3 are the same target that causes automoc to be run for all source files. Also AFAIK emucore is usable as a library (and was refactored at some point to enable that?) so it makes sense to keep emucore and rpcs3 separate targets.    Currently Utilities is still split to multiple targets even though it doesn't anymore provide benefit because building emucore requires them all. Utilities seems to contain quite unstructured mess of code (eg. JIT.cpp should probably be moved to somewhere in emucore...).  I don't really like adding source files to CMakeLists.txt that are not in subdirectories of the CMakeLists directory. It makes targets look messy in IDEs and build directories.

I didn't suggest merging emucore and rpcs3. I just want a single CMakeLists.txt for emucore, which contains all source files (and Utilities, I don't care how it "looks" right now, can refactor later) and thus can be easily edited to add or remove one, instead of having to figure each one out.

So now there are only rpcs3, rpcs3_emu and rpcs3_ui targets. All crypto, loader and utilities sources are part of rpcs3_emu target. All sources are GLOBbed so adding source files doesn't require editing CMakeLists.txt.

I didn't really get it: you split emucore in multiple parts?

Emucore is split into 7 libraries. One for each directory. rpcs3_emu target is the main emucore library which then links to rpcs3_audio, rpcs3_cell, rpcs3_cpu, rpcs3_io, rpcs3_memory and rpcs3_rsx targets.    I first also tried to split rsx to multiple libraries but that turned out to be difficult because of cyclic dependencies and end result wasn't nice...

Splitting utilities folder into good separate libraries was quite difficult because it contained so many different and completely unrelated utility classes.    I decided to split Utilities into 3 targets:  rpcs3_core_utilities:    - File, Log, Thread, StrFmt, VirtualMemory    - These are all included in the precompiled header which means that they are linked to pretty much every target    rpcs3_utilities_jit:    - JIT.cpp    - Only file that uses asmjit and llvm so I didn't want to include this to the main rpcs3_utilities target    rpcs3_utilities    - Everything else    - Also links to core_utilities with PUBLIC visibility so they are also included    Maybe even more detailed splitting could be beneficial but not without properly separating different utility libraries into separate folders. But that would require changes to MSVC project files also.
Fixed some rebasing mistakes
Enumerating source files manually is just unmanageable. Small targets also don't make any practical sense.

Enumerating source files manually is the recommended way to use CMake. CMake documentation discourages using GLOB and GLOB_RECURSE because adding source files requires always manually running CMake because CMake can't detect that reconfiguring is required because CMake scripts aren't changed. It's not like visual studio project files wouldn't require manually adding source files. But I kinda expected that this point might be raised because most of the development is done using visual studio project files which is why I didn't bother to change all libraries to list their source files explicitly.    Small targets discourage creating dependencies between unrelated components, make it possible to easily compile different components with different options and provide good structure. My personal preference would be to split it even smaller targets and add clear public interface and private interface distinction by separating them to different folders and limiting include paths so including header file of a library that is not linked to the target doesn't work. But that can't probably be reasonably done as long as msvc project files are used and it would require large scale refactoring to code also because many files do so many things and include half the project.    Small targets vs big targets is a preference thing. Emucore could be a single library, but splitting it by subfolders felt logical. Visual studio Project files split different RSX backends to separate targets.

@kd-11 why would spinning on the fence solve your deadlock? This change looks super hacky to me, it might be just hiding the actual cause of the problem.

You misunderstand, I was spinning on the wrong fence before (it was never submitted, so it was always not returning VK_SUCCESS). The function takes an optional external fence argument. I just reorganized all the code to have one fence wait function to avoid such problems in future.
@kd-11 I see that instead of `vkWaitForFences` you are now calling `vk_wait_for_fence`, which just spins in a hot loop. Where was the wrong fence used?
Check the changes in the submit function. pending is never true if an external fence is issued.
Ok, the pending flag is good. But why removing the use of `vkWaitForFences`?
>// NOTE: vkWaitForFences is slower than polling fence status at least on NV    My guess is that the change brings a slight performance improvement.
@MSuih I find this weird. Waiting on a fence should never be your performance bottleneck.

It is measurably slower when called on demand. This happens due to an unavoidable situation on page faults (think of PS3 as effectively unified memory, and the CPU can suddenly require something that only exists on the GPU).
what a telling branch name :D

For the arithmetic swizzling, this is what I had in mind:  ```glsl  vec4 make_swizzle_vec(uint remap) {    return vec4(uvec4(remap) == uvec4(2, 3, 4, 1));  }    mat4 make_swizzle_mat(uint remap_bits) {    return mat4(      make_swizzle_vec((remap_bits >> 0) & 0x7U),      make_swizzle_vec((remap_bits >> 3) & 0x7U),      make_swizzle_vec((remap_bits >> 6) & 0x7U),      make_swizzle_vec((remap_bits >> 9) & 0x7U)    );  }    void main() {    vec4 sample = texture(u_texture, uv);    // the matrix is column-major, so multiplying from the right side    vec4 remapped_sample = sample * make_swizzle_mat(u_remap_bits);  }  ```    Note: this isn't tested (other than for syntax), but should be correct. It's also fairly straightforward: no indexing or branching, which I'm not sure the GLSL compiler optimizes out nicely.

Your arithmetic path seems to choose between 4 options but there are 6 possibilites. There is no branching in the current version (greaterThan comparison maps directly onto one hardware instruction). Replacing the 4 index operations with the matrix create and multiply seems like overkill, but honestly I would have to compile+decompile them both to be sure.
Unlikely, and the log shows everything is running smoothly. Also, this PR only affects vulkan+apple, so if the issue was here OGL would run and Vulkan would crash which doesn't seem to be the case.

> By second buffer copy I meant there are 2 copies, one from CPU->buffer1 then buffer1->buffer2.    Oh, I read this as another buffer in memory. If you mean "buffer copy" in terms of operation (e.g. 2 copies), then sure, I understand. Although, CPU could be working with the HOST_VISIBLE memory directly (instead of doing "CPU->buffer1" copy), in which case there is a single copy.    Do the contents change a lot between frames?

@kd-11 FYI, our query support is almost landed, pending https://github.com/gfx-rs/portability/pull/134    > I'll push a workaround for the texel buffer incompatibility on the textures PR in a few minutes and we can see if it now works.    This is incredible! Thank you for addressing our blockers so promptly! :heart:   When implementing this, please make sure to follow the standard Vulkan logic instead of adding `#ifdef __APPLE__`: check the memory types in buffer requirements, and work around if the implementation can't support it. Alternatively, using a non-HOST_VISIBLE memory for those buffers may be good on all platforms as the only path, but this depends on how often and what parts of it need to be updated.

It would be wasteful of vram as the memory content is only guaranteed to remain intact for the immediate near future. This is largely due to design constraints where the cpu is often used to offload vertex calculations on ps3, so you end up reuploading almost the entire graphics memory every frame as it has changed.

@kd-11  > It would be wasteful of vram    I don't think it would have any impact on VRAM. With the old approach, you were using `HOST_COHERENT & HOST_VISIBLE` memory, and since Vulkan spec requires the implementation to return a memory type with more properties first, you were likely getting `DEVICE_LOCAL` there as well. So the old approach is already allocating VRAM for those buffers, very likely.    In the new approach, you'd have the same `DEVICE_LOCAL` buffers, just not visible to the host, plus some scratch space (even if the size of the buffer) that is `HOST_VISIBLE` but not `DEVICE_LOCAL`, so it's allocated from RAM and not VRAM.    > cpu is often used to offload vertex calculations on ps3    So some applications tend to update the vertex data every frame from CPU, and some (minority?) do not?

>In the new approach, you'd have the same DEVICE_LOCAL buffers, just not visible to the host, plus some scratch space (even if the size of the buffer) that is HOST_VISIBLE but not DEVICE_LOCAL, so it's allocated from RAM and not VRAM.    This is what I meant by wasteful (2x allocation, which is what I have right now for apple). Also I would like to avoid the extra copy operation if possible as it is not free.    > So some applications tend to update the vertex data every frame from CPU, and some (minority?) do not?    With the exception of some tutorial samples, this is pretty much guaranteed behaviour. There are measures to reduce the bandwidth pressure, but such is the limitation of trying to emulate a system with virtually unified memory. Vertex transform step is done primarily on the Cell SPEs to improve performance in most cases.
I have added the required workarounds to support non-visible memory heaps, so the assertion should be resolved.

I forgot to mention - the part that is seemingly not applying is the matrix multiplication at the end of the vertex shader. Basically goes something like:  ```  gl_Position = reg0;  ... bunch of other code...  gl_Position = gl_Position * scale_offset_matrix;  ..bunch of other code..  gl_Position = apply_clip_transform(gl_Position);  ```  The non-inline nature is largely since the code generator is shared with other languages such as HLSL. I'm wondering if for some reason on gfx-rs (and maybe MVK?) the `gl_Position = gl_Position * mat` is not working due to the "gl_Position" variable mapping to a write-only variable?

@kd-11 I tried your branch with my latest changes in queries and got stuck in the next problem: RPCS3 [tries to create](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/f3d3a1a4a5d7d32f4fbcf2057d7272ea40beeb2b/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKGSRender.cpp#L591) a 384MB buffer that has `VK_BUFFER_USAGE_UNIFORM_TEXEL_BUFFER_BIT` in the CPU-visible memory. We don't support this (rightfully) and RPCS3 ends up triggering an exception. Do you really need to keep it CPU-visible?

@kvark For now, yes. Working around this would involve a separate upload buffer and a second buffer copy. As far as I could see the host-visible nature does not degrade performance when used for upload in this fashion so it was optimized around that. How much can you allocate once for host access on metal? Those are just storage heaps, you can make them smaller for testing, with possible out-of-memory situations that will degrade performance. You can set to 128M for example and simple applications will not crash.

Why would a second buffer copy be needed?    The Metal limitation here is not the size (sorry, I should have clarified that). We don't support texel buffer views from shared memory.    > On Aug 23, 2018, at 08:47, kd-11 <notifications@github.com> wrote:  >   > @kvark For now, yes. Working around this would involve a separate upload buffer and a second buffer copy. As far as I could see the host-visible nature does not degrade performance when used for upload in this fashion so it was optimized around that. How much can you allocate once for host access on metal? Those are just storage heaps, you can make them smaller for testing, with possible out-of-memory situations that will degrade performance. You can set to 128M for example and simple applications will not crash.  >   > —  > You are receiving this because you were mentioned.  > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

> Why would a second buffer copy be needed?    How else do we transfer a large bytestream (even 384M is not large enough sometimes) for random access in the vertex shader? Isn't the only other solution to have an upload buffer and then copy to the actual stream using a GPU-side transfer? By second buffer copy I meant there are 2 copies, one from CPU->buffer1 then buffer1->buffer2.
I'll push a workaround for the texel buffer incompatibility on the textures PR in a few minutes and we can see if it now works. :crossed_fingers:

I've restored the old ordering of the variable declarations in `get_intersecting_set` at @kd-11's request.

I have added a third fix to this PR. After a lot more time reviewing the texture cache code and pestering @kd-11 with many questions (thank you for your help!) I found a third bug:    - `invalidate_range_impl_base` does not mark some textures that will only be  unprotected as dirty when doing a deferred flush, since that is done by  `flush_all`. However, if there are no sections to flush, the deferred flush will  use the same code path as non-deferred flushes for unprotecting textures  and forget to mark them as dirty.    With this fix I believe I have finally tracked down the bug causing the P5 texture swaps (see #4298), but further testing is needed.

I have updated #4298 with some test results for this PR.    **tl;dr:** P5 texture swap bug is fixed during normal gameplay, but not inside the Velvet Room. I suspect there is a fourth bug somewhere that only triggers in there.
Are there any comments on this or should I merge?

What about display backgound when LLVM caches is compiling?  Suggestion about darkening strength - make it configurable: static or dynamic (depends of compilation progress).

Disk games with a patch installed will have the boot directory be the patch directory, but they don't necessarily have a pic1.png there. So the search path for the graphics should ideally include the disc directory to avoid falling back to icon0.png.

I'm merging this as is for now, improvements are easy to add for any interested developers. The blur algorithm here is very weak, can be replaced with a stronger filter later. Options are for now config file only for now. Defaults = enabled:true, darkening strength:30%, blur strength: 0%

I'm curious, and so people are aware, should we expect similar issues to those that Dolphin saw when they tried asynchronous shaders? Or do these kinds of issues not occur in RPCS3?    I'll quote their [Ubershaders blog post](https://dolphin-emu.org/blog/2017/07/30/ubershaders/):    > In the end, it just came down to the fact that the people who could have implemented [asynchronous shaders] along with other core developers were against it as a solution. They saw it as nothing more than a hack that would cause a lot of false positives on the issue tracker and cause bigger issues down the road. Those worries were proven somewhat valid when you realize that some games need objects to be rendered on the frame they expect it to be. In this case, the Mii heads are only rendered once to the Embedded Framebuffer. If the EFB copy is missing because of Async Shader Compilation, the Mii heads will not show up for the remainder of the game or until they're regenerated.

In all games I tested (P5, Project Diva, Drakengard 3, NieR Replikant, Infamous), it works just as note2 says, massive pop-ups everywhere, and have not met with any problems. It lags when few first shaders are loading, after that it plays while loading more and more, and at the end works as normal. No drops or increase in performance, no dropping OOB. That's why I'm not sure if it's a needed thing at all...

Try with this PR vs Master with Asura's Wrath or Uncharted, the difference is huge. Asura's Wrath doesn't perform well on master unless you spend atleast a few hours compiling shaders. With this PR the amount of shaders that compile is significantly lower the game now performs well with a clean cache. Saying that it's not needed is just wrong.
You can still use synchronous shaders. The option already exists and will be added to the GUI.

@Patkos96 Async is working but your CPU cannot handle the extra work `Intel(R) Core(TM) i5 CPU 760 @ 2.80GHz   4 Threads`. Even modern i5s will freeze a little when using vulkan as compiling from ps3->glsl->spirv->driver is quite a lot of work. Add the lower CPU speed and you might be better disabling it.

Freezing window bugs are caused by https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/4878 and have nothing to do with rsx code. This is why its important to test all builds not just rsx ones when checking regressions.

@spyropt that is normal. The game only renders the faces once so once they are skipped they never show up. If you restart the game the shader will have been saved to cache and faces will be ok. Or disable async to force synchronous compilation making sure the writes are always present. Or load a save then return to menu,  etc. Anyrhing that triggers the faces to update will show correctly after the first time.

@Nekotekina Seems that AppVeyor failed at build merge.  https://ci.appveyor.com/project/rpcs3/rpcs3/build/9691

At first glance, the removal of random whitespace is a little noisy. Also, x64 cpus are required by rpcs3. So there are a lot of checks that basically don't need to happen or that could be simplified. Not a major issue, but something to keep in mind. Only the acceleration hardware needs to be detected.
Removed the `POLARSSL_HAVE_X86_64` preprocessor checks and the various whitespace changes in the latest patchset.
No stability problems or any regression in the games I tested (NieR Replikant, P5, Infamous, Drakengard 3).

I feel deja-vu. On the one hand, it could be merged. But the implementation is not the most efficient because it doesn't handle multiple blocks at time. CTR mode used in PKG installer can benefit a lot from this. Could think about switching to OpenSSL instead.
I'll look into using OpenSSL (as a replacement for aes.c/aes.h).
Can you please mark it [WIP] if you are going to keep commiting

I modified the `aescbc128_decrypt`/`aescbc128_encrypt`/`aesecb128_encrypt` wrapper functions in rpcs3/Crypto/utils.cpp to use OpenSSL's EVP interface (needed for HW acceleration, the lower-level AES interface is only a software implementation): https://github.com/al3xtjames/rpcs3/commit/178bee579ea48c8f2dc46e5810f03875532b6913    Will work on replacing other uses of the `aes_crypt_*` functions in rpcs3/Crypto.

There arent any real 'unknown commands' that are false alarms left except a handful that rpcs3 handles without issue. Usually triggered by infinite loop in shaders. Not sure what to do about those since the games are intentionally doing this and most of the time there is extra runtime information to consider. They can be easily detected though; maybe a recursion watcher can be added to abort if the program loops over one condition more than a set number of tries.

I was not sure whether this is an issue with my system, so I hadn't posted about it before: Since updating to Windows 10 1803 I had a performance drop with Vulkan. It generally showed lower FPS than OpenGL and was _feeling_ very slow. Commit d63500c brings the old performance level back (e.g. Deus Ex Human Revolution now stays at a solid 30 fps on the menu again, while before it would vary between 17 and 25.)    Radeon R9 380, driver version 18.6.1.    Just mentioning this to note that the change also affects the Windows driver.

Wipeout HD still requires WCB for correct brightness on this PR, is it only cases where you also need CPU blit that you're expecting changes? Somewhere along the line on master something changed and the main menu is no longer really slow with WCB however so its no issue to keep it on on this game anymore.

WCB is not going away for games that actually use it for brightness control. Thats just how they are designed and explains why some tests will have white output without the option. Technically speaking a permanent form of WCB is always enabled on blit resources which is why some games can get away with that setting set to off.  I'm more interested in scenarios where cpu blit + WCB (mandatory, they have to go together), gives different results vs cpu blit disabled. Also, test what happens with OGL as a different and more correct solution is implemented there.

The way GPU Texture Scaling works on the back-end has changed a lot since last year, even with it disabled operations that heavily impacted performance are still done on the GPU while the operations done on the CPU barely impact performance.     kd-11 told me he plans on removing it at some stage anyway, I think having it default to disabled would be great as new users wont run into any of the issues it causes and performance is largely the same anyway.

Well, if youre updating build integration for example, have it all in one place. You can mark it as WIP while you add more parts to it. Merging will happen one PR at a time, likely with some time in between (you have to start a new build after every merge as the PRs become outdated after each merging). As for review, things like build integration aren't too critical as they do not actually change emulator functionality. For emulation changes, provide ps3 tests proving the commits are correct and it can get merged in minutes.

Shouldn't it be only triggered on new RPCS3 release (i.e. new tag in the repo)? What's the point of flooding GH releases with artifacts for every push?
The point is having a build for every merged PR like it already works now, we don't do "stable" builds on tags
@AniLeo AppVeyor artifacts aren't going away anywhere.  They'll be just deleted after 3 months. There is hardly any use for random non-release build older than 3 months.

That's exactly why we're hosting them on GitHub releases now. They **are** going away after 3 months, meaning we can't keep a build archive on AppVeyor itself anymore.    Eventually Linux builds will also be hosted this same way. We can also put up the older builds, I have a backup of them all.
As long as there is regressions older than 3 months we need builds older than 3 months.
@AniLeo they have no use after 3 months.  @isJuhn usch old regressions are easier to sport using `git bisect` and for this, the artifacts are useless.

Do you really think users are going to build the commit where the game they want to play works on? No. Let alone bisecting regressions using git.    There are other reasons why you may want an old build apart from playing regressed games. For comparisons between older and newer builds or just for the curiosity of using them are a couple.

AppVeyor made an update about their retention policy: https://www.appveyor.com/blog/2018/06/05/artifacts-retention-policy-update/  - Is this PR still needed with the now 6-month retention policy?  - The post also provides some guides to keep artifacts for a greater period of time (using S3). IMHO, this alternative is more appropriate than polluting GitHub with tons of releases.
Yes, 3 months and 6 months is the same thing, they end up deleted anyways.   No go, S3 is expensive, 90  for every uploaded TB. Citra also hosts with GitHub Releases.

Option to use a host that sponsors open-source projects such as [DigitalOcean](https://developers.digitalocean.com/opensource/) for builds distribution has been suggested. An advantage of doing so that we can easily put up all of the older build history as well.    For now though, we will start deploying to GitHub Releases, as the builds host option will take some time to setup if we choose to go with it.     The whole windows build history has been backed up, and there's a backup of all AppImages as well.
Implemented on website at https://github.com/AniLeo/rpcs3-compatibility/commit/992d6efc78b1be250814e208f24e6c69ce86051f, all builds starting this PR link to the GitHub Releases URL.

I'm getting either freezes or `Out of pool memory (VK_ERROR_OUT_OF_POOL_MEMORY_KHR)` errors with this PR in RDR. Oddly enough, debug output seems more stable, perhaps because it doesn't have a chance render as many frames. I'm not sure if they're caused by this PR or not since master has that VkFence bug, so feel free to ignore this one if it's not relevant.    The following error stood out in the log for me as it seems unique among the hundreds of spec violations. I'm not sure if it's causing the lockups but I feel like it'd be a good starting point.  >E {rsx::thread} RSX: ERROR: [DS] Code 79692390 : Object: 0xd0   Unable to allocate 2 descriptors of type VK_DESCRIPTOR_TYPE_COMBINED_IMAGE_SAMPLER from pool 0xd0. This pool only has 0 descriptors of this type remaining. The spec valid usage text states 'descriptorPool must have enough free descriptor capacity remaining to allocate the descriptor sets of the specified layouts' (https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.0/html/vkspec.html#VUID-VkDescriptorSetAllocateInfo-descriptorPool-00307)    [Full log](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/2077064/RPCS3.log.gz). This is on RX 480.

Looks like it might be a side-effect of increasing the descriptor count to support more than one input texture on overlay passes. I'll look into it later.  The spec violations are intentional, at least until someone (khronos) makes it possible to painlessly stretch stencil data.

Rendering in Mortal Kombat is greatly improved, strict rendering mode is still required. One of the frame buffers appears to be scaled in the upper left quadrant now, it looks like it might be some shadow layer. Other than that only the health bars are missing from what I can tell in normal gameplay.    This branch:  ![pr](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14915620/41080030-5ad63706-69d9-11e8-828d-746ce41d9c83.png)    Master 6901  ![master 6901](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14915620/41080042-6e290a36-69d9-11e8-8e05-12d1c107ee51.png)
@MSuih Retest.

The Out of pool memory crashes are gone, but sadly the random freezes that lock up the whole emulator weren't connected to that and do still remain. It feels like there's some kind of a deadlock going on since RSX threads keep jumping between 0 and 100% usage whenever that happens. I can't provide any useful data on it as it doesn't print any hints to log when that occurs.    But don't let it delay the half screen fixes, all other games I've tested run fine.

Status of driver support for the depth/stencil scaled blit:  - AMD (proprietary) - ok on both OGL and Vulkan  - NVIDIA - ok on both OGL and Vulkan  - RADV - ok on OGL, only depth transport implemented for vulkan  - INTEL/ANV - unknown    Due to the extra work required to properly support arbitrary pixel transfer, this PR is getting merged as is. The missing features will be implemented down the line.
