I noticed on recent master emu can hang or even crash, and in task manager it comes with 100% CPU usage, on this PR this seems to happen even more often

The problem here is fairly simple, lowering the yield threshold will allow usleep to jump to 501us for every sleep duration above it on windows, so we can lower it to say, 10 and suddenly some CPUs are happy again. This is however tricky and will hide timing problems, bringing issues like emulator freezing or unpredictable performance in some situations. I'm also not comfortable with yet another config option, we already have a mess of options right now with many reports of bad performance being the result of poor understanding of the configuration options. I'll ask for other opinions on this before deciding what to do with it.

I don't think I misunderstand the options and general configuration of RPCS3 given the thousands of hours of testing I've already done on this emulator.    I always test all possibilities with the "Spu thread" (Auto/1/2), with or without "Lower Spu thread", with or without "Spu loop detection", ASMJIT or SPU LLVM, etc.. I spend a lot of time on this every time to get an objective opinion.    Even if some options can help a little (notably disable everything related to SPU in fact) it is clear that overall performance is lower than on Master and that audio stutter much more.    The only combination that works better for me compared to the Master are the games that work with the SPU LLVM, which is very rare as you know.    Then I don't know what else to say and I have no interest in inventing problems that don't exist.

@Illynir You misunderstand, I don't mean issues listed here, I mean on the issue tracker. Obviously you know how to use most options as do most people involved in development and testing of rpcs3. But if you see all the bogus issues we always have to close all the time on github you'll understand what I mean. (see https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=label%3A%22Meta%3A+Invalid%22+)    As a workaround, I'll lower allow_yield to 10 usecs for all quads. Looks like 6 cores are actually not affected.

Yes, on Quadcore and less the pressure is huge. Regression in performance almost everywhere and SPU options (Spu loop detection, Spu thread, Lower spu thread) behave strangely and often lead to an even stronger regression instead of improving performance.    You should consider either an automatic detection of the number of threads or an option to disable it so that it is viable on weaker PCs like i5.

as of bb8a098 for P5 changing SPU threads number to Auto brought no observable FPS changes (still very low, somewhere between 5 and 15), however changing it to 1 brought FPS up to 24 in menu and lessened audio stutter (on master FPS on 1 is lower than on 2). On other spu thread counts FPS remains roughly the same as on Auto. Actually, it would be great to have a debug option to log FPS and then get some overall statistics like min/max/average. It will allow measuring overall performance gain/loss on different settings/prs/commits/system configurations. It would be even better to bind FPS logging to a button so we could start/stop it while emulation is running.
EDIT_2: As kd-11 suggested i started to iterate over different combinations of CPU options. So far: Persona 5: __Enabling Thread scheduler greatly decreases performance on any thread count;__ Spu thread number 2 still gives bests performance with Thread scheduler disabled; Enabling SPU loop detection decreases audio stutter and increases FPS ingame, but videos start to stutter a lot more (it seems the higher thread count the biggers is the performance increase, for example on 6 threads with enabled loop detection and disabled scheduler works almost as good as on 2 threads excluding periodical fps spikes but on 2 threads loop detection hardly gives any increase); Enabling lower SPU thread priority increases FPS. Looks like detecting hyperthreading is harder than expected. The performance problems are likely caused by using thread scheduler on an i5

Seems ok for me now on my Ryzen 3 1200 @ 3.9 GHz. Seems to have gone to like it was before (haven't tested all games I have), and some games might have even got a bit of a speed boost (in some parts).

Removed the broken hyperthreading detection. Its a complete shitshow (thanks intel). Names also have no real meaning on intel CPUs (some i7s are dual cores, and there are xeons in there as well) and trying to detect physical CPUs is more trouble than its worth due to intel changing cpuid bits all the time. Thread scheduler is therefore disabled for intel until we find evidence that it is still useful for weaker CPUs (only ever worked on older i3s and laptop i7s anyway).

Just a note, some newer i5 are actually 4C/8T, like the i5-8300H that I have, which is why I didn't test it with this PR.   Might have to keep that in mind if you decided to re-implement the hyperthreading detection for Intel.

Testing each build takes time, so I couldn't test 267de418 build properly.    Good news is that 319beb31 seems to be working just fine, had only two semaphore timeouts and zero texture issues in 4+ hours.
Hyperthreading detection could be implemented with `GetLogicalProcessorInformation` on Windows and parsing `/proc/cpuinfo` on Linux.
For high cpu load applications, hyper threading mostly does not improve performance.

I someone want to invest the time, you test disable some cores and hypethreading on bios level and compare results, almost all modern board supports it.    So if you have Core i7 you could test similar performance to Core i5 / Core i3.

Why this doesn't go in rsx callback, which is already called on every memory deallocation.  I doubt this is exclusively limited to mmapper.

You have a point, that any unmap/deallocation should probably always update the offset tables in gcm_sys library (I don't know if anyone checked for this, maybe @elad335 has done the tests for it). In that case we need a gcm_sys callback that then optionally invokes the rsx::thread back-end callback. The rsx::thread callback is for the rsx side of things only and does not actually interact with gcm_sys. Maybe can be provided as a util function that checks if memory is rsx mapped, then once confirmed to exist, invokes the existing on_memory_unmapped callback and updates the offset tables.

@jbeich Yes, if it is a bug it should be reported upstream so that we do not have to modify the file each time the file changes. Does malloc.h not exist on BSD? Or what is the actual problem?
It could be related to the whole 64 bit overflow thing. Thought that was patched though.

> should be reported upstream    GPUOpen isn't in `.gitmodules`. What is the correct upstream?    > Does malloc.h not exist on BSD?    Correct. See [FreeBSD](https://github.com/freebsd/freebsd/commit/2ffad81b1757554bf9413d11af0e92c93a94575b#diff-a4986d1e0374734b819a94e04f45c239), [DragonFly](https://github.com/DragonFlyBSD/DragonFlyBSD/commit/02b66c54cac986a0bf93435b8d5ae1b17521515b), [OpenBSD](https://github.com/openbsd/src/commit/d88f57029e5acaaaf028633c7fa15c5d7325c5cc) commits. DragonFly, NetBSD, OpenBSD don't have malloc extensions. FreeBSD has (e.g., `malloc_usable_size`, `mallctl*`, `*allocx`) in `<malloc_np.h>`. However, `aligned_alloc` is C11/C++17 feature, not an extension.

What about OpenGL-only systems and cards? Will the emulator load normally if Vulkan not found at system? I think the people who use OpenGL renderer-only should not care about Vulkan and its issues...    This PR works for me, though (I have Vulkan runtimes installed by nVidia driver).

First of all, I do not think psycho-A's issue was really because of vkstatic linking, unless driver loading protocol has changed again. The one benefit of linking against the dll instead of the library is that we do not need to update the precompiled library. However, this will (and I guarantee this will happen) make rpcs3 fail on systems with broken vulkan setup since vulkan-1.dll will likely not be configured correctly. Ironically the solution to this is shipping vulkan-1.dll which contains the same code as vkstatic and has the exact same pitfalls. We switched to vkstatic from vulkan-1 which is the default for this reason.  That said, I'll leave the decision up to those who deal with our #help channel as they will be responsible for diagnosing vulkan library problems with this changeset.

@Relsig thanks for the comment, I didn´t notice any regressions in my tests here, but I appreciate if you could help testing too,  :)    About the SceNp returns, you mentioned above:  This function (sceNpManagerRequestTicket2) is needed as a part of a process to acquire data from NP server.  Since the emulator actually can´t connect and finish the steps to online check the downloaded content, probably is safer to assume that the system is offline than makes it wait an event, through a callback, that will not trigger.

Actually, after thinking about it a bit more, I think it would be better to check   `if (g_psn_connection_status == SCE_NP_MANAGER_STATUS_OFFLINE)`  and in that case return `SCE_NP_ERROR_OFFLINE`  As show [here](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/master/rpcs3/Emu/Cell/Modules/sceNp.cpp#L1087)

In main(),  I didn't remove timeBeginPeriod(1) as I wasn't sure if there was other code that needs it (e.g. UI?).    So, reverting to 1 msec is not an assumption.    If you still feel its better to save the default and then restore, let me know and I can make the change.
Fair enough, I wonder if the timebegin/timeend calls are still relevant in this case. They likely are not needed anymore.

From what I've picked up about high resolution timers my understanding is that timeBeginPeriod() and timeEndPeriod() both delegate to NtSetTimerResolution with a min granularity of 1ms    Instead of 'restoring' it to 1ms you should remove your request for .5ms by switching the flag to FALSE    These are a couple of the articles I viewed when I was looking for information on high performance timers some years ago, hopefully they help.    http://mirrors.arcadecontrols.com/www.sysinternals.com/Information/HighResolutionTimers.html  ^about NtSetTimerResolution itself      http://www.windowstimestamp.com/description  ^long scholarly article on timers in Windows in general. Might be helpful when you're trying to get times from the os/etc

@kd-11 if you look at the original source I provided -> http://mirrors.arcadecontrols.com/www.sysinternals.com/Information/HighResolutionTimers.html    > Set  This is TRUE if a new timer resolution is being requested, and FALSE if the application is indicating it no longer needs a previously implemented resolution.    > ## Implementation Details  >...  >**NtSetTimerResolution** also keeps track of whether a process has set the timer resolution in its process control block, so that when a call is made with Set equal to FALSE it can verify that the caller has previously requested a new resolution. ...    While this is an independent study the details match up with other low level functions that need to be process specific which would mean false removing the request is intended.    Your confusion likely stems from the use of the word "set" and a "true"/"false" value. By providing "false" you are telling it that you do not need the time interval set anymore. Your original, almost certainly incorrect, assumption is that you're not telling it to set a value.    do a test, hereafter "power report" means run   `powercfg -energy duration 5`  and then open the file which should be put in C:/Windows/System32/energy-report.html, scroll down to the first few yellow blocks under "warnings" the first will be the default platform timer details, the second+ blocks should be any outstanding timer requests you have.    open 2+ timertools (as many as you like), set different values for each.  check the power report -> every single timertool will be listed. Click "unset timer" on one, check the power report you'll see that one is delisted. Change the value on another to 12ms, check the power report, you will notice that the value of that one changed to 12ms but is not removed.

It's safe to assume that the most of the time the emulator is running is in-game. What do you gain with all this complexity? Just call it once at startup, all problems solved. No need to restore anything, the OS will restore it anyway after you close the emu.

You don't actually have to store anything in both cases you're feeding "currentres" to ntsettimerresolution so that it can write back the current resolution in case you need it. Simply setting the Boolean to false will suffice.     NtSetTimerResolution(5000, true, &currentres) is what we want for setting it    NtSetTimerResolution(0, false, &currentres) is what you want to release it. (Note, this is not the same currentres you used before)    NtQueryTimerResolution(out int MinimumResolution, out int MaximumResolution, out int CurrentResolution) is what you want if you want to know the max res, min res, and/or current res.    It's unwise to assume the OS will handle every case of the application closing when it's easy enough to release the request ourselves.

The complexity is because there are multiple clients of NtSetTimerResolution within RPCS3, one of which we don't control.    1. In main(), rpcs3 sets it to 1 msec.  2.  Then once the QT5 logging library is loaded, QT5 library sets it to 1 msec.    If we simply set NtSetTimerResolution to 0.5 msec in main(), the QT5 library will override it.    So, NtSetTimerResolution was moved to the start of emulation.  Now the problem is how to restore the timer resolution after emulation has stopped.  We'd like to restore it as it saves power and we're being good Windows citizens.    There are two choices right now:    1. NtSetTimerResolution(m_orig_timer_resolution, true, &curr_res)       advantages - qt5 request of 1 msec is still honored.     disadvantages - the original timer resolution could be < 1 msec if another process had set it to 0.5 msec.    2. NtSetTimerResolution(0, false, &curr_res)       advantages - will correctly release the timer resolution request for the process. The timer resolution can then go back to 15 msec.    disadvantages - does not honor the QT5 1msec request.    If the QT5 request is just for logging and we really only care about logging speed during actual emulation, I'd say we go with #2.    I'll prepare the change.

If you kill RPCS3 process, the timer resolution will be restored anyway. There is no need for placebo code.  Regarding QT issue, I'd just find another place which happens after said logging initialization.

@Nekotekina it's bad practice to hold on to resources you don't need and you only need the heightened resolution while emulating.     That being said the only real side effect of set and forget is that you'll prospectively double power usage even when not emulating simply by having RPCS3 open.     If you feel like up to double power consumption is acceptable there's no real reason not to set and forget.

Sounds more like a user error to me. Just don't keep it opened when using it on such a power-sensitive device? It's not like it has any use in stopped state, it's not a browser or anything.    I'd not question the solution if it was simple and reliable. But here it's not, it looks extremely fragile, adding to the fact that some Qt library operates it too. And suddenly 1ms is acceptable for idle, when 0,5ms is not? If it's a real problem, then idle should use max value of ~15,6ms or something.

> idle should use max value of ~15,6ms or something    It will be with the latest change.    I believe it's common for PC games to manipulate the timer resolution.  When the game is paused or minimized, the timer resolution is unset.    Tweaking the timer resolution on emulation start/stop is probably sufficient for rpcs3.

You're right, if QT didn't operate it reverting would be much more reliable. Qt uses the resolution for timers. I'm not sure if any timers are in use currently but there's no reason to muck about with things that will affect possible future features especially when having RPCS3 open will already impact performance by up to ~16x simply by Qt setting the value to 1ms. Might as well make it up to 32x (double the original) and tell anyone who complains it's Microsoft's fault and not to leave RPCS3 open when they're not using it.  Set and forget it is. Ok. I'll remove the unset.

The proper way is to remove timebeginperiod completely and just explicitly set timer resolution. After reading internals documentation and playing around with the timer program sample it seems implemented in a hackish manner in the kernel itself anyway.

Tested working on two different windows machines however Neko had requested placing the NtSetTimerResolution as soon as possible after Qt makes it's call, currently it runs when you start an emulation.
I moved it to rpcs3_app::Init() after main window init.    The QTimer object is initialized in   void main_window::Init()  => CreateDockWindows();  => 	m_logFrame = new log_frame(guiSettings, m_mw);

tested, works as expected.    My only nit left is the comment saying we set it to 0.5ms when we in fact set it to the maximum supported res and a select few systems may not support sub millisec values. the code makes it obvious what's being done though and the comment will let people looking at the code know 0.5ms is the value we're hoping for so it's not worth changing IMO.    thanks for all your hard work!

>Instead of 'restoring' it to 1ms you should remove your request for .5ms by switching the flag to FALSE    That wouldn't work.  By setting the flag to false, it's declaring that the app (process) doesn't care about the timer resolution anymore.  The global timer resolution will then be set to min(all other process'es timer resolution requests).    >The proper way is to remove timebeginperiod completely and just explicitly set timer resolution.    True, but the QT5 library is also setting timeBeginPeriod to 1 msec.    Since we don't know what 3rd party libraries may require, probably the best thing to do is to save and restore the original timer resolution before the game started.    If everyone agrees, I'll make the change.
Oh, and I'll remove the rpcs3 call to timeBeginPeriod/timeEndPeriod.

Yes, timeBeginPeriod and timeEnd period don't belong anymore, they just manage calls to the hidden ntdll instructions you're implementing directly.    If the UI doesn't care about the system timer, as it honestly shouldn't, removing timeBegin/end completely is the way to go. You don't want to increase power consumption if you don't have to.    You need to make sure you're removing your request for a lower timer using  NtSetTimerResolution(5000, FALSE, &currentres)  otherwise you may permanently set the timer to 1ms, which can effectively nullify any power saving settings the computer has. My PC defaults to 15.625ms.    You can test this by opening 2 timer tools and setting/unsetting the values arbitrarily or just looking at the timertool's source which is available at http://github.com/tebjan/TimerTool    You might also consider implementing NtQueryTimerResolution and checking that 0.5ms is available before setting it because while it -should- be it may not be.    Edit: picture for more clarity    ![timerresolution](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8096354/40130840-d0f25344-58fd-11e8-920a-f028f6641234.png)  set one to 0.5 ms, the other to 0.75 ms, unset the first and you will see the current is 0.75 ms.    ![timerresolution](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8096354/40130986-3042984a-58fe-11e8-97f6-711c60240cb0.png)  unset both and the timer returns to the original value

1) Don't include sync.h, use DYNAMIC_IMPORT directly in cpp file.  2) Setting desired resolution once at startup is enough. It doesn't make much sense to use 1s initially and then switch between values.

@kd-11 it doesn't appear to matter what value you place in the timer resolution as long as you use false for set it removes your request.     in the timertool clicking "Unset Timer" button calls NtSetTimerResolution( 0, false, uint) and provably removes the requested lock    Here's the pertinent parts of the timertool's code ->    MainForm.designer.cs lines 111-121  ```  		    //   		    // UnsetTimer  		    //   		    this.UnsetTimer.FlatStyle = System.Windows.Forms.FlatStyle.Flat;  		    this.UnsetTimer.Location = new System.Drawing.Point(92, 51);  		    this.UnsetTimer.Name = "UnsetTimer";  		    this.UnsetTimer.Size = new System.Drawing.Size(77, 30);  		    this.UnsetTimer.TabIndex = 7;  		    this.UnsetTimer.Text = "Unset Timer";  		    this.UnsetTimer.UseVisualStyleBackColor = true;  		    this.UnsetTimer.Click += new System.EventHandler(this.UnsetTimerClick);  ```    MainForm.cs lines 143-146  ```  		void UnsetTimerClick(object sender, EventArgs e)  		{  			WinApiCalls.SetTimerResolution(0, false);  		}  ```    WinApiCalls.cs line 42-47   ```  		public static ulong SetTimerResolution(uint timerResolutionIn100nsUnits, bool doSet = true)  		{  			uint currentRes = 0;  			var result = NtSetTimerResolution(timerResolutionIn100nsUnits, doSet, ref currentRes);  			return currentRes;  		}  ```

@kd-11 in reference to #3792, I've just built this PR branch and can confirm that both RADV & OpenGL @ Linux (Mesa 18.0) are still freezing GPU & the whole the OS, 100% reproducible...  This ain't surprising, on RADV the **gpu_name** returns `AMD RADV POLARIS10 (LLVM 6.0.0)`, this patch fixes the Vulkan;  ```  diff --git a/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKHelpers.cpp b/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKHelpers.cpp  index 9925cab6b..5989378e0 100644  --- a/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKHelpers.cpp  +++ b/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKHelpers.cpp  @@ -212,7 +212,7 @@ namespace vk                  //One has to choose between using degenerate primitives or primitive restart to break up lists but not both                  //Polaris and newer will crash with ERROR_DEVICE_LOST                  //Older GCN will work okay most of the time but also occasionally draws garbage without reason  -               if (gpu_name.find("Radeon") != std::string::npos)  +               if (gpu_name.find("Radeon") != std::string::npos    gpu_name.find("AMD RADV") != std::string::npos)                  {                          g_drv_no_primitive_restart_flag = !g_cfg.video.vk.force_primitive_restart;                          g_drv_disable_fence_reset = true;  ```  Any clue where to fix OpenGL in a simmilar manner?

@sibradzic   1. You first have to isolate the opengl bug for mesa, afaik ogl was working fine without hard-locking the GPU. There exists a workaround for broken vertexID but that only affects proprietary drivers and that is the existing openGL workaround. There is no known primitive restart bug on mesa as of now unless you have found one? Disable primitive restart and see if it fixes the problem (the robustness extension will guarantee that the application shall not crash because of out-of-bounds error). You can find the enable in GLGSRender::end  2. Thanks for testing RADV, will add proper patch for it since adding it to "radeon" group is incorrect. Proprietary driver has a dangerous fence reset bug that needs separate workarounds.

After implementation of recompiler cache two of the 3 consisitent fatal errors regarding spuasmjit spukernel have been resolved. Now I only get 1 consistent mem access violation writing fatal errors instead of 3.    Before spu recompiler cache  `·F 0:46:11.539028 {SPU[0x2000001] Thread (CellSpursKernel1) [0x05d88]} MEM: Access violation writing location 0xffdead00  ·F 0:46:11.539597 {SPU[0x2000004] Thread (CellSpursKernel4) [0x05d88]} MEM: Access violation writing location 0xffdead00  ·F 0:46:11.539609 {SPU[0x2000003] Thread (CellSpursKernel3) [0x05d88]} MEM: Access violation writing location 0xffdead00`    After spu recompiler cache implementation  `·F 0:12:56.849387 {SPU[0x2000001] Thread (CellSpursKernel1) [0x05e40]} MEM: Access violation writing location 0xffdead00`    Params  D3  SPUASMJIT Recompiler  PPU LLVM Recompiler  Vulkan    Mem access violation are well known to the devs that this means anything and could not be pinpointed exactly the cause, but the implementation of spu cache and disappearance of the 2 spu fatal errors means the devs was close to resolving this issues.

Hi    can you please rebase?

@AniLeo By default, Linux (which includes Travis) does not use the Vulkan submodule to build RPCS3. We only rely on the distribution package. Therefore, it is not mandatory to update Travis when we update the Vulkan submodule. As a proof, I removed the Vulkan submodule checkout and Travis will be able to build without issues. The AppImage generated will also have the Vulkan renderer available.    Still, we can, if we want, update the libvulkan*.deb files for Travis but we have to keep in mind that we are limited by Ubuntu 14.04. We use the packages with "ubuntu1~16.04" in the names for compatibility reasons I think. I haven't found any new packages available with the same pattern in the name and a newer package might not work.

Yes, Travis builds because it pulls from universe, but there are new universe packages available. If you don't update Travis you'll have the Windows builds building against a much newer version in comparison to Linux.

Are you sure these new universe packages will work with Travis/Ubuntu 14.04? Which packages would you recommend to use?  I don't think there is a way to have the packages and the submodules synchronized. The most recent package is from "14-Mar-2018" whereas the submodule is more recent.    @kd-11 What are your thoughts on the topic?
Of course they're not absolutely synchronized, but it's close enough to not have any issues.  The packages will work, 14.04 is an LTS Release and is still supported.

Well, it looks like we have an issue with the latest packages:  https://travis-ci.org/scribam/rpcs3/builds/373492523    More information on the issue: https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/9361  > You probably need to either re-archive shellcheck as tar.gz, or source an older deb which is packaged as tar.gz.

That's an upstream Ubuntu issue that got fixed recently  https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/dpkg/+bug/1730627    Can you run `sudo apt-get install --only-upgrade dpkg` before trying to run dpkg?

I pushed some new changes that moves the initialization to when you're booting a game as there was no reason to do it on app startup if you don't update the presence. This also makes it easier to minimize presence updates. Rich presence will not be initialized now if the option is off at startup. There is however some problems with how presence works, such as the fact that if you terminate rich presence, it doesn't update the presence, so the game will still show. And the fact that if you call terminate too quickly after you update the presence (to clear it), the presence will not be updated.    So if you don't want to make a new thread that wait for a second and then terminates, this option needs an app restart or it will still use rich presence, just with a clear presence. Ideas are welcome.
Reverted a bunch of stuff and made it require a restart, I think this is as good as it's gonna get unless discord make `Discord_Shutdown()` actually clear rich presence.

I need a bit more time to test, but this PR seems to finally fix issue #4334 (and maybe #2359 as well?) , but I also encountered some crashes due to "unhandled exceptions" that I've never had before when testing other revisions...

Ratchet & Clank Triology: The third game now has [flickering models](https://streamable.com/qgdnj) if there is too much stuff to render at once. Doesn't seem to affect the other two games as much.     Red Dead Redemption: Still crashes with VK_ERROR_INITIALIZATION_FAILED. [Log with debug output](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/1935260/RPCS3.log.gz).

RDR issue should be fixed.  R&C flickering is a driver "bug" and only happens on AMD. While there are possible ways of working around it introduces either a great performance hit or excessive VRAM usage (basically either increase VRAM heap or add small wait after waiting for a fence to complete). Games should not be drawing 10k+ individual triangles which is something that will get fixed later on. Note that it also happens on master for me (GCN1)

Fixes Disgaea Triple Play Collection in the gamelist.    Allows the selection of Disgaea 4 and D2.  Also fixes the banners showing up in the gamelist.    Unfortunately, there are *severe* issues as the games will still look for important files within the PS3_GAME folder, causing them to crash.    E {PPU[0x100000c] Thread (fios mediathread 11) [0x02b44090]} 'sys_fs_open' failed with 0x80010006 : CELL_ENOENT, “/dev_bdvd/PS3_GAME/USRDIR/Data/SOUND/SndPak.pak” [1]    I figured I'd clarify exactly what the game is doing since I reread my post and it was a bit unclear.    The ISO has three folders within the game folder.    PS3_GAME  PS3_GM01  PS3_GM02    All *three* of these are stand-alone games that I can be used as individual ISOs.  So if I were to split off GM01 into it's own folder as a "PS3_GAME" folder, RPCS3 will see it as a game and it'll load/function correctly.  While this works if you want to play the games, I'd rather the game work out of the box for other users if possible.  Because GM01 is more or less it's own game, the fact that RPCS3 is having the game search for files in the GAME folder is incorrect.
I changed it to use a different approach. maybe this time the games can function properly?

The other two games are still searching in PS3_GAME path for some things.  Here's an example with the GM01 (Disgaea 4)    E {PPU[0x1000013] Thread (_cellsurMixerMain) [0x003b1530]} 'sys_mutex_lock' failed with 0x80010008 : CELL_EDEADLK [3]  E {PPU[0x100000c] Thread (fios mediathread 11) [0x02b44090]} 'sys_fs_open' failed with 0x80010006 : CELL_ENOENT, “/dev_bdvd/PS3_GAME/USRDIR/Data/SOUND/SndPak.pak” [1]  E {PPU[0x1000013] Thread (_cellsurMixerMain) [0x003b1970]} Stat: '_sys_lwmutex_lock' failed with 0x80010005 : CELL_ESRCH [x3256]  E {PPU[0x1000013] Thread (_cellsurMixerMain) [0x003b1970]} Stat: 'sys_mutex_lock' failed with 0x80010008 : CELL_EDEADLK [x814]  E {PPU[0x1000011] Thread (_sys_MixerChStripMain) [0x003b5eec]} Stat: '_sys_lwmutex_lock' failed with 0x80010005 : CELL_ESRCH [x6512]
I should note that the latest version of this PR does fix the issues completely.

I've been investigating a hang in Kingdom Hearts HD 1.5 ReMIX (BLUS31212) and it seems that with SPU ASMJIT this PR reawakens a hang that was happening in recent builds that suddenly disappeared at 0.0.5-6655.    While it may end up just being another timing issue, it seems to be 100% consistent, and using the interpreters does cause the game to start working again in this PR (but not in builds prior to 0.0.5-6655, at least for me) making me think there may be a regression in this change.  Considering the volatility of the hang (and how it seems to have simply vanished with an "unrelated" change) I can't exactly say why this reawakens it.    I've attached a lot of the game being run on the most recent version of the PR as of the writing of this comment.    My Specs - Core i7-6700K, GTX 1070, Windows 10.    [RPCS3.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/1930152/RPCS3.log.gz)    EDIT:  At the advice of @Nekotekina I attempted to use different SPU thread counts, including 1 thread, but, it was not effective at getting around the hang.

Yes, the games are working again. That being said and to be quite honest I think there is a very notable regression on processors with few threads like my i5 4670K. I have lower performance on quite a bit of game or else the sound is messing up a lot more with performance equivalent to before.    Obviously it depends on the games and it's especially on those who rely a lot on SPU. So I don't really know what to think, I guess on an i7 or a Ryzen the performance has improved but is closing the door more and more to the i5.

@Illynir That´s not because you´re using an i5,i3 or i7, that´s because the instrution set of your processor, I got a i7 4790k "the same family and architecture of yours" and all is ok for me with this last PR.

This is exactly what I say, on i7, Ryzen and globally those with many threads the performances are identical or better. On i5 with only 4 threads I see several regressions on quite a few games in terms of overall performance on games using massively SPU. So it's kind of logical that you don't have the problems I'm talking about since you have an i7 of the same family as mine, the only difference being the number of threads, 8 for you 4 for me.    The number of threads is more important than the instruction set, below a critical threshold it poses a problem with RPCS3 which uses it massively. On this PR the difference is even more marked, that's what I'm saying.

Hello there,    Relating inquiries of @Nicba1010 & @Megamouse     As per the [docs](https://discordapp.com/developers/docs/rich-presence/how-to) the images need to be stored on the application's page as assets with the name being the key. This is limited to 150 so it'll be a bit annoying if you want to add all game titles there.    Docs about this:  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/439655/38426150-29904676-39b6-11e8-9f57-5f70c7bec415.png)    Example on the app page:  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/439655/38426214-5bf8f59a-39b6-11e8-9541-bd0e5e0fb215.png)

Apparently uploading images in the application is something they're considering.  > Q: Can I send images via the payload rather than uploading them to my Developer Dashboard?  >  >Unfortunately, the SDK does not support this feature right now. However, we hear your desires! We know that a lot of games, like customization-heavy RPGs, would benefit greatly from being able to programmatically upload assets. It may be something we tackle in the future.  -- https://discordapp.com/developers/docs/rich-presence/faq

Retests all around for anything thats broken.    @Kravickas Lower resolkution threshold to anything below 16x16. For the game "Stealth Inc: A Clone in the Dark", using libvdec.sprx leads to a fatal error (see the related issue) so LLE is not good enough.    Second option for your question:  > it just wont throw the exception with HLE and continue running as normal

I'm not sure the git command from AniLeo will have the intended effect. We want to isolate the change, not mesh it together with the rest.    I'd recommend the following. This is complicated by the fact you opened this PR using your master (avoid that in the future and just make feature branches), but okay.    `git fetch RPCS3` -- This fetches the changes from the main repository.  `git checkout RPCS3/master` -- This switches your current checked out state to the state of the main repository.  `git cherry-pick a2e641fb383e5ccef471c9c6dc0264b66b954fc9` -- This takes a single commit (the one with the fix here, a2e641fb383e5ccef471c9c6dc0264b66b954fc9) and applies it on top of the currently checked out state.  `git branch srm-fix` -- This takes the current state (main repo + fix commit) and gives it a name, so we can easily refer to it later.  `git checkout master` -- Switch back to this branch you opened the PR on.  `git reset --hard srm-fix` -- Overwrite the `master` state with the state we stored in `srm-fix`.  `git push --force` -- And push the fixed state up to Github.

@AdmiralCurtiss it does, I use it all the time. It can squash everything into one commit, and the redundant changes (e.g. merging upstream's changes to fork) are not accounted for.

@pauls-gh Should've just done a pull rebase on upstream. Add upstream remote and just `git pull --rebase upstream master` should fix the commits.  As for the change, it as we had discussed which is ok, I'll implement the split memory access properly later.
Please don't rebase on every upstream commit, otherwise you're taking compile time from other PRs waiting merge. We can issue a rebase before merging, so don't worry.

Sorry about all the git confusion and unnecessary compiles.  I'm slowly becoming a git expert. :-)    **git pull --rebase upstream master**    => I had some merge conflicts with this for some reason.    So instead, this worked for me.    **git rebase -i upstream/master**   => interactive rebase with upstream.  I chose the single commit (SRM fix) that still needs to be upstreamed.    **git push -f**  => force push local to origin    Now my fork shows that I'm correctly one commit ahead of RPCS3/master

I'm new to git/github.  There's only 1 new commit, but it says 11 commits for this pull request.  The other commits are from my previous pull request (which was merged to master) and syncing my fork to the master branch.    Is there anyway to avoid this?
I have made some changes, after discussing this further with developers the interpreter names will remain unchanged while LLVM (PPU) and ASMJIT (SPU) will indicate that they are the fastest option.
The tooltips already explain that PPU Recompiler (LLVM) and SPU Recompiler (ASMJIT) are the fastest options. Adding 'fastest' to the options seems excessive but ohh well...

Some users just see (fast) and click on it, while I agree we don't necessarily have to cater to users like this. Anything that results in users using correct settings will result in less users asking for help or complaining that RPCS3 is slow. And trust me, it does happen quite often.    At the end of the day, this change will not negatively impact anyone, however it will help users who do not read the descriptions.

Will Rpcs3 be affected by changes in Vulkan 1.1 API standards & VulkanRT Loader 1.1.70?    OS : Win7  Display card : AMD RX480  Driver version : 18.3.3

RX 480 is a different generation (GCN4) and has its own problems. As long as the physical device has the string "RX 480" the workarounds should be in effect unless you have "force primitive restart" set in your config file.    Vulkan versions (like opengl versions) have little impact on anything and are usually extensions moved to core. Newer versions usually mean nothing to most developers.

Alot of issues are just whitespace formatting, no big deal. ~~The decoding itself is rather curious although admittedly I have not had as much time to tinker with VTC compression as you have.~~ I find it very strange that nvidia still enforces this extension with no way to disable it on modern opengl, despite every other vendor ignoring it.
Man, you work fast! I was hoping to fix the white space issues before anyone reviewed the code.  :-)    I'll look into the non-power of 2 depth.

@AdmiralCurtiss - thanks for the detailed analysis.  I pushed a change to the src_offset increment that should hopefully fix this.      				src_offset += row_element_count - 4;    If you can't make the change yourself, a build should be available shortly.    BTW, I only have the Tales of Vesperia English patch so I can't test the Japanese text.

@kd-11 - I added code to handle the end case of 4x4x3 or 4x4x2 or 4x4x1.  In other words, the VTC untiling now handles a depth that is not a multiple of 4.  Hopefully, this is what you had it mind from reading the spec.

Still incorrect, I'm afraid: https://i.imgur.com/L7yEa4I.png    In case you didn't notice, the big problem here isn't the slight X offset, although that was certainly also an issue (might be fixed now but hard to say, there's certainly still stray pixels on some glyphs), but rather that it renders characters from a completely different plane.

Thanks for retesting it.  The offset is definitely improved but is still slightly off.  I'm don't know why it renders characters from a different plane, unless I'm misunderstanding the tiling algorithm.    I'll double check the algorithm.

@AdmiralCurtiss - I'm pretty sure I found the problem.      				// Move forward to next group of 4 planes  				src_offset += row_element_count * 4 - 3;    Needed to multiple by 4.  This would have caused planes 1-4 to be copied again and then the wrong plane would be selected.    Please retest and let me know how it goes.  I'm hoping the offset is correct now too.
I captured a frame of Vesperia/Vulkan using RenderDoc and I was able to view all 16 planes of the 3D texture.  All planes showed unique characters, so I think it should be fixed now.

Basic GUI has been created, you can switch users while the main window is up, but you do need to re-initialize the emu in order for the new user to be stored in memory. More questions:    - Should the User Manager have "Save and Close" and "Close Without Saving" buttons? Or is it ok with "Close," and saving the setting immediately?  - I had a problem with the Q_OBJECT macro - it wouldn't build if I left it in the user_manager_dialog class. Taking it out seems to have no effect, other than letting me build. (?)

Q_Object should definitely be used in this case since you're using slots and connects. That macro tells QT's MOC (meta object compiler, what let's Qt do connects in first place with slots and stuff) to function. That'll create the autogenerated file that you can find.    From a cursory glance on my phone (lul), I can't tell why you're getting an error from that macro, but you should definitely be using it.    On top of my head, usually it's because you aren't including something that inherits QObject, but that's impossible given your includes. Otherwise, sometimes, the generated files DONT generate. So you got to cheese Qt a bit. It's simple. Remove qobject. Save. Readd it. Save again. It should pause a bit on saving. That's because it's forcefully rewriting the project's solution file to inform of the auto moc command.    If you still have issues, hit me up on discord. Current alias is chest
usually when you try building with the macro again after you removed it it will work. (i just tried)

I would say config.yml is the correct place for storing this setting, and not CurrentSettings.ini. This is not a GUI-only setting. From my understanding, it will alter the way the emulator runs and how games search for saves and create them. Therefore, it is an emulation setting, and thus belongs in config.yml.

I got reports that `-DUSE_NATIVE_INSTRUCTIONS=Off` didn't work on OpenSUSE OBS, make sure that the AppImages are actually compiling without -march=native

I added a test to make sure the compiler supports "-march=native" before to add this compile option. As such, cmake now outputs:  ```  -- Performing Test COMPILER_SUPPORTS_MARCH_NATIVE  -- Performing Test COMPILER_SUPPORTS_MARCH_NATIVE - Success  ```  if USE_NATIVE_INSTRUCTIONS is set + "Success" if "-march=native" is supported by the compiler.  Because I cannot see this output in Travis logs, I assume it builds the AppImages without "-march=native".    I don't know exactly what the issue is with OpenSUSE OBS but I saw  ```  sed -i \  -e 's Qt5 5.[0-9]\+ Qt5 g' \  -e 's -march=native -msse -msse2 -mcx16 -mrtm g' \  %{name}/CMakeLists.txt  ```  which is probably a workaround they found when dealing with a not working USE_NATIVE_INSTRUCTIONS.    This PR should not affect this behaviour and, maybe, might help to figure out the issue with this extra test.
Are there any more events that should be covered, like `CELL_CAMERA_FRAME_UPDATE`? Or will that relegated to a future PR?
No other events needed, this particular function only registers event queues for `ATTACH` and `DETACH` notifications.

This has nothing to do with rendering, this is a cellCamera pull request. Don't flood

If you set "Camera Handler" to "Fake", this game goes also ingame, likely thanks to your previous PR.  Maybe I am mistaking something but the option "Fake" means to me we are simulating a connected camera. What I want to address in this PR is when you have no camera connected.

I think you misunderstood what Fake is. You just set it on the dropdown Input/Output settings, you don't need any hardware.    Null should emulate no camera, Fake should emulate a (fake) camera. That way all bases are covered.
I haven't expressed myself clearly then.  The attempt of this PR is to improve the "Null" emulation. HW tests on the DECR show that cellCameraInit returns CELL_OK when no camera is connected.
Ah ok so you tested on h/w, didn't get that.  Just verified that cameraInit can never return `CELL_CAMERA_ERROR_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND` by looking at libGem as well.
So, without camera, the camera thread is not initiated, it just returns CELL_OK?
Well, I don't have the answer to this question. @VelocityRa, do you know anything about the camera thread?

Yes, I made the camera thread. Its purpose is to send messages to the event queue registered with the `cellCameraSetNotifyEventQueue*` functions. Such messages are camera connected, camera disconnected and frame update events.    It is therefore useless if the camera handler is set to Null, so the current code is fine. All functions check for its existence before trying to use it, so it is safe as well.    *Edit*: Er, that's not true actually, there's a couple in there that don't check.  I need to check which of the remaining ones need to return `CELL_CAMERA_ERROR_NOT_INIT` and which ones not. I can fix that at a later PR.
If PS3 starts thread regardless it can affect behavior, because we'll be returning CELL_OK instead of ALREADY_INIT.

Excuse me if this is completely wrong (I don't know much about the inner workings of sceNp) but is it possible these titles are using sceNpMatching2Init to check online status and maybe they're all programmed to handle the returns differently?    Perhaps SpongeBob et al don't check for timeouts? You might try returning offline and cross examine the results.    I don't own any of the above games or I would test the theory myself.    As a side note it might be handy to have a spreadsheet for the games that are known to handle sceNp functions, the functions they handle, and the effects of the returns on the game to help debug the sceNp code.

I currently have no idea how `sceNpMatching2Init` works. I found using `CELL_OK` helps some games to go further and as long as it does not introduce regressions, I think it is a worthy change. IIRC my tests on DECR, `CELL_OK` is returned even in offline mode.    Your idea about spreadsheet is good but, I think, very time consuming. Gathering and sharing all these information would be certainly useful for the project so it is a welcome help if anyone wants to do it.

@greentop Retest; Cache prediction gets AMD vulkan back up to 30 fps, nvidia sits at around 27. OpenGL is also 30fps locked, but has more audio stutter. I suspect it has to do with uneven frametimes due to the balancing algorithm being not well tuned yet. Audio stutter with vulkan should be at a minimum.    P.S - The performance drop is warranted. The game is actually copying data from a render target to an allocated buffer, something akin to glGetTexSubImage. Before this PR, the readback would be all zeros, which raises questions why such an expensive call is even being made if there is no visual change. Just another puzzle in the list of this engine's quirks.

As of 785f212, the FPS is roughly between 21 - 23 in Neptunia under the Vulkan renderer, and the audio stuttering is now gone. With the OpenGL renderer, the FPS is roughly between 19 - 21 in Neptunia, and the audio has some minor stuttering.

On master you need wcb and likely cpu blit enabled. Code in this PR autodetects this and enables something similar behind the scenes (note the 2 flush requests). Ryzen has no issues with any game, I fixed that. On master with those settings (wcb, cpu blit) it runs at 1fps or at least it used to.

Even with WCB and CPU bilt turned on in Master, I am getting 7-8 FPS while I use the integrated HD 630. Nvidia seems to crash with API  device lost when WCB is turned on for this game.    With this PR the slowdown in B2S seems to be adversely affected for nVidia GPU(maybe?) or is it that integrated GPU is less affected as it is closer to the CPU, and can do bilt faster?    With nVidia 1050 as GPU (1-2 FPS)  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28158623/36240998-97e79d4c-11e1-11e8-8bc9-3e6a2d424d4e.png)    With Intel HD 630 (2-6 FPS)  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28158623/36241201-c19a42ec-11e2-11e8-923c-9be9f0baf25c.png)

Pretty much. Even amd isnt as badly affected by gpu reads. The call to vkcmdcopyimagetobuffer is oddly expensive on nvidia cards. Intel will always have minimum transfer cost since everything is in system ram.

Nvidia slowdown is partially due to support for D24S8 surfaces. Forcing D32S8 and emulating D24S8 with post conversion is actually alot faster which raises questions as to how this format is actually implemented in hardware.  EDIT: D32S8 can be enabled in debug tab: "force high precision Z buffer"

With the "Use high precision Z buffer" enabled and as of b6dca09, the FPS in Neptunia with the Vulkan renderer is observed to be between 28 - 30, an increase of around 7 FPS. There is also no audio stuttering observed with that configuration. If using the OpenGL renderer, the option will greatly reduce FPS and produce audio stuttering.    ![screenshot from 2018-02-15 10-58-47](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2325766/36267085-1166330e-1241-11e8-9998-69e3b9e0ef05.png)

Apparently, nothing good comes from replacing ``\`` with ``/``.  1) On Linux, \ is legal characer for filenames.  2) On Windows, network locations start from ``\\`` and it can't be replaced with ``//``. And to add more complexity to it, some further parts of the path should remain ``\``.  3) ...    We currently do this only in a single place trying to get RPCS3 executable path. The possible damage is much less than from deploying this algorithm all around.

Confirmed working for me. Fedora 27 (Fully updated).    Just as an aside, I am not sure if this solution is more of a work around. I am assuming in an ideal world that an AppImage is supposed to be self contained and as such should have no dependencies on the host system?    The fact that removing the libfreetype file means that it falls back to using the host provided version suggests that there are other libraries in the AppImage that are falling back to the host versions as well (resulting in the mismatch).    I am not sure how to prove it, I think it might require some input from the AppImage developers themselves but I think there is a dependency on a QT library that is not being bundled with the image.

On what data you assume that second thread argument is unused?  Thread name cannot be changed in thread-safe manner, it won't work this easy.
And no explanation for gui changes.

It's set to zero in the stub that executes the syscall, plus the entrypoint declaration only takes 1 parameter.  As for the GUI, it doesn't update the thread list if no threads have been deleted or created, so the changed thread name doesn't show up.
Regarding thread safety, would changing the name string to `atomic_t<std::string*>` and adding a lock in `thread_ctrl::set_name` suffice?

Stub doesn't prove anything. The parameter exists and may have its specific purpose.  If changing thread name could be done easy and effective, I'd have done it already. This needs much, much more unrewarding work.
Okay, I'll revert the offending changes, though I'd appreciate it if you were to elaborate on how this method of changing thread names is problematic for future reference.
Throwing an exception already does its job. I don't see what are you trying to achieve.
Throwing an exception doesn't make it possible to continue execution

@liududu The option you are asking for already exists. Open Emulator settings and disable the "Use native user interface" option to use the Qt fallback dialogs.
@nhydock Only ansi charset is supported at the moment, so only english characters. Exotic glyphs will show as empty text. Load an english game and you get a view of all the save information possible.

Basic message prompts are now implemented. Confirm that they work. Progress dialogs are not yet done but will be implemented as soon as I have a good test case for more than one progress bar.    @liududu Loading of glyphs outside the basic ANSI set is not implemented. Usually these characters do not actually use the font selected but will fall back to a separate CJK glyph set. That means native UI is not compatible with CJK text atm.    As for autodetection of X and O, its better to have it as a separate option. Even with system set to JP I still prefer X to select and O to cancel as do some other users. Note that some titles will only run if system language is set to JP so its not trivial to just change that.

To install the icons on linux, you must first run the game from its own root folder since there is no fs method to determine the application directory. It will then find the icons and copy them. Its a general problem with rpcs3 on linux. Or maybe it can be added to first run or something.

>I wonder if displaying all the save information is too much (it makes the entries too verbose). I see some games really do store alot of information in the details section which is more than I expected.    Well, you got two options; add a "Is this the save you want to load?" dialog with the extra information listed or reserve some space from right side of the save menu for it. Both approaches have their drawbacks; the extra space looks weird if the game has nothing to display & can get quite cramped for long texts and the dialog option would require an addional button press.    It'd also be possible to show the extra data for selected item only, hiding and showing it as user moves from one item to another. But that'll be much harder to implement especially if you want to add smooth animations to it. You should probably save that for a future PR.

This branch fixes unreported problem with Heavenly Sword Demo. Problem report for interested people: Game expect to compile shaders at the start of level. If you have powerful PC it will probably happen very fast but if you don't game will think GPU stopped working (GPU hang) and will try to load "GPU hang" file and will "trap" not founding it (probably only debug/development version have it). You can bruteforce it to the game by resetting it compile some shaders before crash (81 shaders are needed and it take me 27 restarts each one minute long).   Now it is fixed. What I don't know if it because we are printing compiling shaders at compilation time (what game takes as GPU working) or this branch compile shaders many times faster.

To everyone interested:  I didn't find anything more, which could be missing from sys_overlay.  At this point what needs to be done is refactoring ppu_load_overlay_exec and ppu_load_exec so their functions do not overlap* (overlay module is more or less a smaller version of ppu exec with less features from my point of view).  Since the graphics are broken i'm keeping this PR as is, unless i find a reason why overlay modules would cause corrupted graphics.    As to why mgs4 graphics are broken all i can say is: i do not know.  There are three possibilites:  a) i missed something  b) i did something wrong  c) it's completely unrelated

Woudn't it be better to store the profiles as a vector rather than a fixed-lenght array? That way you could arrange them more freely and delete unneeded profiles from the middle of the list. You'd have to add profile naming though, else it would get confusing really fast. Some kind of dynamic loading would be worth looking into as well to avoid clogging up the system if users create large amounts of profiles.    Saving the profiles as individual files and then f.ex. loading a whole /profiles folder into the UI would be an neat feature as well, but I'd imagine it woudn't be easy to implement since you'd have to work through the OS and it's file system.

So, here's the procedure (for documentation purpose):  1) launch a game  2) close it and modify the evdev_positive_axis.yml  In my case:  ABS_X: true  ABS_Y: true  3) Configuration>Pads>Config and remap your controller  This seems to cover all the special cases. Good job.
I guess this could one day be switched out with a "controller dictionary", but for now this should work.  at least until we added profiles to the mix
You can now also see the "ABS_" name in question when using the "filter noise" button.  This should at least help to identify the proper axis
For now, I imagine that guys with a custom stick won't bother modifying a config file...  Improvements are possible, but I think it's ok for now.

So looks like the regression is in LLVM cache

Rebased and whitespace should be fixed. I thought I could find a complete fix for the Thor save issue (and Wolfenstein has a similar one - it hangs while loading) but this might actually be a race condition. The emulator is a lot faster with the save functions and the scheduling is different.

It is a race condition for both Thor (saving from menu) and Wolfenstein (loading).    Add this to the bottom of "savedata_op()" to wait a second before returning and all is good:  ```    thread_ctrl::spawn("Waiting Thread", [&]()    {      _sleep(1000);      lv2_obj::awake(ppu);    });      lv2_obj::sleep(ppu);      while (!ppu.state.test_and_reset(cpu_flag::signal))    {      thread_ctrl::wait();    }  ```    I am not including this in the PR because I don't know if this is the right way to do it. The technique is copied from sys_net.

Out of curiosity, does kicking the callbacks to trigger through sysutil get past the race condition? Something like     ```cpp  atomic_t<bool> wait(true);  sysutil_register_cb([&](ppu_thread& ppu) -> s32  {  	funcFile(ppu, result, fileGet, fileSet);  	wait = false;  	return CELL_OK;  });    while (wait) {  	thread_ctrl::wait_for(1);  }    ```  around each one

@jarveson That code never calls funcFile and just causes a freeze.    The reason why I did the more complicated lv2_obj::sleep waiting is because thread_ctrl::wait_for does not work in this situation. I have not looked into the scheduling behaviour of the emu in detail but in both games thread_ctrl::wait_for adds a delay but after that goes on as if no wait had happened. So it does obviously not reschedule as needed here.    Here is the behaviour for Wolfenstein:  - with thread_ctrl::wait_for: save is selected - savedata_op() is called - wait is called -> screen freezes for a second - savedata_op() returns - games shows "Reading save data" message on screen and hangs forever  - with lv2_obj::sleep: save is selected - savedata_op() is called - wait is called - games shows "Reading save data" and does not freeze - savedata_op() returns - game starts loading the map    Here it is for Thor:  - with thread_ctrl:wait_for: savedata_op() is called - wait is called -> game continues but does not return to main menu  - with lv2_obj::sleep: savedata_op() is called - wait is called -> game continues - savedata_op() returns - game goes to main menu    Also whie loading the save data during startup Thor displays a black screen on a PS3. With the lv2_obj::sleep patch it does this too. With thread_ctrl::wait_for it does not switch to black at all.    It surely would be better to delay piecewise where the PS3 would, so on every file access and not once at the end.

I'll add min and max size to the log.  You can do so as well if you know how to see what the range is.  If it is non negative then the problem is clear

Axis are checked by ranges from negative to positive space while triggers are checked by 0+ range.    So if your axis has 0+ range it will be handled as trigger.    I could do a button like "handle trigger axis" to whitelist those axis and handle them accordingly
I added min and max to the log message in order to make sure I'm doing the right thing next

**Update**    **Tales of Vesperia**  Not sure if this PR is the cause, but a change (related to the shader cache) solved the PPU Trap! issues. Well, kind of. Loading a save right before a Trap! error with no shader cache will trigger the error, but not if you have one. The error would disappear in a normal playthrough.  **EDIT/CORRECTION:** Not all occurences of the Trap! error are fixed by this method. This error seems to lose its consistency with time. For example:  - previously, it would always occur when entering Capua Nor  - currently, it can occur one time, then after reloading the game/save, it won't occur immediately (the error occurs a short time later)  Right now, only 100% fixed Trap! errors are the one around the end game boss.    **Eternal Sonata**  Driver crash when going ingame with Zcull enabled is fixed.

>Qt 5.9.1 (C:\Qt\5.9.1) has been replaced with Qt 5.9.2 (C:\Qt\5.9.2).     Not better set 5.9.2 ?

According to https://www.appveyor.com/docs/build-environment/#qt, `C:\Qt\5.9` mapped to `C:\Qt\5.9.2`. I don't want to see the same issue in the future (with Qt 5.9.3 for example) so I have chosen to use `C:\Qt\5.9`.

It's not right. Affinity must be supported everywhere.

@Nekotekina According to a quick Google search, it might not be possible on Mac OS. "Mac OS X does not export interfaces that identify processors or control thread placement—explicit thread to processor binding is not supported. Instead, the kernel manages all thread placement. Applications expect that the scheduler will, under most circumstances, run its threads using a good processor placement with respect to cache affinity."
https://developer.apple.com/library/content/releasenotes/Performance/RN-AffinityAPI/#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40006635-CH1-DontLinkElementID_2

This introduced a freeze for me, whenever exiting fullscreen (not entering) the window freezes and then i have a swapchain error:  `E {rsx::thread} RSX: Swapchain: Swapchain creation failed because dimensions cannot fit. Max = 1280, 720, Requested = 2560, 1440`  Happens even with resolution scaling disabled and can be reproduced even on the title screen. This may be another Nvidia specific error.  [RPCS3.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/1484573/RPCS3.log.gz)    Edit: Not game specific, can reproduce on all games so far..

What's the point? Wouldn't be better to just not use shallow clone on AppVeyor if you want to have commit count?

I was told that using non shallowed clone would increase build time substantially.    But even not accounting for that, this approach only displays correct commit count for master builds, making it easier to distinguish master builds from non-master builds, which wouldn't happen if we always cloned from unshallowed clones.    If you have a better approach to do that, please PR it. This is what I could do to fix the commit count ASAP under those conditions.
@AniLeo not build times. Just clone times. And in your PR you are doing exactly that, i.e. you fetch the whole thing anyway. The only benefit I see with approach is that PRs still use shallow clone.
But I'm just fetching the branches, not cloning them?   I'll try finding better approach though, maybe defining depth only on pull request builds, thanks for input
@AniLeo you still download all repo history. I.e. you make shallow clone unshallow. It is the same as just making full (unshallow) clone but in two steps instead of one.
Maybe I'll just remove shallowing and not include commit count on pull request builds, seems good. Thanks again

After 0.0.3-6726 (last commit) log is full of this, and shader compiling happens too often comparing earlier versions.    > E {rsx::thread} RSX: Blit request denied because the destination region does not fit! x812    Just like at #3681 instead of "Framebuffer memory occupied by regular texture"...  nVidia GTX 760 Ti video card.

@greentop  That bug is different from the earlier depth blur bug (where depth of field is applied incorrectly) and seems to affect texture quality only. I am not sure why that is but since its not reproducible on windows it will be difficult to diagnose right now.    Ni no kuni "regressed" due to how a game bug is being handled. The two options we have are:  1. correct graphics in shaders that only do add/sub with invalid data and black output in shaders using mul/div  2. correct graphics in shaders using mul/div and overbright in shaders that use add and likely garbage where sub is used (less likely)    The only "true" solution is to interpret instructions like we do for CPU stuff (hint: performance hit) or generate dynamic shaders after running variable analysis in the cpu which is a huge task and will add on to the problems we already have with the shader cache so I'll leave it as is for now (with overbright menus in some games to avoid generating NaNs from division by 0)

@Asinin3   1. Scaling has never worked with write color buffers + vulkan. Vulkan does not like to be used on demand like that as it uses deferred processing of queues and would suffer significant slowdown if resizing of the data is attempted. A compromise is to crop the image read back from the gpu. Always use 100% scaling or openGL for that.  2. The unreleased value can go up quite a bit, as long as memory consumption does not go very high (i.e small textures are occupying the space) its not a big deal. Verify with GPU monitoring tools that VRAM usage is excessive (e.g over 800M VRAM usage)  3. I have pushed an update for the freezing issue with wcb that can happen in some games. Check if the situation has changed. The mechanism can still fail but I feel the majority of cases are properly handled now.    EDIT: Its possible that there is double counting of sections causing the reported value to grow excessively while the real number is quite small. Its also possible that there is excessive invalidation of sections going on. I'll look into what could be causing that to happen

@Asinin3 Demon's Souls uses cpu readback to only fetch a 16x16 luminance buffer, not actual color data. Thats why the threshold slider is there. At default settings, 16x16 is below the threshold and is not actually scaled. The same goes for any game that uses the readback for anything that is not actual color buffer data.  The cache thrashing issue should be fixed now with https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/pull/3664/commits/427df64423a27e71e58d7a9b8c1f98bbbfe7f643. Performance should be back to normal now and cache evictions should be minimal now, probably even less than master (unreleased textures counter)

Imo, wcb should not be used with scaling if color data is being written back to the cpu. It will downsample the image to fit in the cpu space and then the image will be stretched again to fit the screen. This usually gives very blurry result due to the upscale->downscale->upscale cycle where information is lost every time. I will however set up a mechanism to scale the output if conditions are right.

Yes, the files would still be kept in the git history. To switch to the `zeux` repository, you can either do a fresh `git clone` or run the following commands (for Linux):  ```  git submodule deinit -f -- 3rdparty/pugixml  rm -rf .git/modules/3rdparty/pugixml  git submodule update --init  ```

you have to increase the deadzones or thresholds.  your controller sends small signals even if you don't move it. that's why the buttons are being mapped to the u- axis. when you increase the deadzone it will filter out these small movements.  You can see the received signals by enabling log level notice in the log section of rpcs3 (rightclick on the log to open the context menu).  I suspect you constantly have something like: "mmjoy button U- pressed with value: 5".    For now I have no plan for making the value visible in the gui. soyou have to adjust to these minor inconveniences
In case you don't want the deadzone working ingame you can first map all the buttons with the deadzone and then put the sliders to 0.  Then save and it should be fine

Nice work @scribam , building from CMake on Windows bothered me as well. Sometimes, a developer on Windows would break the Appveyor build because usually his changes are only tested on VS (I did that once). Running VS on Appveyor makes sure that what was tested in the developers machine end up on the Appveyor.     With this problem solved, there's still a lot of windows-specific hacks on CMake files that makes it overly complex. Wouldn't be better just to deprecate this build and remove CMake on windows altogether? This would make it easier to maintain the files. What do others think?

I think we should keep the CMake windows build around, at the very least for building with mingw64. Perhaps if it becomes enough of a burden down the line, we could look into removing it.    Any AppVeyor specific hacks in the cmake though, I'd be ok with them being removed.

It would be better to deprecate `sln` files and move to CMake projects, since CMake support in various IDEs  (including VS) improves every year. That way both Windows and Linux devs would be working on a unified project.

Deprecating VS solution files in favor of a single build system is tempting. But in the end I feel that loads of Windows developers simply don't want to mess with CMake just yet.     @hcorion Ok, I was planning to remove the hacks but let's keep them for the time being. However the CMake build on windows can silently break now that we don't use it anymore on CI.

Unfortunately, it [broke openSUSE](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/Emulators/rpcs3) right after it was introduced into OBS :( Reverting with USE_SHARED_LLVM_LIBS fixes it.    And is it really a good idea for an app to keep its own version of giant compiler on Linux of all things ? Whatever is "interferes" with Mesa should be fixed there, as is [this "primitive restart" problem](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/commit/8f324dfc0a475b95861b97cce1be9e4640f523d2).  Maybe it has something to do with [this Mesa/Vulkan/LLVM issue](https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=99591) ?
Aaaand then it links with its own copy of "libhidapi-hidraw.so" (which it doesn't install) while system is having "libhidapi-hidraw.so.0", so it can't be installed.

Yes, it is still very much necessary to link statically against LLVM. It's not a mesa bug, it's an issue with the way LLVM works. This has nothing to do with the "primitive restart" you mentioned.    Looking at the OpenSUSE build, it has this CMake flag, `-DCMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS=" (llvm-config --libs mcjit vectorize ipo x86codegen x86disassembler)"`, have you tried removing that?    What exactly does it fail with?    I'm pretty sure hidapi links statically against RPCS3.

> Yes, it is still very much necessary to link statically against LLVM. It's not a mesa bug, it's an issue with the way LLVM works. This has nothing to do with the "primitive restart" you mentioned.    I didn't say that it has something to do with "primitive restart", I've linked Mesa/DRI driver loading bug in FreeDesktop. "primitive restart" part was about how instead of making assumptions and permanent workarounds it would be better to ask driver developers directly if you have to. Let them fix these things for everyone. In fact, it's their job, there is paid AMD, Intel, Red Hat, HP, etc. staff in there.    > Looking at the OpenSUSE build, it has this CMake flag, -DCMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS=" (llvm-config --libs mcjit vectorize ipo x86codegen x86disassembler)", have you tried removing that?    That's the first thing I did. It's just adds '-lLLVM', I think. But all those "LLVMCore, etc." files simply don't exist in openSUSE. Nothing short of removing ''llvm_map_components_to_libnames" helped. Strangely, these files were mentioned in my 'locate' database, meaning that may have been removed on LLVM update to 4.0.1. In fact, in [update changelog](https://build.opensuse.org/package/rdiff/openSUSE:Factory/llvm4?linkrev=base&rev=9) I see this:  "Tue Oct 10 12:14:31 UTC 2017 - msrb@suse.com  - Drop llvm4-devel-static. llvm4-devel contains shared library with the same content."    But they also fixed [that loading bug](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/Vulkan-LoaderAndValidationLayers/issues/1978) which I [linked earlier](https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=99591). Not sure that this approach (fetching compatibility on each refresh from the web)  is very good.  Dolphin, for example, uses offline ini DB, which also stores best compat options.    So, another approach, without creating such db in the repo,  would probably be to generate something like this in the appveyor when creating an artifact/build. I.e., where could be some compat. db generated from the website stored locally that rpcs3 will use to display compat. ratings. This has the benefit of the DB being a snapshot of compat. at the time of the build creation (so there shouldn't be any worries regarding a user using older build but seeing the higher compat. for a newer version).
@Megamouse no, it means that Qt Network will support OpenSSL 1.1.0 as a back-end. It still would have to be provided by the OS/dev.

@Megamouse well, there are at least two alternative solutions that don't require using any crypto/ssl:  1) Store DB locally and use that (it could as well be a json from some of the calls to https://rpcs3.net/compatibility?api=v1 (not sure if there is a way to get the whole cmpat info, or it could be stored in the repo and periodically updated, it's not a feature that affect emulation in anyway anyway (yet)).  2) Allow "unsecure" (i.e. over regular http) access to compat. db.    In case you decided that simple compat. rating is worth the hassle, you'd probably need to adjust the cmake script to copy OpenSSL to the bin dir on windows (appveyor already has OpenSSL installed). The devs would manage to install it themselves (or ignore it). @Megamouse what do you mean by `we don't have to link it ourself in case we update Qt`? Qt already dynamically links with openSSL by default. It's jsut that it can't legally ship openSSL dlls/libs along with qt distribution, so you would either ship them yourself (if it's allowed in the target country) or you would tell your users to install it and then your program would just pick it up at runtime.

Means the argument is unreferenced and not used in the function body. You don't have to name unused arguments at all (actually naming them will show a compiler warning about an unused parameter). I wrap in comment to indicate what the argument is supposed to be.

**Ubuntu 16.04 / Nvidia 384.69 / LLVM 4 / (PR3488 as of c7bb414)**    **RPCS3 GPU Additional Settings:**  Enabled - Invalidate Cache Every Frame & Use GPU Texture Scaling    **Game: ToCS BLUS31572**    **PR3488 Vulkan:** The loading of the Camp Menu and Quick Travel menu no longer hangs the game video. Why do i have this bug if i change my resolution other than 1280x720  ![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32216817/30771544-ab080afa-a07c-11e7-8607-35b53eae74ca.PNG).

@joshuacode751 ps3 games usually render at 720p max and are designed around this, Other resolutions are added in after and often make use of features that are not working properly yet.    @greentop  Looks like memory is still leaking when using vulkan, but not when using openGL which is curious.
@kd-11 KH games support 1080p natively on PS3
Like I said, they start with a 720p base resolution and add in workarounds for the other resolutions. The 720p pipeline is often the most straightfoward.

Nice job! Glad to see more users on BSD!
Why not use official FindVulkan module bundled with CMake (not sure which version though)?    At the very least you can just copy https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/master/Modules/FindVulkan.cmake

It appears to have been added in 3.9.2, so we would need to bump the minimum cmake version number as well. And because Ubuntu 16.10 doesn't ship with a cmake version that new, they would have to install a custom version of cmake...  Just to detect vulkan, not worth it IMO.

Following the merge of #3419, @danilaml suggested that I used `windeployqt ` tool to better solve the problem of finding and copying the DLL files that are needed to run RPCS3. So that's what I did in the PR.    I've tested the AppVeyor build and made local clean builds in Release, Debug and Release LLVM modes. Everything seems to be working.
This adds stuff we don't actually use (yet).  Like:  Qt5Svg.dll  translations folder, --no-translations  stuff in imageformats  iconengines folder
I checked `rpcs3/rpcs3.vcxproj` and there are hundreds of occurrences of ` (QTDIR)`. I'd be surprised if a system without this variable would be able to build at all.
@hcorion yes, you need to set up qt location for plugin to work: http://doc.qt.io/qtvstools/qtvstools-managing-projects.html#managing-qt-versions

@Megamouse I think Qt Widgets depend on Qt SVG, but if no svg icons or images are used anywhere, it should be fine. Probably not worth it delete it explicitly, since it only weights about ~320 KBs and that way you don't need to keep track of it in case you decided to add some svg handling.
Yeah but at least translations and iconengines are not needed
I will remove the translations and the iconengines later. However if the do-not-copy list gets bigger than the do-copy list I might just leave the old approach and forget `windeployqt` for now.
new approach has an advantage of working even if rpcs3 gains new qt dll dependencies while the old one would require to manually modify all the solutions and build scripts.
It's easier to remove the few restrictions later than to add new files all the time

I removed most of the new DLLs, however I didn't want to remove imageformats because I couldn't find a clear way to do it and they seems to be useful anyway (it wasn't clear from the documentation the impact of not deploying them).    I've tested the local builds and the AppVeyour, everything seems OK.

Is the `QTDIR` env variable set by the [Visual Studio Qt plugin ](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=TheQtCompany.QtVisualStudioTools2015)?  For those people who don't have `QTDIR` set?
