@hcorion Yes, any non-shallow clone will still download them. So this is mostly housekeeping.

@henriquenj it's just an `exe`. You can query it's location from `qmake` and I think you get `qmake` location from `find_package`. I saw several CMake scripts do that. Or you can just don't include that part in the cmake and add it to the appveyor script (similar to how `linuxdeployqt` is used on travis).
Have you verified that the AppVeyor build works with this fix? It uses cmake, and I'm not sure if the build copies the Qt dlls for packaging.

Just downloaded the zip file it generates. It does not work, the dlls are missing. I'll investigate exactly what AppVeyor is doing and see if I can find a solution.    Meanwhile please do not merge this.

The Appveyor build just zips everything in the `bin` folder. You could probably add a special cmake step for installing the Qt dlls during the build.  IMO you should just leave the dlls where they're at, unless you fancy fiddling with CMake, but I don't think it's worth the effort.
Hcorion covered the exact reason I added them to the bin directory-- I'm too lazy to figure out how to do it in cmake. And, it saves hassle of figuring out the Qtdir when copying

I've used this last Appveyor build to boot some games and it seems everything is working. The Appveyor build indeed performs some strange steps, such as downloading libraries from someone's Google Drive, so it took me a while to get the CMake build running it locally.    I couldn't build on Debug mode using CMake on windows though, I'll take a better look tomorrow.
Ok, seems to work as expected.
The proper and more "robust" and correct way would be probably to use `windeployqt`.

Yesterday I had a look on `windeployqt` but I though it was tied to the nmake/qmake tools, so I was not sure how to use it with CMake. However I managed to use it locally from the windows CMD and it seems to do the job. It somehow found all the DLL files that were needed by just looking at the compiled rpcs3.exe.    The only thing different is that it actually copies more files than we actually needed it. So I'll keep the current CMake solution for now. But I agree that using the QT provided tools seems wiser in the long run.

Map/set wouldn't add much efficiency since page_fault_notification_entries is indexed by event_queue_id in sys_mmapper_enable_page_fault_notification and by address elsewhere.  So, I don't think there's an O(1) solution everywhere without multiple maps. Forward_lists would probably be better for how I'm using it.  But, again, so far all games tested only page fault from one thread and have only one thing being notified-- there isn't much point to optimizing data structures while n=1. Good job on actually getting the length values,    > I don't know if this is because the motion input alway jitters in the LSB (and therefore always changes) or if this is by design.    Its the former of this statement, not the latter. Silent hill depends on the idea that when gyro is enabled, more often than not, it will receive new data, which is completely wrong on their part.    Always reporting non 0 length will cause issues with other games that are coded differently, like for example 'Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo HD Remix' will hang on boot now because its expecting a 0 length value.    https://www.gamefaqs.com/boards/632692-silent-hill-hd-collection/62302779 , the game has controller problems on an *actual* ps3

I can only say that my tests show that there is always "length = 24" data in the buffer even if nothing changes (including gyro data) if the gyro is enabled. Turns out my second controller has a much lower jitter and can actually produce the same values for both analog sticks and the gyro indefinitetly. Still I never get a "length = 0" reply.    Enabling the gyro and then waiting for a 0 packet seems like a game bug to me and should definitely not work at all from what I can see. Maybe some other function that the game calls actually resets the controller input and that is not correctly emulated?

How often is ur test calling cellPadGetData?  If you call it without pause twice on decr, you *will* get 0 len,  ```  ret = cellPadGetData (i, &PadData);  ret = cellPadGetData (i, &PadData);  if (PadData.len == 0) {  	printf("0 len\n");  }  ```  your right, 'Super Puzzle Fighter ' expecting 0 is a game bug but so is silent hill expecting data everytime,. It has issues even on an actual ps3, from my link ( i havent tried after the patch), but i dont think just reporting back data every time when gyro is requested is the solution

I see. My test calls it once per frame, so there is some pause between calls. But still the "new data" flagging is not triggered by the data changing because the data is the same for every call.    It could of course be possible that the flagging for new data is done with higher precision data before converting the gyro range to 0-255. Or maybe new data is delayed by time.

After reviewing the information from this: http://games.soc.napier.ac.uk/resources/ps3_tutorial_003.pdf (it is archived on the wayback machine) it is clear that _always_ returning non-0 data is wrong. That tutorial claims that the minimum time between pad updates is about 10 ms, so probably limited by the packet rate from the controller. So a more correct behaviour for the gyro mode might be returning updated data every time the last call to the function was >= 10 ms ago. Still not quite correct as the updating is asynchronous to the call but maybe close enough.    e: As to why SH has controller issues on a real PS3? Not sure, but a broken gyro in the controller might prevent the controller from sending new packets?

Another attempt. This time only updating every 10 ms if no change occured in between. Just noticed that this only works as intended for one controller though :-/    Seems to close to what a PS3 does. I noticed that also other games have issues with the controller, e.g. in Wolfenstein every time a button must be held down for an action, it retriggers after a short time as if the button was let go with the current code. This code fixes the issue.

When there are several devices, give the lowest to the 1st player, then another one for player 2, ...  2. With the present code, if I plug only 1 joystick, it'll create and control 2 players. Some games (street fighter HD remix) don't allow the same controller to play 2 fighters, but it's not universal.

Yeah there is a bug(set the connects too early), fixing it  Current behavior is:  -On Pad Window: It will keep the input selected but revert to default device if it can't find the device  -On Game: if it can't find the device it reverts to null handler

It's better, but there's another pb: the /dev/input/event-numbers don't survive a reboot.  So, I have this on the log after a reboot, as my new number is 19.  E Joystick /dev/input/event14 is not present or accessible [previous status: 0]  E Joystick /dev/input/event13 is not present or accessible [previous status: 0]  although the pad configuration shows a device at number 19.  This results in a non-working stick (test with castle crashers).

So, I suggest to modify the current behaviour:  -On Pad Window: It will keep the input selected but revert to default device if it can't find the device. It tries to assign a different device to each player.  -On Game: if it can't find the device or the device is already used by another player, it reverts to null handler

`extern` warning is not really a proper warning. It's just a codestyle issue. And there is no way to disable it on GCC (they "forgot" to add that option and it was only recently updated on their bug tracker).    Regarding operator precedence, I haven't touched them since some of them looked like a legit bug, so I'd rather the devs that worked on that modules to look at them. For example in cellPad.cpp `std::min(data->len / 2, 15) & 0xF` doesn't make sense, since the value of min will always be <= 15 (and I doubt that len could be negative, but who knows? That's why I haven't touched it).
The extern is a "proper" warning. extern means the var is declared else where, so here extern should not exist. extern and being declared here makes no sense. :joy:

@paulsapps it makes explicit that this variable is used as extern elsewhere though. And this is a fully valid code. See https://stackoverflow.com/a/21585233/4114447 and https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=45977

I disagree, if its not static then its clear it can be used extern anywhere else. If its static then it can't be used extern anywhere else.     This not idiomatic usage at all thats why there is a compiler warning, it looks like a mistake. Nothing can can see this "extern" declaration because its in a cpp file anyway. Its completely useless.

@paulsapps developers cans see it. Personally I see it like "this variable is intended to be used as extern in other TUs") Anyway, it was introduced by @Nekotekina so I'd rather he decided whether it's useless/wrong or not.

Yeah I get you, but its not idiomatic C++, the thinking should be this:    All globals are intended to be used else where unless they are marked static or contained in an anonymous namespace.    Otherwise `int foo = 5;` appears to not be intended to be used else where no? But it can be because it isn't `static int foo = 5;`. Also the use of extern like that is not consistent with all of the other true globals in the code base.

Hmmm, can you upload your RPCS3.log @gasinvein ? (It's at `~/.config/rpcs3/RPCS3.log`), looks like my joystick detector is faulty.

I think I know the problem. The `JOYSTICK_BUSTYPE` macro is actually just [`BUS_USB`](http://elixir.free-electrons.com/linux/v4.6/source/include/uapi/linux/input.h#L231), so all USB devices are getting picked up as joysticks.    A "proper" solution would be to use libudev, which invokes callbacks with arguments that can be used to determine if the input device is a joystick (it would also add room for hot plugging). However, as a temporary fix, we could [mimic what SDL does](https://github.com/spurious/SDL-mirror/blob/master/src/joystick/linux/SDL_sysjoystick.c#L182-L195). Off the top of my head, I think a libevdev equivalent would be:    ```  if (libevdev_has_event_type(dev, EV_KEY) &&      libevdev_has_event_code(dev, EV_ABS, ABS_X) &&      libevdev_has_event_code(dev, EV_ABS, ABS_Y))  {      // It's a joystick.  }  ```

Can confirm very noticeable desync on initial run in Catherine. It's obviously fine on the second run,  but it's not really fun the 1st time) Is it possible to precompile shaders beforehand? Also, you've probably already seen/read it but here is a nice article from doplhin-emu on the issue: https://dolphin-emu.org/blog/2017/07/30/ubershaders/

ubershaders means implementing a GPU microcode interpreter to run on the GPU. Its nice, but it will be a while before thats done if at all. We cant know where to get the shader data or how they will be used before they are used, so thats a problem. Vulkan has heavier compilation penalties than openGL so if all else fails, fall back to GL. It also has less state permitations than vulkan, and performance is pretty much identical now anyway.

@kd-11 well. maybe something like Asynchronous Shader Compilation would be a good enough workaround for the time being (though no idea how hard it would be to implement in rpcs3), since shader compiling/loading doesn't really stall all the threads correctly in the current implementation either, i.e. it looks like audio threads just continue without much problem while the graphics stutter, creating nasty desyncs in some cutscenes, and that's troubling since it's probably the only place where a lot of new shaders might be introduced as gameplay parts would be pretty much covered after completing first few stages.

Its not so simple. The problem is at the link stage, which will be done by the driver synchronously. The compile step isnt so bad from my measurements. The only way around it is to simiplify shader design (not an option) or lower the number of shader permutations. I'm looking into the latter but the shader pipeline is in a bad state right now.

In Hatsune Miku:Project Diva F (BLUS31319) on vulkan depending on scene every third or fifth or so frame is dropped. I was testing on one song to ensure no new shaders are compiled. CPU usage at ~30-40% and GPU at ~15-20% at all times. Frame drops aren't reflected on FPS counter.  No frame drops prior to this build and newer builds don't help either. OpenGL performance is about the same on any build but it's not buttersmooth like on vulkan prior to this build.

If you use a variable rate monitor, you'll notice the frame isnt actually dropped, its submitted at the 'wrong' time due to lack of framepacing. Framepacing requires a FIFO queue managed by rpcs3 since we already manage the driver's FIFO queue and write to the back and front surfaces directly. This would improve smoothness at the cost of increased frame latency. Before, no new frames were submitted for present asynchronously which is why the frametime metric was stable across samples.
So far Persona 5 has been running really good and a lot less stuttering. I wanted to say that you have done an awesome job! Thanks for all the hard work.

I'm 90% sure changing std::uintptr_t to u64 is not needed.
So long on macos is 64 bit? Thats messed up since they now use x86-64.
@kd-11: Yeah, both macOS and Linux have 64-bit longs (and pretty much every other system) in 64-bit mode. Windows is the odd one out, with 32-bit longs.

Unfortunately on Mac, `std::uintptr_t` is `unsigned long` and `u64` is `unsigned long long` (via `std::uint64_t)`, so implicitly converting between them like is done in JIT is impossible. I chose to replace the `uintptr_t` type with `u64` because that was the least code change.    On 64-bit Linux both are defined as `unsigned long int` so you can freely mix between them.    Note: This just updates the implementation in `JIT.cpp` to use the same types as `JIT.h`.

Why you say memory leak when it's just UB in crypto?  Also I believe "++x += y;" isn't UB, when I'm not against the change in code.

`++x += y;` is indeed undefined behavior. x gets modified twice between what the old standard called sequence points.     `std::unique_ptr<u8> metadata(new u8[metadata_size]);` is a memory leak. The referenced object gets freed with `delete` instead of `delete[]`. You need the array specific template for that.  On a more general note, `make_shared` and `make_unique` should be preferred over new.

In old standard it could be UB but that shouldn't be UB in C++11 anymore. It says  ``The side effect of the built-in pre-increment and pre-decrement operators is sequenced before its value computation``    I know about delete operator. But it doesn't change the fact that the wording is incorrect. Since it's typically not a leak and the memory gets released successfully by either.

No. Only the first element of the array will be freed, the others will not.  Edit: I might have misunderstood you. The last remark was that this new[]/delete mismatch is UB and might or might not leak? Then maybe we can take the language lawyering to irc and keep this about the PR.

@mp-t u8 is a base data type with no destructor. Since free does not take a size variable, this has no effect on most implementations afaik. I'm not defending the mismatched scalar declaration + vector allocation, but it should not leak. Valgrind will complain about it, but in reality delete should still free the whole range (at least on gcc)
Its pointless to say its not leak because its UB, anything can happen. Otherwise you can use this argument for all other types of UB.

In this case the underlying mechanism is well known (malloc/free), and stdc++ sources can confirm the same. It is UB no doubt, but I think the original complaint was that it isnt a memory leak. Its a minor issue with wording and nothing more. It cannot be proven to be a leak, but it can be proven to not be a leak. It is however undoubtedly UB, so why not word it as such.

I know it's faster without the reader lock but I cant guarantee non msvc compilers like gcc and clang will not crash so I added it back for now. A better solution will be more stable. If building for yourself on windows you can comment out the reader lock

Also spu threads does not work the way you think. Its either better performance with it at 1 or 2 or it works better disabled. If you're using 4 threads you will likely only benefit from loop detection

There is some odd behavior with how the game configuration is read.  e.g. If you have the PS3_GAME (i.e. contents of disc) under /dev_hdd0/disc/BLES00296/  And if you have the USRDIR folder with EBOOT.BIN for that game under /dev_hdd0/game/BLES00296/  When you boot from the game list, the global config.yml is used instead of the game config.yml under data/BLES00296/config.yml    This is how the Title in the GSframe looks and the configuration is read from the config.yml from the root folder instead of the per game config.yml stored in /data/(Game Title)    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28158623/28149501-0905da42-675c-11e7-9078-1d8d3833fa9e.png)

I finally found the time to take a look at this.    I tested it with a PS3 controller connected via USB:  - The button mapping was wrong, which is to be expected, as the PS3 controller just maps the buttons linearly, so I wrote my own mapping file: [gist](https://gist.github.com/MonokelPinguin/564ab06665a810426e4053b708079e45)  - After that input was really laggy (10 Seconds for each button press), so I reduced the sleep interval and changed the button mapping form vector<vector<int>> to vector<unordered_map<int>>  - Currently the digital buttons can't be remapped, so I added that.    With those modifications the controller seemed to work really well. I also tried to remove the sleep and instead use select/poll, but they both increased latency by ~0.5 Seconds, which I felt wasn't acceptable. I pushed my changes to my [fork](https://github.com/MonokelPinguin/rpcs3/tree/evdev), if you want to have a look.    Currently integration with the controller remapping dialogue and rumble/button axes are still missing, but that can be done later. Well done!

@MonokelPinguin: I tried your fork with a custom stick  DragonRise Inc.   Generic   USB  Joystick   (/dev/input/js0)  2 problems:  1) Although I created a config_linuxjoystick.yml in my .config/rpcs3 folder, the buttons are wrongly mapped (I used the kde joystick utility to detect the correct button number). For example, I have to press "select" instead of "start", and so on. So buttons are working but are not correctly mapped.  2) I can't figure how to declare the axis for the d-pad (no analog stick on my device).    Lastly, when I press (and release) a button, I've got this on the log:  E Unknown joystick #0 event 4  E Unknown joystick #0 event 4

@toccata10    1. In my case the button order is exactly the same as in the joystick kcm. Does anything change if you swap button mappings after you tested the buttons? I.e map what was select to start. Also did you restart rpcs3 after creating the config and does the mapping change if you remove it?    2. You should be able to map axes with "Right stick - X axis" and so on, although I didn't fiddle with that. Although you currently can only map to the left and right stick axes, not the trigger, dpad, symbol buttons etc, that the original PS3 controller has on almost every button.    The unknown joystick event 4 is EV_MSC, which can be ignored. I get that too and we probably should remove that log message for EV_MSC. Basically some controllers emit this event additionally to the normal button events for every button press and it contains the key code of the pressed button. I still don't know, what the intended use is, but we don't need it.

So, I finally realized that there's an offset:  in kde, the 1st button (the square) is reported as number 1. In the config file, it has to be reported as number 0.  This way, I was able to have my buttons work (and they seem to respond very quickly).    I then tried to have the d-pad working. Putting this in the config file results in a bad behaviour (rpcs3 becomes slow and freezes when I touch the stick).  Left stick - X axis: 0  Left stick - Y axis: 1    So, I removed this and saw that my X and Y axis for the d-pad were swapped (normal on my custom stick which is rotated by 90°). To make them correct, I tried to modify the   evdev/rpcs3/evdev_joystick_handler.cpp  line 29 was:  enum { DPAD_AXIS_X = -1, DPAD_AXIS_Y = -2 };  I changed it to  enum { DPAD_AXIS_X = -2, DPAD_AXIS_Y = -1 };  No change.    I tried also a xbox360 controller. I was able to remap the buttons, but the axis are completely wrong.  The config_linuxjoystick.yml is:  ```  Start: 7  Select: 6  L1: 4  R1: 5  Triangle: 3  Circle: 1  Cross: 0  Square: 2  ```

So I had a look at the axis remapping code:  Currently it works in a way, that you can only swap around the first 4 axes. So you have to remap all 4 axes or you will get duplicate mappings. I can't say why it froze rpcs3 in your case though. Maybe you can set the log to Notice and see if anything is obvious.    I don't know though, if you can remap your dpad to a stick in the way you imagine. A stick only has 2 axes, I'd imagine your pad has one for every dpad button?

To make things clearer, this is what I have when I press my custom joystick: left, up, right, down. When pressing "left", by default, I have a "up" (because my axis are rotated). What I need, is a way to declare that my horizontal axis is "y" and my vertical axis is "x" (and probably, for greater flexibility, a way to declare that those axis could be reversed).  ![joystick configuration du systeme_272](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7478580/28079479-e16e12b8-6668-11e7-9362-1aa2d3b5a0ef.png)  Pressing "up", gives me a "right" signal by default:  ![joystick configuration du systeme_273](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7478580/28079481-e327bc3a-6668-11e7-85c0-950917a7e3bf.png)  ![joystick configuration du systeme_274](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7478580/28079482-e4ea83ea-6668-11e7-823b-f7124079836e.png)  ![joystick configuration du systeme_275](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7478580/28079485-e6a284e4-6668-11e7-976e-72d18cddffad.png)

Then your above mapping should be correct, but you also have to map the right axes to something else.    E.g.:  ```      Right stick - X axis: 2      Right stick - Y axis: 3      Left stick - X axis: 0      Left stick - Y axis: 1  ```

@hcorion The XBox controllers should be working now. @MonokelPinguin @toccata10 For your controllers, you'll now have to add this to the config file:    ```yaml  Axis scaling: false  Z axis triggers: false  ```

Was able to fix using multiple joysticks by changing line 34 in rpcs3/evdev_joystick_handler.cpp from  ```cpp   m_info.max_connect = std::min(max_connect, static_cast<u32>(1));  ```  to  ```cpp   m_info.max_connect = std::min(max_connect, static_cast<u32>(2));  ```    EDIT:  Though a proper fix would just be adding  ```cpp  m_info.max_connect = std::min(max_connect, static_cast<u32>(joy_paths.size()));  ```  at line 59 in `rpcs3/evdev_joystick_handler.cpp`

My tests:  with the added line 59:  1)with 2 xbox controllers: fine  [RPCS3-joy02-2xbox.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/1172253/RPCS3-joy02-2xbox.zip)  2)with 1 xbox controller and 1 dragonrise (custom stick): fine (but the dragonrise remapping is wrong of course)  [RPCS3-xbox_and-dragonrise.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/1172254/RPCS3-xbox_and-dragonrise.zip)  3) with 2 dragonrise: only 1 is detected (see logfile). A bit more testing today: my custom stick works fine most of the time. The joystick is recognized as an analog input, which is often fine. Except on a few games (ex: Dragon's lair, Chaos code): these games are only accepting D-pad input.  In retroarch, they have an "Analog to Digital Type" which can have 3 values: none, left or right.  That's very convenient for custom sticks.  So, my humble request: is it possible to add a parameter in the config_linuxjoystick.yml which could be:  `Analog to Digital Type`  Or:  `Dpad=Left stick`  This would duplicate the input on both the analog and digital  Or:  `Dpad=Left stick digital only`  which would desactivate analog input and just keep the dpad inputs

> @mirh Which axes do you think are missing? Afaik 20 axes are supported (4 Stick axes, 4 axes for Translation/Rotation and 12 for the buttons/triggers)    The analog buttons axis have been dropped in 4.12 (because they were [spilling](https://www.spinics.net/lists/linux-input/msg51824.html) over accelerometers axis)

@raven02 you can adjust the value in your GuiSettings file.Just set the marginFactor ever so slightly smaller.  for example from 0.1 to 0.09  Edit:  the margin is calculated from icon size * marginFactor.  the lower margin is multiplied by textFactor in order to fit the text    so with an icon size of 160* 88 and the default values 0.1 and 2,0 the margin for each icon will be:    16 px on the sides  8.8 px on the top  17.6 px on the bottom    of course all rounded to whole numbers
it's very nice , good job

I'm looking at liblv2.sprx dump, it's pretty certain that it returns -1, 0, or 1. Some standard requires it to be "negative" or "positive", but we know better in this case. This is also why other functions in this module may require manual reimplementation (even those already implemented).

> I have a workaround for the broken gl context init.    Something better than c3701e4b973ed96 ?

Not really better. Actually just the same but with create done conditionally when setting current context since it is not needed on all platforms. You can check the result of makecurrent to determine if you need to force the call to create.

> when setting current context    Done.    > You can check the result of makecurrent to determine if you need to force the call to create.    `isValid()` returns `true` for `QOpenGLContext` when RPCS3 crashes. I couldn't figure out what else to check.

When rpcs3 crashes, the context is valid, but theres no window to bind to. The context->makeCurrent(this) call returns a boolean result that is false if the bind fails. Thats when you call create and try binding again.

Seems a bit crazy that static linking conflicts between apps but dynamic won't? Seems like this problem should be the other way around :S

The LLVM runtime can only be initialized once per process and keeps around a global list of variables visible to other instances. Once an instance confirms the existence of another, the runtime shuts down and exits. This means statically linking any llvm app on linux is useless unless you modify the source to keep the static instance hidden and separate from the global instance created on dlsym since the check is done during `__attribute__((constructor))`.
Can submodules be cached until they don't check out and need updating? Build takes a while cloning them
It's possible, however unless the appveyor is a Premium or Pro account, you might run into a [size limit](https://www.appveyor.com/docs/build-cache/#cache-size-beta)

~I don't think this PR is good, have you tested to make sure this is actually faster? From what I've read from the Travis docs, it's actually faster to download rather than caching them, caching is supposed to only be for files that need to be compiled and can speed up the build by caching the compiled files, I would assume appveyor would be similar.~  I read the appveyor docs, apparently caching downloadable dependencies is fine and is actually recommended.

I didn't know how you would prefer it to detect that, however I can change the commit to invalidate on the change of appveyor.yml, so when you update the yml with the new urls it invalidates the whole cache

Awesome work on getting asmjit updated!   So the things you mentioned from my branch was because i was attempting to use the 'assembler' part of asmjit rather than the 'compiler' feature which is used currently, because i wanted to see if there was a difference in jit compile time, which, unfortunately, really didnt seem to make a noticeable difference during my testing, which is why the branch was left stale heh    In the assembler mode you choose and allocate registers manually, and the lines you mentioned was me just using cherry picked registers that are volatile/non-volatile/parameters on win64 calling convention. Another downside of the assembler mode is you cant use other nice features such as `XmmConst` which is why there are random `InterpreterCall(op);` littered about as i was lazy and just wanted to get a quick concept. So the code is heavily win specific, but can mostly be ignored as the 'compiler' version, which youve kept, will (should) adapt to whatever it is called on    As for your other questions, FuncFrameInfo can be ignored as its more 'assembler' specific, and the errorhandler, while nice, is only really helpful when asmjit fails to compile the code, which i dont think has ever happened so far.    Otherwise, looking at your code changes, functionaly it should be the same, barring any bugs/fixes in asmjit.    This kinda turned into a wall of text, but hope it helps, or let me know if something seems wrong/off/needs clarification

Confusing or not, the PAD Settings option ONLY works for remapping keyboard controls; you cannot remap a controller at this time. Thus the option should reflect that.
What does load automatically + manually actually mean/do? What is its current equivalent?

It does the same thing as having both "load required libraries" and "only load libv2.sprx" enabled at the same time, but it is much more straightforward.    Basically, it loads the libraries that the game says it needs automatically, but it also lets you manually pick additional libraries to load.

Is it though? A new user will have no understanding of liblv2 so telling them that an option does both manual and auto selection makes no sense. Also liblv2 is not exactly manual selection. I mean, the option says that only liblv2 is to be loaded exclusively.  For liblv2 option, a checklist makes more sense imo. I'm a contributor and even I had to have an option explained to  me so I dont think its easier for noobs this way.

I believe the way it is set up right now makes it so that if you have "load required libraries" enabled, "liblv2 only" will add additional libraries on top of automatic ones. I am not sure if I am missing your question or not... sorry if this isn't what you are talking about.
No. This is an important usability improvement. It is literally very necessary.

you can add manual on auto.  In order to prevent user from choosing manually from the get go, auto is set to default with manual disabled

Currently, to build the qt portion with visual studio, here's what you do.    Assumptions, you have the Qt visual studio plugin installed as well as Qt.  Otherwise, you can download it from Qt's website. We haven't finalized Qt's version for RPCS3 (or I haven't been told one yet), but 5.8 works for me.    1) Open rpcs3.sln in visual studio  2) Assuming you have Qt visual studio plugin installed, go to QT5->Open Project File (.pro)  3) Navigate to rpcs3/rpcs3qt and select the qt .pro file.   4) Right click the now uploaded project rpcs3qt, and click "Set as Startup Project"    From there, you can build as normally.  Ie. Click "build solution."
@flash-fire Perhaps you could add a README.md in the rpcs3/rpcs3-qt folder with the steps you just explained above.

@ikki84 your header file is named `cellImeJp.h` with a capital `J`, while cpp file and include inside it use `j`. Linux uses case-sensitive filesystem so build fails there (or more like Windows uses case-insensitive, that's why you probably didn't notice this typo and appveyor build passe). Please fix this.
@btw, judging by the module name, it looks like `J` is supposed to be capitalized, so IMHO instead of using `j` everywhere it's better to use `J`.

@Nekotekina Please explain, as I've really tried hard to implement this as efficient, correct and platform-independent as possible. The only thing I can see is that .find can be changed into .rfind. It runs all the same correctness checks as the old code, and checks g_cfg_vfs_dev_bdvd is a directory in addition. Maybe you want an error message if the value of g_cfg_vfs_dev_bdvd is not valid?

For example, if PS3_GAME appears as a part of other directory name, it'll behave incorrectly. You may alternatively search for "/PS3_GAME/" after appending a '/' at the end and (win32-only) replacing '\\' with '/'.
@Nekotekina By using rfind, the PS3_GAME found by rfind is always the folder we want. If it isn't, then it is not a valid path anyways and will be caught by the check for PS3_DISC.SFB

The games which appear broken (blue tinted sceen) with this PR were already broken with #INF/#NAN values which is why they are overbright. If you check previous output the brightness seems to have been wrong, just that GPUs set invalid values to black. Clamping makes them seem really bright and makes them appear buggy. How does this work when the whole machine gets reset at each build?

From TravisCI doc:   >Travis CI fetches the cache for every build, including branches and pull requests.    https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/caching#How-does-caching-work%3F    In short, TravisCI store/upload the ccache's cache everytime when a build is finished; on the next build, it restore/download the cache files and utilize it.    Due to TravisCI having infrastructure issues now, I cannot point out which line in log does this.

@kd-11 I think that we can safely bump minimum openGL reqs to 4.4, since OS X is still stuck at 4.1 at it seems that apple is more likely to remove openGL support altogether in favor of their Metal(tm) API rather than supporting newer cross-platform open APIs and all GPUs that support 4.3 should support 4.4 too with the latest drivers (according to wiki).

We should also check for required extensions support as well during init to help with non-compliant drivers. Also need to update glew library used to build on travis by the way since it does not have some newer extensions listed (such as ARB_direct_state_access)
@kd-11 `ARB_direct_state_access` is oGL 4.5 though, is it not?

GL4 uses a wierd extensions mechanism (core extensions). If old hardware implements an extension, it works the same as when it is made part of core (no EXT/ARB suffix). Even older terascale AMD supports this extension via GL 4.3. Ultimately GL versions > 4.3 are kinda irrelevant, you just check for extension support and it just works.

Texture cache does not handle small texture invalidation properly! Will add commits to fix the basics here then follow up with a proper implementation later.

On second thought, it might be better to just merge this in as is and add the improvements later otherwise this changeset will become too large.  The joint strike issue is pre-existing; it worked by luck before. I have a fix for it, but it will need testing of its own as it definately affects more games than just 1942.
Vulkan is working again . The other fix can apply later after this merge.

I'm guessing the fault is not handled within the context of the rsx thread which is why the driver is bugging out. OpenGL contexts are only valid for the RSX Thread unfortunately, so more work is needed here. I'm concerned that leaving the caller on wait may cause a deadlock if the rsx_thread is also waiting elsewhere.

@SakataGintokiYT Could you retest? I've added a crude mechanism to allow renderers to process internal work queues posted from other threads. It should fix this issue or at least minimize how often it happens.

@cornytrace `bind_array<NV4097_SET_POLYGON_STIPPLE_PATTERN, 1, 32 * 4, nullptr>();` will loop over the range [NV4097_SET_POLYGON_STIPPLE_PATTERN,  NV4097_SET_POLYGON_STIPPLE_PATTERN+(32*4)] and set all the method pointers to nullptr which is not what you want in this case; or at least that's what I get from looking at the code.
It is so that the pointers do not point to invalid_method, which crashes the RSX.  So yeah it implements nothing, it just stubs it out, just as the lines above and below it.

In that case I think count should be 32 not 32*4. POLYGON_STIPPLE_PATTERN has an address range of 32 (520h to 540h; see gcm_enums.h) and the implementation of bind_array does a for loop setting the next count methods to the implementation pointer. This would overwrite other methods that fall in that range with nullptr.
Travis should be OK now.

@kd-11 Yeah, I thought so too, so I first set it to 32, but still got errors for addresses under 540h, so I thought there was some pointer-size math I had to do. I changed it to 32*4 and the errors went away.  Just now, I changed it back to 32... and it worked T_T  Sorry for wasting your time!  I'll rebase while I'm at it.

No, that's not the case. The reason why you get ILLEGAL_CONFIGURATION is because I limited available configurations to the only one user selected in options. If the game doesn't like the only available option it just doesn't know what to choose. For example, in your case it doesn't like 1080p so it tries 720p even though it is not an available option. If aspect ratio and resolution don't mach it will send VIDEO_RESOLUTION_UNDEFINED instead.  Anyway, game does start up ignoring ILLEGAL_CONFIGURATION error it seems. In GL,  ```     case CELL_GCM_TEXTURE_Y16_X16:          return { GL_RED, GL_GREEN, GL_RED, GL_GREEN};      case CELL_GCM_TEXTURE_Y16_X16_FLOAT:          return { GL_GREEN, GL_RED, GL_GREEN, GL_RED }; ```  In Vulkan,  ``` case CELL_GCM_TEXTURE_Y16_X16: case CELL_GCM_TEXTURE_Y16_X16_FLOAT:     mapping = { VK_COMPONENT_SWIZZLE_R, VK_COMPONENT_SWIZZLE_G, VK_COMPONENT_SWIZZLE_R, VK_COMPONENT_SWIZZLE_G }; break; ```

While the original code was correct strictly speaking, I think we can remove the comparison_func::never case since it makes no sense for alpha kill and alpha test. It is more useful for things like stencil test, where the programmer guarantees that the FAIL path will always be taken, since it usually results in actual render. Issuing a draw call with never pass just makes little sense on such old hardware.
Alright .Will update this PR.
Just add a comment explaining why we're not discarding on never. We'll need more tests to determine correct behaviour.

Humm if i comment out the never case , it returns shader error as below  ``` E {rsx::thread} RSX: Failed to compile shader: 0(69) : error C1048: invalid character 'l' in swizzle "aalpha_ref" 0(69) : error C7011: implicit cast from "vec2" to "bvec2" 0(69) : error C1019: scalar Boolean expression expected  F {rsx::thread} class gl::glsl::link_exception thrown: linkage failed: 'Fragment info ------------- 0(69) : error C1048: invalid character 'l' in swizzle "aalpha_ref" 0(69) : error C7011: implicit cast from "vec2" to "bvec2" 0(69) : error C1019: scalar Boolean expression expected (0) : error C2003: incompatible options for link ```
you still have to handle the never case, just return an empty string {}. Also, i'd like to take a look at that broken shader.

Yes. I see the problem - there is no operation returned when comparison is never. That is why I suggested just  `if (never) return {}` or `if (never) return ""` Either will prevent the last part from being executed since there is no logical operation for never/always comparison  The PR is actually okay as is by the way, I was just requesting that references to never and always are kept to help others reading the code understand why they were dealt with like this.

I don't really understand these format tweaks, UseTab must be ForIndentation as it was already used (with discussible move to spaces in future, but not the opposite). Automatically enforcing clang-format currently doesn't make sense because the tool is broken one or another way, and correctly supports (it seems so) only its default style. I installed VS plugin and prefer to manually apply it to selected fragments of code if necessary, like for formatting enum constant lists. If it breaks something or code becomes ugly, the best approach is to avoid autoformatting at all.

Issue is that it's hard to define rpcs3 coding style in term of clang-format style option. It looks like clang-format doesn't support tab as well as spaces. I'm getting mixed tabs-spaces at line continuation because clang-format uses tab for indentation and then spaces (continuationIndentWidth). Using always for tab + tabWidth matching continuationIndentWidth turns the spaces into tab. Unfortunatly others space sequences may be replaced with tabs... Otherwise clang-format works well for me with the command line ; I once used the visual studio plugin but for some reasons it ignored the settings in the .clang-format file even with the "file" style set in the options. The hook is only active if moved in .git/hooks and without the extension ; the file in the directory doesn't activate it automatically. I added the file just for reference since all the solutions I found with google doesn't handle the non staged change properly or just abort commit if style is wrong.
I will remove the clang changes

I think VS plugin silently ignores the style file when it contains errors, however I can't say for sure. Regarding spaces instead of tabs, it seems fine to not worry about these minor inconsistencies.  ``` AlignAfterOpenBracket: DontAlign ```  This change seems correct.
Removed the tab changes in clang format.
By the way I found this which tell MongoDB's experience with clang format : https://engineering.mongodb.com/post/succeeding-with-clangformat-part-1-pitfalls-and-planning/

Is it really XAudio bug though? It's more like rpcs3 submits more samples than XAudio can handle at the moment. I think It was reliably reproducible in some games after pausing for a long time and then unpausing.  P.S. Just saw that you've came to the same conclusion. So it's more like a bug in our implementation, rather than XAudio itself.
@danilaml I don't recall any limitation for the number of buffers you can submit. And 2.8+ seems OK in the same situation.

@Nekotekina there was a `#define` with max allowed buffers or something.  Here, [found it](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ee419230%28v=vs.85%29.aspx):   ``` XAUDIO2_MAX_QUEUED_BUFFERS Maximum buffers allowed in a voice queue. ```

It's obvious that the queue has some internal size. But it still doesn't mean I can't submit more. Of course, they may be discarded in this case. 2.7 is wrong because it crashes without even trying to recover (it should be easy to detect internally rather than explicitly checking it as I did). It could theoretically return the error code, but I don't see anything like this specified. IXAudio2SourceVoice::SubmitSourceBuffer method doesn't say much too. ~~That's why I assume that discarding excessive buffers is right.~~ No, it's not absolutely right, but rpcs3 having a bug doesn't discard other bugs.

unordered_map was used because the methods array is sparse. There's around 100 entries filled in a 4k array. Ideally there would be a fast way to check if an entry is empty at the expanse of a small overhead for non empty entries. Tweaking hash function may help here.
@vlj What's wrong with sparse arrays? P.S. ~1000 entries, not 100.

Anyway if you want to make it less sparse (which is insignificant in my opinion, but hypothetically), `std::unordered_map` is questionable choice, it's compex and tweaking hash may not be enough. I recommend to wrap array in custom class for such experiments. Its overloaded operator[] may do some lightweight index conversion. It requires some more effort anyway.

According to spec  > memoryTypeBits is a bitmask and contains one bit set for every supported memory type for the resource. Bit i is set if and only if the memory type i in the VkPhysicalDeviceMemoryProperties structure for the physical device is supported for the resource.  Unfortunately this goes against what we have been doing for image memory. We have been assuming that type bits will match memory type. NV approach to this is actually rather interesting. I'm pushing a fix for this. It seems the property flags in the table dont mean anything for images.  EDIT: Actually, both the type property flags and the memory block type bits are used. This can be quite confusing, but it makes sense when you take a closer look.
NV issue should be resolved now.

Cleaned up for merge

Is there a command dump ? m_rtts_dirty is set when surface format/offset/... is changed but the app can reuse the buffer afterwards  For instance a game can render solid geometry in a first pass using color + depth buffers, then render shadows in another depth buffer, then draw shadows on top of the color buffer filled in the first pass. The game reuses the color buffer data and we can't clear it (otherwise we will lost every geometry data rendered). Same case for depth : games often render solid geometry and transparent geometry in two pass. If we clear depth buffer between the 2 pass (because of some postprocessing step for instance) the transparent object will be drawn on top of solid geometry.

@Nezarn What GPU are you using? It may be missing the GL_ARB_Clear_Texture extension. What level of opengl support is provided by HD 4600?  @vlj, Well, only Dx12 is affected by that specific issue since for some reason. Either dx12 is reusing old texture resources or the dx12 clear depth value during texture init is ignored, but I'll have to check. On vulkan and gl clearing new depth buffers to max depth fixes the issue.

@Nezarn It seems to be very poorly implemented on that system then. All this change does is call glClearTexSubImage after a new surface is created. I have no performance difference on AMD GCN. I honestly think you are hitting the software fallback path, or the intel driver uses the same software method for texture clearing which is very bad. I'll modify to use opengl 3 clearbuffer although the code may get a little messier than it should

Apparently the speed is dependent on the type of clear being done, and depth clears are not particularly good.

@vlj Why the array must fit completely in L1 cache if only parts of it are actually accessed? I would think about few cache lines actually used. However I would even store an array of `be_t<u32>` to avoid cost of byteswap for bool conversions. Also indirect function calls (registered methods) may have significant overhead for each RSX instruction compared to current implementation when only u32 value is copied. But I'm not profiling it, it could be that the overall amount of RSX instruction is not that big to produce noticeable overhead...

Actually there is already an indirect function call : for every instruction parsed, the operand is stored and then instruction opcode is tested in a rsx_method_t [] array. What I like is to combine both storage and calls to these special opcode values inside a single function table. To be honest I'm not sure if this PR will improve performance or not. I think it won't make a difference, we may loose some perf when parsing command buffer because of indirect function call but we may gain some performance in backends code by having smaller data members to read and by sorting them by relevance. For instance there are around 20 boolean values accessed as u32 with current implementation, without array they can be grouped on a single dword. As you suggest it would require some profiling (which is likely impractical atm given that there are innefficiencies in other part of rsx emulation, like no buffer caching)  On the other hand with this PR parsing the rsx_state at debug time is much much easier since the real values are accessible to the debuger instead of encoded version. And it's easier to dump rsx_state on disk if needed.
@vlj . It is working okay now .

@vlj I still think it's a mistake to use slow and obscure design just to make some values show in the debugger. If you need to peek them, the right approach would be to customize debug output, something like this: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj620914.aspx  To simplify access to individual values, there is another trick:  ``` C++ struct rsx_state { private:     std::array<u32, 0x10000 / 4> registers;  public:     u16& testreg1 = reinterpret_cast<u16&>(registers[NV4097_SET_VIEWPORT_HORIZONTAL]); ```  Now some value can be accessed transparently. It's not also the only way to implement it. For bit fields, there is `Utilities/BitField.h` custom bitfield class which can work even with big-endian values directly. It is also more correct to avoid using C/C++ "native" bitfields completely because they have unspecified layout. For debugging, as I said, there should be a way to customize debug output: for BEType, for BitField and anything else.

I'm switching to Bitfields atm. The issue I want to solve too is to enforce that whenever and opcode is used in code a dump() function is provided otherwise compilation break. This way command buffer dump should be more accurate and better reflect what is used or not in rpcs3.
The debugger helpers are cool but if you are not using the VS debugger they don't work. Do you plan to have some sort of real time view of the commands or just for debugger only?

Unfortunatly command buffer can change states several time before emitting an actual draw command. I guess it's because of some gfx API layer but it's not uncommon to have "vertex array X : (disabled)" then "vertex array X : type = ... size = ..." or depth write disabled and then reenabled. From rsx point of view only the last command that modifies a given parameter matters (it's a state machine afterall) so it might be hard to find a way that doesn't involve copying parameters to some location.  However I think copying parameters can be improved to some extend : currently every parameters are copied in a 16k array of u32. This array doesn't fit in L1 cache and I suspect it's not uncommon to access distant addresses : When looking at GCM.h it appears that every command block (ie NV4097, NV3062,...) is identified by a value in the high bits ("0x6XXX" for NV3062, "0x8XXX" for NV309E, "0xCXXX" for NV3089...) while some command block don't have a lot of command so a lot of space is unused. Since NV4097 is the 3d engine (and thus the mostly used block) and NV3089 is used to update fragment constant (and thus likely the second one most used block) I guess cache miss are rather frequent.  Another inefficiency is that some parameters are copied twice, for instance transform constant (a first time from command buffer to rsx::method_registers, and a second time to the actual transform constant buffer) or transform program (same : a first time from command buffer to rsx::method_registers and then from method_registers to the transform program buffer).

Actually fragment program constants can be changed by memory write. Fragment constants are inlined in the fragment microcode which is stored in memory, while vertex shader and vertex shader constants are stored in registers. This means that an application can overwrite a fragment constant if it knows where it is stored.   Shader cache needs to check that a fragment shader instruction is not a constant otherwise it will always fail to recognize shader's footprint when a constant change (and it happens quite frequently).  Obviously from PS3 app developpers writing directly to shader microcode is likely not recommended since it requires some synchronisation (to avoid overwriting a constant when a shader is in use by RSX) so they often use a trick, they use the 2d command "NV308A_COLOR" which is used to draw a point in a framebuffer. When setting framebuffer format to float32 and point size to 1 pixel it will write exactly one float in memory at location determined by framebuffer start address, row and column.  This way adding a NV308A_COLOR command can be used to "draw a float pixel" at the fragment constant memory location before the fragment shader is actually used. It makes fragment constant update part of RSX command buffer which prevents concurrent memory access between RSX and Cell.  In RPCS3 the NV308A_COLOR operation is supported in rsx_methods.cpp (see nv308a::color<>::impl)

@vlj Thanks for your explanation. I just don't understand why the fragment shader constants (all of them by the way) get trashed after a short while on opengl and the new decompiler. Admittedly, I don't have a deep understanding of the rsx itself, but I guess I'll have to look deeper then.
Is it not possible to set memory break point on them?

Well, now that I know how the contents can change, finding the real bug shouldn't be too hard. It has something to do with the new rsx/gl cache processing though, since the other backends are not affected.
Seems the raw progam cached is pointing to the wrong ucode address. get_current_fragment_program.addr != raw_progam_.fragment_shader.ucode_ptr. Will update the PR as soon as it is sorted.

The fix is actually easier than expected: the new decompiler considers two programs identical if the ucode is identical and ignores constants when computing the hashes. The retrieved shader is indeed correct, but the raw_program handle may contain out-of-date information. I've changed the PR to use the current ucode_ptr instead of the cached one

@kd-11 , writing to depth buffer (NV4097_SET_DEPTH_MASK) should also only enable when depth testing is enabled, what do you think? (DX12 and Vulkan are not but GL does)
have it fix on Disgaea 4 and The Guide Fate paradox
@raven depth masking and testing are different things. It is legal to write to the depth buffer without a depth test in place.

@raven02 If you look at the GL code, you can see that depth mask is set separately and depth func is only changed if depth test is enabled. However GL is a state machine; the previously set depth func remains unless depth testing is enabled and not set to nothing as your fix does. Unless there is a driver bug, depth func should have no effect if depth test is disabled.  EDIT: If this is a driver bug, it should be reported to NV/AMD
i see.Thanks @kd-11 .
This seems more and more like a driver bug since DX12 has no comparison func with enum 0 which is what is set when you use this fix. It usually falls back to D3D12_COMPARISON_FUNC_LESS

@danilaml this fix is setting depth test function to invalid (thus setting it to less by driver fallback). This should not be necessary since depth testing is already disabled. Just wonder how this change can speedup the loading of LLE modules?

> Just wonder how this change can speedup the loading of LLE modules?  It's just for bulk decrypting a lot of modules at once. It loads every encrypted module one by one into the emulator which decrypts in afterwards, until the all modules are decrypted.  If you look at the code its basically just `MainFrame::BootElf` with a range-based for loop, nothing else.  Saves a lot of time when someone needs to decrypt LLE modules.  ##   First I wanted to extract the decryption code from RPCS3 and write a standalone CLI app for this, but I don't understand the dependency tree (header files) and failed. So I just added this to RPCS3 itself inside the GUI.

Should probably be better to place a mass decryption tool under tools. Making it check if all the modules are encrypted every time a user loads the modules list would increase its loading time, and one only needs to decrypt their modules once or twice.

@DHrpcs3 I have significantly improved my code and also tested it. What do you think about the changes? Its much better now and I also don't make a call to Emu.  EDIT: Also rebased and changed the commit message.

@Nezarn I think we'll track the scaling issue with vulkan and nvidia separately. It's the same issue as https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/1655

@kd-11 but its a bit different than that, since if i don't resize the window, it works fine (while in #1655 game is like that even without touching the window) or is it really the same issue?  example:1280x720 ![rpcs3_2016-06-16_18-28-32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3817985/16124667/27b8745e-33f0-11e6-9bc1-e8208f5a2cf8.png)

@Nezarn We never draw to the actual window ever. There is always scaling in place when we copy the final image to the screen and scaling always happens unless the game's internal resolution matches the window size. This means that for every game, there is a "perfect" window size where everything will be ok, but resizing will trigger the scaling. Try running commercial games at 720x480 and see what happens.

@danilaml Its for users with 1G graphics cards and lower actually. Ingame allocation when other stuff is also allocated goes slighttly over 1G causing paging in and out and reported slowdowns on DX12. It should help alleviate some games slowing to a crawl since most games dont actually use that much vram anyway. Either way, I think the proper allocation strategy should also consider that DWM uses some of that same VRAM so (VRAM-128) is still going to hammer resources.  My proposal is to keep something like MIN(VRAM-128-X, Y) where X is an allowance we can leave for dwm and Y is the limit we choose. I dont think that 1G is actually needed. The GL spec is very vague about what states affect the outcome of glblitframebuffer. It is clear that scissor test, pixel ownership tests and srgb are honoured but nothing is mentioned on write masks. As such, please also disable color masking just in case by setting all channels to GL_TRUE. BLEND, LOGIC_OP and CULL_FACE need not be toggled in my opinion as they are per-fragment and per-primitive operations and the fragment processing stage is skipped during a hardware blit. Depth testing and stencil test may not be needed, but a buggy driver may result in undefined results so its okay to disable them.

@John-Gee The update button creates merge commits, but we always prefer cleanly rebased PRs. That merge commit is likely going to cause trouble for actually cleanly rebasing (from my experience) - ie. you might want to simply redo the commit (_git reset --hard_, reapply your changes and _git push -f_). Also check [git rebase](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-rebase) documentation.

I'm guessing you reset to the master branch and pushed the changes and Github detected that there's no difference between your PR and the master and thus closed the PR. Once again, thank you.

If removed, what it got replaced with?

@Nekotekina glShadeModel is not needed with core, GL_CLAMP is replaced with CLAMP_TO_EDGE and CLAMP_TO_BORDER, I chose to use CLAMP_TO_EDGE. Enabling blend for MRTs is rewritten to use the buffer indices rather than the COLOR_ATTACHMENTn values, after observing debug output from drivers (AMD driver actually replaces it with a call to glEnableIndexed).
@kd-11 What do you mean not needed?  Anyway, according to docs, all three mentioned clamping modes seem different, but now you use CLAMP_TO_EDGE for two of them. That's why I ask.

@Nekotekina glShadeModel was deprecated in favor of shader interpolation qualifiers. GL_CLAMP was removed from core and has no true replacement for it. I went with CLAMP_TO_EDGE to avoid any unwanted seams from border color sampling since this would never have happened using the old GL_CLAMP.
What's the problem with using deprecated features? Why creating obvious regressions without providing an alternative way?

@Nekotekina GL backend was migrated to a core profile recently by vlj. Also, CLAMP_TO_EDGE should give similar results to GL_CLAMP in almost all cases. We could just add them back, but debug layers spam the logs with deprecated feature errors. Also, IHVs dont have to support legacy GL with compatibility profile unless they want to (but it is supported widely on Windows at least).
Ssa is gl_front_face https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/master/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/D3D12/D3D12FragmentProgramDecompiler.cpp#L218

Will have a look later. Btw take attention that ARGB4 is a 16 bits formats. ARGB8 is uploaded untouched to avoid the cost of swizzling but in your code ARGB4 is byte swapped (it's read as be_t<u16> and written as u16). So you likely need to use the swizzle format accordingly.

Was this fixed targeted at any specific game?
I'm more confused by its inclusion in the first place.

It's not targeted at a specific game.   Basically the function returns the true mipmap count of the texture.  RSX can accept a mipmap level of 12 for a 128x128 texture ; however you can reduce such texture only 8 times (128=2^7). In case of compressed texture the base level is a 4x4 texture ie it can be reduced only 6 times Opengl and Vulkan texture is invalid if texture mipmap count is too high. This function is clamping texture mipmap count reported by rsx with the max possible mipmap count allowed by the texture width height and format.
-2 was a typo actually

I used this layout initially, but switched to using separate sets due to issues assigning register locations to varying outputs. This way is better, but i think we need a neater way of assigning the locations (enums or a configuration struct or something instead of having to set location+19).  EDIT: Ignore the first issue. I remembered that I resolved it using another method. A better way of setting the binding location offsets per domain would be nice though.

In DX12 I use 6 "descriptor sets" but D3D12 and Vulkan's descriptor management slightly differ.  I'm still thinking about the best way to do with Vulkan. In DX12 I initially used a single descriptor set but I had to rebind it every draw call so I break it down into 6 "sets", 3 for uniform buffers, one for vertex buffer and two for texture (one for the texture themselves and one for the sampler, they can't be combined). The fragment constant buffer is a dynamic uniform buffer since Nvidia recommended it and MS docs moreless say it's ok to have a couple dynamic descriptors for fragment shader resources since some hardware prefers it.  Moving to finer descriptor layout didn't bring big performance increase since vertex buffer and fragment constants have to change every draw call and I'm still copying texture descriptors to present them as a single array. On the long term however having a split descriptor layouts allows to pass some descriptors (like textures one) as an array of descriptor and thus almost completly removing resource binding from the cpu side. Unfortunatly this is only possible on DX12 Tier 2+ resource binding hardware (ie only GCN 1.1+ Maxwell and skylake).
@vlj could this be detected and used at run-time though?

My only issue was with the hard-coded arbitrary figures. I separated the descriptor sets to 2 to make the code and generated shaders easier to undestand. I still think we'll need a unified way of getting the domain stage offsets in the long run.

It still doesn't work with Nvidia but I think we can fix this after merge.  Two errors reported by the debug layers :  "·E {rsx::thread} RSX: ERROR: [MEM] Code 16 : vkCmdBeginRenderPass(): Cannot read invalid memory e6a0b60, please fill the memory before using." Digging into this error inside the debug layer reveals that depth stencil VK_ATTACHMENT_LOAD_OP_LOAD in renderpass is the culprit. I think it's because the first time the depth stencil image is created it has undefined content. I'm not sure if it's an issue at driver level or if it's more a warning about API apparent misusage. Using VK_ATTACHMENT_LOAD_OP_DONT_CARE fix the issue. I think a proper fix would involve issuing a clear command to a rtt surface right after it has been created.  The second error is  "vkQueuePresentKHR(): Cannot read invalid swapchain image e3f01a0, please fill the memory before using." This one seems to crash Nvidia driver. Investigating memlayer code didn't bring me a lot of information, I suspect here that the swapchain content is considered undefined as well before being presented but flip() should fill it with the content of surface target A or B.

BTW looking at the flip code it looks like there is no barrier to change present image layout. According to https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.0/man/html/vkCmdClearColorImage.html the present image needs to be set in VK_IMAGE_LAYOUT_GENERAL or VK_IMAGE_USAGE_TRANSFER_DST_BIT  layout.

@vlj There is an image barrier during fbo blit. There isnt one during clear though, so i'll add it. The OP_LOAD is there to prevent a draw call from erasing previous draw calls. @raven02 I mean that the current implementation that i'm using tries to avoid download by storing the data on the gpu unless needed, but for now, it never actually downloads the data, only uploads. If the cell uploads (writes) data, the cache will be invalidated (rightfully), but if the cell reads from an old cache in system ram, it will obtain invalid data, possibly corrupting the next write. To make it work properly, I'd need to download gpu buffers when accessed, probably by marking the regions as not-present instead of read-only and downloading when actually accessed. I need a test-case to check correct behaviour though.

I'm not sure how the pitch per index should be fetched. The other values are set in the init() function but not for depth and pitch. Someone more familiar with the core RSX should confirm.
Updated to also affect vertex textures. Fixes alot of texture alignment issues on openGL backend.

Nice catch.   I think gcm.cpp code correctly parses control 2 and 3, I had an issue where some texture related opcode had a stride of 8 and some other a stride of 1.  Dx12 doesn't use texture pitch from the register and computes it from texture width. It'd likely not accurate but I didn't know how to interpret the pitch value from the register when I wrote the code: sometimes it's 0 and sometimes the pitch value is wrong. Actually the pitch value is ignored if texture is swizzled. Textures and their mipmaps level are tightly packed. If texture is linear stored then pitch is used for textures and mipmap levels. Since mipmap width is halved at every level it takes more storage space with unused memory gap (which is sometimes used to store other texture like in after burner climax)  Depth is almost always 1. As far as I know rsx doesn't support texture array so depth is needed only in 3d texture case which are rare. The only game that uses a 3d texture so far is Resogun in the first level.  That's likely why it wasn't spotted before.
@jarveson Indeed; there is a rather large gap between 583-640 (base 10) so I agree with your analysis about the indexing having a stride of 8. Will update accordingly.

I don't know if the z and w value are the same as gl_FragCoords ones. The behavior can be customised with the NV4097_SET_SHADER_WINDOW behavior : https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/commit/f6d2409b2082ead31366b61c5974dcdff49e4ca5  The "origin mode" setting change the origin of the coordinate system : pixel (0, 0) or (.5, .5) can be either the upper left hand corner of the screen ("openGL style") or the lower left hand corner ("D3D style"). Since RSX is a G70 derivative that supports both API on PC nvidia likely left the register for PS3 dev usage. The "pixel center" setting can be used to add a (.5, .5) bias to the pixel coordinate. By default gl_FragCoord stores pixel coordinate as integer value (ie (0, 0)   (0,1) ...(0,1279); (1,0) (11) ...). However from a sampler point of view, texel are located at half one offset. ie the first texel of a texture is "spread" (in unormalized coordinates) between [0, 1] on x axis, the second in [1 2], ... [1279, 1280]. If bilinear filter is used then the exact texel value can be accessed right at the middle of the range, ie 0.5; 1.5; 2.5; ... 1279.5. Since render target textures are often accessed as texture it makes sense to add an half one offset to the pixel coordinates which can then maps 1:1 to render target texel.

@vlj That's better. Is it possible to determine the nature of the texture access from the rsx shader? On openGL there is an explicit sampler for that that would not need any normalization.

Unfortunatly no, RSX sampling opcode are "typeless". They only encode the operation (sample, sample proj, sample + lod) but texture type is stored in hardware register. That's why RSXFragmentProgram has a "   u16 unnormalized_coords;" member that must be filled every draw call. But it's available to the FragmentDecompiler so you can query the i-th bit of unnormalized_coords member of the current decompiled fragment shader : if it is set then the texture is not normalised and the input needs to be divided by texture size in d3d12 (but it looks like GL has the textureRect sampler that just do this), if it's not set then texture coordinate are normalised.

@vlj but can VS2015 check these guidelines as of now? With help of this lib of course. Or newer clang? Maybe it's better to enable these on travis too.

You need to download from NuGet 2 tools, cppcorecheck and gsl (search with "static analysis" keyword).  Unfortunately they're not compatible with shared pch (as static analysis) but it's possible to manually disable pch and run the tools. They're still work in progress and they crash on d3d12gsrender analysis now. I don't know if we should enable the tools for travis. It will print several warnings in the log and they're likely a lot of them. We should fix all the errors emitted by clang before enabling them by default.  Meanwhile it can be run manually on part of project.   Please note that while GSL helps static tools, c++ type system already ensures some bounds and type checking happening at compile time and runtime with as least redundancy as possible. For instance the span template ensures that there is no buffer overflow happening when used naked pointers (which are common since we deal with memory).

@achurch Needs a rebase.  I found that Minecraft [NPUB31419] uses l10n_get_converter and l10n_convert_str of the string conversion functions. This PR makes Minecraft crash. Though previously it would simply make it crash later on in some DX12 string handling, which could've been caused by the problems of the previous string conversion.  **Log:** https://gist.githubusercontent.com/tambry/1a12b5ab89082b181388/raw/4bc2a45c87a5e4b72918c86454e46c0d49388acf/Minecraft%2520%255BNPUB31419%255D

It looks like Minecraft is passing NULL as the destination pointer; it may be that the function treats dst==NULL as "return only the length and discard the data". I'll go ahead and add that in, since I don't see any other reason the program would be passing a null pointer.

FWIW, it does indeed look like Minecraft is using a "get length first" pattern in a previous call (which doesn't crash for whatever reason):  ``` HLE: W {PPU Thread[0x1] (main_thread)[0x0081e1b4]} cellL10n: l10n_convert_str(cd=65536, src=*0x20df0580, src_len=*0xd000f9e0, dst=*0x0, dst_len=*0xd000f9e4) HLE: W {PPU Thread[0x1] (main_thread)[0x0081e1b4]} cellL10n: l10n_convert_str(cd=65536, src=*0x20df0580, src_len=*0xd000f9e0, dst=*0x22ded150, dst_len=*0xd000f9e4) ```  Given that that previous call doesn't crash, it may be that the null pointer isn't the cause of the crash, but the call pattern does suggest to me that this special handling of a null destination pointer is correct.
@achurch You seem to be right:  ``` If NULL is specified to dst, the buffer size required to store the conversion result will be stored to dst_len. ```  I think the PR is ready for merge.

Since there are exception in D3D12GSRender, is it possible to destroy GSRender object if an exception is caught ? If a command is not executed then the backend is left in an unstable state. Future operation will always throw or worst, a device removal signal can be issued by windows and invalidate several pointers. When rpcs3 crashes this is not an issue but with this PR it looks like all exception will be reported to the TTY with the ability to resume execution. The proper way to do in such case is to automatically shutdown D3D12GSRender and potentially restart it.

Thread stopped with an exception will not resume. Other threads may resume, but resuming was not really intended, emulation is paused in order to observe debugging state which is not immediately destroyed.

I initially implemented stencil ops without knowing what the difference was between _WRAP and non _WRAP opcodes and there was no test using the _WRAP variant. But it makes sense that "wrap" means 255+1 is 0 actually. Which is the default (ie non SAT) version in d3d12.  So Bigpet is actually right, the correct mapping is : CELL_GCM_INCR = D3D12_STENCIL_OP_INCR_SAT CELL_GCM_DECR = D3D12_STENCIL_OP_DECR_SAT CELL_GCM_INCR_WRAP = D3D12_STENCIL_OP_INCR CELL_GCM_DECR_WRAP = D3D12_STENCIL_OP_DECR  Still I'd like to have comment mentionning the game where the opcode can be found for testing purpose. A big portion of function in D3D12Formats.h are not properly tested because no app use them (for instance logic op ones). Documenting which app uses a function allows me to know what to test when I'm doing a change (there is no really better way to test gfx code atm).

Mergeable ?

@vlj what was the purpose of moving all these function to map (like `vm.reservation_update`)? They are not "executables" and have different interface than others. They might as well remain separate entity. Because of them map of executables changed to map of void ptrs and conversion from/to `void*` of function ptrs is not well defined afaik (it's either prohibited or implementation defined, but I might be wrong on this). **UPD:** Yeah, it seems to be prohibited in one direction and possibly implementation detail in the other: http://stackoverflow.com/a/25816309/4114447

@danilaml the Call Template was already putting the function to executable_map (which was called executableMap before) : "               m_executableMap[name] = (Executable)(void *&)function;" When building a module we don't use the function address at all. LLVM's ExecutionEngine is responsible for symbol resolution on the other hand, that's why we were recording the name to Executable mapping. With this PR I record all the "system" name to Executable function before creating the module. executable_map can be updated by compiler to record "dynamic" (ie other function to-be compiled) symbols.  Like you mention casting pointer to member is prohibited and that's how I discovered that there was issues with PPUThread::fast_stop. A pointer to member is not a function and ABI is not compatible. Likely we weren't emitting the PPUThread::fast_stop or we didn't execute the call otherwise it would trigger a crash since the pointer is invalid (and we didn't provide the pointer to this anyways)

The function interface doesn't matter btw as long as they are functions. In x86 a function is just an instruction address (pretty much like in PPC), the function call site is responsible for saving register content, pushing the arguments, calling the function, and restoring register after the function returns.  That's different for pointer to member because function can be virtual, a "call" needs to fetch the type of the object and fetch the actual function pointer.

"cannot convert from void(__cdecl PPUThread::_)(void) to void_" Which is conformant with the link you gave.  I have no idea why it built before. We let the template type deduction do the magic and it likely took a type (std::function ?) that could be casted properly to void*.
Use reinterpret cast instead of static_cast

Stop adding noexcept everywhere... It seems 1) Purposeless in most places 2) Even harmful sometimes

Why harmful sometimes ?  noexcept is an hint telling the compiler that the function won't throw, and thus it can optimise away the seh branching logic in windows build. Plus containers like std::vector use a faster implementation if the underlying object has a non throwing move operator.  Of course it's harmful if a noexcept function is actually throwing but it should be fixed in the specific function, not ban noexcept for every other ones.

What SEH branching logic? Anyway, you can't sacrifice correctness for some imaginary optimizations. So the safest way would be to avoid noexcept at all in the first place. If it's really necessary (some function is called from C callback, destructor or something else), it's different question.
@Nekotekina About optimizations, he probably means [this](http://stackoverflow.com/a/15461402/2176813).
Yet you don't tell how they can be harmful and want to sacrifice optimization for some imaginary uncorrectness claims.
But you said it yourself: if the function actually throws, the exception is not passed and calls std::terminate. What should I add?

@vlj this is a function though, not an constructor/destructor. So very little optimization could be made by compiler. And besides, SEH exceptions should be zero cost if they doesn't happen, same with noexcept and terminate. These functions are not truly noexcept too, there are possible OoM exceptions and such, though it shouldn't really matter.

I don't like this `unreachable` thing. If I understood it correctly, If the compiler assumes that default case is unreachable, and any invalid value is taken from method_registers, the result is unpredictable. Plus it doesn't match upper-case macro style.

rpcs3 doesn't define NDEBUG even in release mode, so unreachable just calls abort and can provide line number and file name when it crashes. If we ever define NDEBUG yes the compiler will assume that this code is not reachable and thus will optimise the switch (possibly turning it into a non switch statement) but it's rather for performance build rather than debug one and I don't think we will provide a performance build soon. It suppresses the "control reaches non void" warning emitted by several compilers.  It's used everywhere in llvm (that's where I took the code snippet) as "abort" and "assert(0)" is considered there as not bringing enough information and occuring an unecessarry if statement in code for performance build.
Did you test it? How it's supposed to provide info via the abort call? I don't say that `assert(0)` is better. I just say that "unreachable" looks like a time bomb for me.

Ideally, that "__assume" thing can only be used if you can guarantee that "unreachable code" is truly unreachable. But it's possible only if you have complete control over it, which isn't the case when you take values from method registers.
Make sure that nothing breaks this time =)

is it possible to move "load_vertex_data" calls to backend instead of RSX ? With D3D12 I try to preserve buffer layout as much as possible instead of concatenating attributes so the method is not used.
most samples (cube samples for example) and some games show this error E {rsx::thread} in_weight not found.

Another improvement is to add a "void *allocate_vertex_buffer(size_t);" and "void *allocate_index_buffer(size_t)" + corresponding unmap methods in backend, and have RSXThread call them and fill the given pointer with vertex/index data, thus avoiding extra copies.  Currently RSXThreads copies vertex data to a vector, and the backend copies the vertex data from RSXThreads to the gfx API. It would be better to have RSXThreads copy directly to the gfx API. With GL it could be implemented using glBufferData(..., size, nullptr, GL_STATIC_DRAW); return glMapBuffer(...);
@vlj   > is it possible to move "load_vertex_data" calls to backend instead of RSX ?  possible, but we can make cache in rsx thread instead
