@Nekotekina Could you look into implementing support for structs in callbacks? Since cellSail callbacks are required to pass a struct that contains the info about why the callback was called, etc. Passing a pointer or reference doesn't work.

C++ doesn't support reflection so you can't do much about such structs passed by value. Fortunately, it's rare. The only option is to decompose them manually according to their fields' displacement in GPRs, FPRs, VPRs registers and the stack. Here is a partial solution to cover CellSailEvent specific case:  ``` C++ union CellSailEvent {     be_t<u64> value;      struct _data_t     {         be_t<u32> major;         be_t<u32> minor;     }; };  template<typename T, bool is_enum> struct cast_ppu_gpr;  template<> struct cast_ppu_gpr<CellSailEvent, false> {     force_inline static u64 to_gpr(const CellSailEvent& event)     {         return event.value;     } }; ```

Callback for CELL_GCM_DEFAULT_FIFO_MODE_TRADITIONAL mode:  1) Update `ctrl.put` with `context.current` 2) Calculate bounds of the next command buffer 3) Write jump command, update `context` 4) Wait on `ctrl.get`  I'll try to get more details later, but they may become obvious during implementation of this algorithm.

As told in [a reference](https://stackoverflow.com/a/613132), just add `typename` keyword before it (binary2FS::const_iterator, here) could solve such problem. Or a fragment from [this article](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/dependent_name) below. The `typename` disambiguator for dependent names In a declaration or a definition of a template, including alias template, a name that is not a member of the current instantiation and is dependent on a template parameter is not considered to be a type unless the keyword `typename` is used or unless it was already established as a type name, e.g. with a typedef declaration or by being used to name a base class.
I've added the typename (I think I didn't forget one) and I also reverted the id->Id rename so the change should be less invasive.

@raven02 I copy/pasted the GL decompiler from master for D3D12 ; I intend to factorize the decompiler between the 2 backend because HLSL and GLSL are very close. @Hykem I've seen the original `RPCS3/rsx` deleted by accident. Code and project has `<<<<` inside. I have an easier way for you to restore it totally, and this needs @raven02 's help. Today i got a bad IP and can not come to see you on IRC, so long things short. - `raven02/rsx` was forked from `RPCS3/rsx` you can use this branch. - Find the commit where `rsx` branch was created from raven02's repo. - Delete current `RPCS3/rsx` branch again, and create branch `RPCS3/rsx` with same start point. You can head to `coverity_scan` and find this commit aafd5c01811386d0fe50165a58b081d042e7cd1a and create it here, as on `raven02/rsx`. - Then let raven02 start a new pull, try to merge his `raven02/rsx` to main `RPCS3/rsx`. - Merge those greedly.  Reason for git: When a commit is just after another parent, it could be merged. If a branch has the same branch start point (commit) it could be regarded as the same branch. So this trick should work.  BTW for raven02: please not delete/sync your `raven02/rsx` using `RPCS3/rsx` currently or else it would be much more difficulty to restore.. The `!GIT!` was presumably intentional. I don't know much about the Windows command line but I've found some references to `!var!` being "delayed evaluation" or something.  Could you maybe explain the reason behind that change a little bit better than "works for me"  edit: yeah, looking at [this stackoverflow post](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14347038/dos-batch-why-are-my-set-commands-resulting-in-nothing-getting-stored/14347131#14347131) makes it seem like the `%GIT%` is wrong and the original `!GIT!` was right

@Bigpet Well at least the `!GIT!` doesn't work for me.. Wait a while and let me find some clues about it. _Don't need to care about the results in a command line window. This is Script file related only._ the Delayed Expansion must be stated before use, as [This Answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/13205093) Shown.  ``` @echo off setlocal enableDelayedExpansion  for /f %%i in ('echo aaa/') do set REPO=%%i if "%REPO%"=="" (   echo No input ) else (   echo %REPO:~-1%   echo %REPO:~0,-1%   if %REPO:~-1%==/ set REPO=%REPO:~0,-1%   echo !REPO! )  endlocal ```  You would need to `Delayed expansion must be enabled before you can use it.` And [this](http://stackoverflow.com/a/10558905). Already changed it back to `!GIT!`. That's my System vars broke the intent indeed.

@Bigpet I've read the line and tried out again, found that is my existing system var settings broke the cmd. I'd set GIT to the base folder of my Msysgit/PortableGit installation. So that is my fault. Well since i changed the name and revert the change it now works. Would revert that change.
I can't really speak to the coverally/coverity stuff (since I have no idea about those)  but the rest looks good to me

Although modifying the auto-generated project files works for now it could be a problem in the future since we don't know how CMake, LLVM or VS will change.  If there is consensus that LLVM is adding too much bloat to rpcs3 then I can try and make a .dll of the LLVM libs and have rpcs3 link to the LLVM dll at runtime (GetProcAddress/dlsym). The LLVM headers will still have to remain in the repository.

Well if we update llvm we need to rebuild it anyway, I recognize that this is very fragile solution, which is why I didn't delete the llvm_build.vcxproj  Here's the deal, what we need most is more people working on rpcs3, so one of the very crucial things to me is how easy it is to get your own build up and start tinkering with the code.  I know we are still sorely lacking in the most important part, the documentation. But takes a lot longer than to do something as trivial as providing an easy build.  It may seem trivial to just require "well just install cmake and python and put it in your PATH" and you may say "well if they can't even do that then how are they gonna contribute". But the fact is that before people even seriously consider contributing, they try to build it. I saw projects being set up all modular and supposedly easy and "the right way" but when you need to comb through a bunch of dependencies and/or set up a bunch of property sheets people can easily get frustrated.  The download size of ffmpeg is already rather large, so I can't really complain about the download size of llvm (but it's the reason why I didn't opt to just add prebuild binaries, no reason to make the problem worse), but I'm going to try to find binaries to download for travis at the very least (as we did with wx), since the build time increase is a little much for my taste and we won't be changing llvm code.

Regarding binaries for travis: Linux binaries for LLVM are available at http://llvm.org/apt/. The reason why the travis script was modified to build LLVM from source instead of just installing the apt package is that travis uses Ubuntu precise and the package for Ubuntu precise from http://llvm.org/apt/ does not have the proper CMake scripts. For Ubuntu trusty you can install the LLVM development packages and don't need to compile the LLVM source.
Travis should switch to Trusty in the foreseeable future. It will make builds a lot easier/faster.

@xsacha By default *.cpp files inherit the project settings, the project settings say that there's supposed to be precompiled headers, so you need to include the pch in all *.cpp files unless you manually disable pch for that file.  We could just set the file to not compile or not compile with pch but the whole `#if 0` was to make sure that it doesn't compile under linux (because these files were originally not in the *.vcxproj) and I included these empty files in the project afterwards to make their contents easier to search for in msvc and make sure that people don't forget that they're there and re-create them.

We are not including the emulator headers (Memory, Conlog, System, etc.) on _stdafx.h_ in Linux. So you have to add: `#include "Emu/Memory/Memory.h"` on _SPURSManager.cpp_, after `#include "stdafx.h`. Maybe other headers are required as well.

Just FYI: I have found `_cellSpursEventFlagInitialize` does not check its arguments properly. There are two wrappers of this function which give following parameters: `_cellSpursEventFlagInitialize (spurs, 0, eventFlag, clearMode, direction);` `_cellSpursEventFlagInitialize (0, taskset, eventFlag, clearMode, direction);` So the proper check for null pointer errors would be: `if ((!spurs.IsGood() && !taskset.IsGood())    !eventFlag.IsGood())`  But this is not related to your pull request. So, I merged it. :wink:  **EDIT: I took care of this in my last commit.**

Another thing to note is that probably something will happen to the event flag if `cellSpursFinalize` or `cellSpursDestroyTaskset2` is called for the corresponding _CellSpurs_ or _CellSpursTaskset_ instance. With the current implementation, event flags are free beings who doesn't belong to anything. Probably that's not what real PS3's do. But this is minor stuff, and the currrent method probably works for most of the cases. :-)

Wouldn't ToULongLong be more correct?  That's essentially what it was doing before 0c5526f2fd6efc91f50b0d53a3d165f0baa4d432 (`%llx` = long long.)  -[Unknown]
@unknownbrackets yep, I think so
Unless windows is different, ToULong works on unsigned long, which has the same size as unsigned long long (8 bytes). Unless I am mistaken.

Long is the opposite of short.  On Intel:  Byte = char = 8 Short = word = 16 Long = int = doubleword = 32 Long long = quadword = 64  Java defines long as 64.  More modern architectures (that weren't originally 16 bit) define words as 32 bits and halfwords as 16.  But these are more modern - C++ retains long and short just like near and far pointers of old.  Long is the default int (`long = long int = int = signed` - you're allowed to omit the length or sign or etc.) `short int` is also valid.  -[Unknown]
Interesting. On AMD:  Byte = char = 8 Short = 16 Int = 32 Long = 64 Long long = 64

Windows is always IL32/P64, even on x64.  It is different on Linux (which rpcs3 doesn't even work on right now), but that's simply why it's a bad idea to use long at all.  But on Windows, it's the same as I described.  -[Unknown]
